—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain elected representatives and officers of local governments in Australia shows that:
General Revenue Grants to local government under personal income tax sharing entitlements have increased by 8.2 per cent in 1983-84 over 1982-83,
The inflation rate over the same period was 11.2 per cent,
The increase in grants to State governments over the same period was 11.8 per cent,
Increased demands are being made on local government authorities to participate in Federal Government programs e.g. Community Employment Program,
The Labor Party made a pre-election commitment to allocate not less than the real value of the previous year's allocation in general revenue grants to local government.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government will amend the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act of 1976, to provide a real term minimum guarantee to local government general revenue sharing arrangements in 1983-84, and in future years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bjelke-Petersen (from 11 citizens), Boswell (from 29 citizens), Collard (from 30 citizens) and Jessop (from 37 citizens).

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CHANEY; CHILDS; CHIPP; EVANS; MASON; RICHARDSON
PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 could be used to support the provision by the Commonwealth Government of funding, counselling, etc. for deliberately procured abortions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled:
should amend the Sex Discrimination Bill so as to prevent it from being used in support of deliberately procured abortions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chaney (from 90 citizens), Childs (from 36 citizens), Chipp (from 41 citizens), Jack Evans (from 100 citizens), Mason (from 156 citizens) and Richardson (from 90 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are concerned about foreign owned military bases on Australian territory and the entry into Australian waters and territory of foreign warships and aircraft carrying nuclear weaponry. And that the Australian Government should take an active and constructive role in the promotion of a nuclear-free world. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. Promote the expression of Australian sovereignty by legislating to bring foreign military bases on Australian territory under the control of the Australian Government.

2. Make it compulsory that the disclosure of weaponry carried by foreign warships and aircraft be given in confidence to the Australian Government prior to a request for entry. And that foreign warships and aircraft that carry nuclear weaponry be banned from Australian waters and territory.
3. Legislate for the cessation of all uranium mining in Australia and its subsequent export.

4. Urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to pose to the Governments of the United States and the Soviet Union that both countries agree to immediately halt the testing, production and further deployment of all nuclear weapons, missiles and delivery systems in a way that can be checked and verified by both sides.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned shows-
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally-funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Childs (from 50 citizens), Mason (from 32 citizens) and Zakharov ( from 79 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to
undermine civil liberties and religious freedoms.
entrench abortion funding and render liable to action hospitals, doctors and nurses who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations.
deny to parents their rights to insist that the school ''community'' provide an environment conducive to the development, including the moral development of their children.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of the principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Church of Mary Queen of Peace
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the Church of Mary Queen of Peace Klaipeda, Lithuania was the only church permitted (by the Soviet authorities) to be built in post-war Lithuania. That the church was built by the Catholic parishoners from their own resources and with support from overseas Christians. That upon completion of the church building in 1960, the church was not allowed to be consecrated and, in 1961 was resumed by the State for purposes other than religious. That this resumption of the church and the subsequent persecution and arrests of the local clergy and other christians is contrary to the spirit and the letter of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenent on Human Rights.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled request the Australian Government to communicate most strongly to the Government of the USSR the sympathy of the petitioners for the plight of the Lithuanian Christians and ask that the Church of Mary Queen of Peace be restored to the Catholics of Klaipeda for the practice of their religion without interference.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1988 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to undermine civil liberties and religious freedom. It could also be a means of undermining the traditional family structure of our nation.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: should delay the Bill and ask:
That the Government set up a Joint Parliamentary Committee to examine:
(a) the implications of the U.N. Covenant for public policy, the extent of Australian commitments, responsibilities and accountability in terms of the Covenant;
(b) the full effects of the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 for public policy in giving effect to the U.N. Convention.
The Terms of Reference of the Joint Parliamentary Committee to be widely publicised and oral and written submissions sought from the interested organisations and individuals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 208th report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The 208th report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts contains the Department of Finance minute on the Committee's earlier report-No. 194-on expenditure from the Advance to the Minister for Finance (Appropriation Acts 1980-81). The Department of Finance minute is the formal mechanism used by the Government for responding to the Committee's recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee's 194th report which examined departments expenditure from the Advance to the Minister for Finance (Appropriation Acts 1980-81) was tabled in Parliament on 20 April 1982. In accordance with normal practice, the Committee obtained from departments 129 explanations relating to items from the Advance to the Minister for Finance in 1980-81. Four departments, the departments of Defence, Finance, Industry and Commerce and the Australian Federal Police were selected for public examination and additional written information was requested from a further 12 departments. The only amounts which should remain a charge to the Appropriations for the Advance to the Minister for Finance at the end of the financial year are urgent and unforeseen expenditures which arise between time of preparation of the additional Appropriation Bills Nos. 3 and 4 and the close of the financial year. In its examination, the Committee seeks to ascertain whether or not expenditure from the Advance has been confined to urgent and unforeseeable requirements for which provision could not have been made in the original or additional estimates.

The Committee concluded that in most cases, expenditure was used according to the accepted guidelines. Notwithstanding this, the Committee resolved to act in closer consultation in the future with the Department of Finance in examining departmental requests for funds from the Advance and their final explanations of expenditure. The Committee is satisfied with the Department of Finance response to report 194 and notes that as a result of the Committee's inquiry, policy revisions were effected to establish new procedures to apply to departments submitting applications for funds which will remain a final charge to the Advance in a certain year. The Minister for Finance has agreed that copies of all departmental applications for funds from the AMF which will remain a final charge to the AMF at 30 June be sent to the Public Accounts Committee as soon as possible after approval is granted. Unsuccessful applications for AMF funds classified as 'non-approved' by the Minister for Finance will not be sent to the Committee. This arrangement supersedes the current after the end of the financial year procedure which requires departments to submit to the Committee explanations in respect of each amount that remains a final charge to the AMF.

To assist the Committee in its assessment of the need for recourse to the AMF, it will be necessary for departments to ensure that applications submitted to the Department of Finance for funds from AMF which will remain a final charge to the AMF at 30 June contain or are supported by detail which will enable the Committee to assess the requirement. Estimates explanations relating to the appropriation item concerned that were submitted to the Parliament in the Budget and Additional Estimates contexts or, where a new item is concerned, similar background information, are suggested as possible supporting documents. The applications submitted are to continue to justify the urgent and unforeseen criteria. Applications which do not address the criteria will not be approved. I commend the report to honourable senators.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, I present a report on proposals for variations of the plan of layout of the City of Canberra and its environs-eighty-first series, dated November 1983, together with extracts from the minutes. I seek leave to incorporate a tabling statement and to make a short statement on one aspect of it.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The Report I have just tabled on the 81st Series of Variations to the City Plan covers 19 variations and recommends the approval of work valued at $7m. The Committee in considering these proposed variations took evidence from several organisations including a community group, as well as a member of the ACT House of Assembly.

The Committee approves the variations contained in the 81st Series of Variations except Variation 19. Variation 19 concerns the village of Tharwa and the Committee has agreed to defer examination of this variation so that further studies can be undertaken.

The Committee has approved a variation which will allow the completion of the duplication of the Federal Highway between Wells Station Road and the ACT/NSW border. This duplication is to be completed in time for the Bicentenary celebrations in 1988. The New Parliament House will be opened early in that year and a large influx of visitors is expected for the opening and for a considerable period after the opening.

However, during the Inquiry, the Committee was informed that on present indications the duplication of the NSW section of the Federal Highway will not be completed before 1988. While the Committee understands that New South Wales has other priorities in highway construction, the Committee is disappointed that the duplication of the Federal Highway will not be completed by 1988. The Committee therefore recommends that the Minister for Transport confer with the New South Wales Government to endeavour to have the duplication of this major access road to Canberra completed for the Bicentenary.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the upgrading of the Federal Highway which, certainly, it had been hoped would be completed by 1988. The part in the Australian Capital Territory is proceeding as a result of this decision and will be completed. In the course of our inquiry we were informed that the other part of the Federal Highway in New South Wales would not be completed by 1988. It seems it has slipped somewhat in the New South Wales Government's order of priorities. In view of the state of that road, the amount of use it receives and the danger to traffic at the present time we were somewhat dismayed at that decision. We have recommended that the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) confer with the New South Wales Government with a view to having that road upgraded at least by 1988. I hope the matter will be taken seriously and pursued.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Australian Shipping Commission Act 1956 in order to permit the Commission to operate more as a commercial business undertaking. The opportunity is also being taken to repeal certain sections of the Act which are not appropriate to legislation concerning the establishment and operation of the Commission.
The Bill is of importance to future development of the Australian Shipping Commission which trades as the Australian National Line.

We recognise the importance of reliable economic and stable shipping to Australian domestic and international trade. We recognise the role ANL has played in the development of modern Australian shipping. Equally we recognise the challenge to ANL of current conditions prevailing world-wide in the shipping industry and the need for it to be put on a proper commercial footing.

ANL must be freed of unnecessary bureaucratic restraints if it is to survive and develop. It needs commercial flexibility to respond to market opportunities and to deal with competitive pressures as they arise.
This Bill contains several of the provisions of an earlier Bill introduced with bipartisan support by the former Minister for Transport and Construction, the Hon. Ralph Hunt.

We commend him for this action. But this tentative step in the direction of deregulating ANL was not enough. It did not overcome the years of neglect by the former Government which resulted from lack of leadership and clear policy guidelines.
This Government recognised that if the process of decline in ANL and disharmony throughout the maritime industry was to be reversed several steps had to be taken.

The key ingredients to arrest ANL's decline were five-fold: Firstly, ANL needed to be put on a proper financial footing. It needed an injection of equity capital to put it on a proper commercial basis with an equity/loan gearing ratio more closely related to that of its competitors. An undue interest burden simply added alarmingly to ANL's costs. Any prudent financial manager knows the importance of a company's gearing ratio.

When this Government came to office ANL was in a parlous financial situation. It had a gearing ratio of 15:1 as at 30 June 1982. This worsened with the unprecedented losses being incurred during 1982/83. The cupboard was bare. The Government responded by converting $60 million in loan funds to equity and injecting a further $30 million into the enterprise to put it on a proper commercial basis. It did so on a conditional basis. It called for a determined commitment by management and unions to greater productivity and joint action to improve ANL's performance.
Secondly, management needed to be streamlined and modernised. This is an ongoing process, but several useful steps have been made. Head office staff have been trimmed by 20 per cent.

This Bill also provides for a strengthening of the management team and clarification of the roles and responsibilities of the Chairman and the Chief Executive officer. It provides for a part-time Chairman of the Commission and a full-time Managing Director who will be the Chief Executive and a member of the Commission.
Thirdly, the climate of industrial relations had to be improved and the working relationship between management and employees given a positive and constructive direction.

A better industrial climate was long overdue. The Minister for Transport took the initiative by chairing meetings between ANL management and the unions. We are delighted that both parties have responded positively and have established a better climate for dealing with the serious problems facing ANL.
The unions now have a greater involvement and have a greater opportunity to contribute to the improvement in ANL through the regular consultative meetings that have now been established.

In particular an ANL Shipboard Practices Committee has been established under the Chairmanship of Mr Charles Fitzgibbon who is a Commissioner. This committee is working assiduously to deal with a range of manning and shipboard practices to improve productivity and reduce costs. They have already made some valuable progress.

ANL faces difficult times with world shipping currently depressed and experiencing tough competition. To meet them successfully both the workforce and management must jointly contribute to a more competitive ANL.
The unions are responsibly facing up to implications of the financial stresses confronting ANL. Their officials are making some difficult decisions.
While there may be fewer jobs available in the short term, we stress that this process is essential to ANL's survival, to its growth and to it providing more jobs in the future.

Fourthly, ANL needed to become more commercial, more market oriented, to be freed from bureaucratic restraints and ecouraged to develop. Several of the provisions in this Bill are specifically directed at providing that encouragement and that freedom.

Fifthly, the climate within which the industry operates needs to be conducive to stability and future growth. This requires the Government to set the scene by having policies in place that offer reasonable oportunities for efficient Australian Companies to participate in a reasonably equitable way in the shipping activity generated by the trade and commerce of the nation.

In this area the Government is establishing the climate with responsible policies. We will be introducing legislation these Sittings to give effect to the recommendations for accelerated depreciation allowances contained in the Crawford Report on Revitalisation of the Australian Shipping Industry.

That report was adopted by the previous Government and received bipartisan support from this Government when in Opposition. Again we congratulate the former Minister for Transport and Construction the Honourable Ralph Hunt for his initiative.

We believe that an equitable share of Australia's trade should be carried in Australian ships. Again we would wish to see this done in a responsible commercial way, as envisaged in the recommendations of the Crawford Report rather than by flag reservation.

We acknowledge the need to look realistically at the marketing and other problems in the way this should be achieved. It is, however, our intention that there be a gradual expansion of shipping opportunities consistent with economic recovery and expanded trade opportunities overseas.

This then is the five-point plan. It is not foolproof. We do not promise that it will overcome all the problems of the industry. We do not promise that shipping problems will not occur in the future. It is, however, a comprehensive program designed to place the industry on a more efficient and competitive basis and so provide the opportunity for growth and security.
It will be up to ANL and its employees to grasp the chance for success and work hard to achieve it. The Government can set the climate-but management and unions together must accept the challenge.
Turning to the specific provisions of the legislation.

The Bill quite clearly distinguishes the powers and responsibilities of the Commission and those of the Government. It spells out the need for the Commission to operate commercially and places the onus for commercial initiatives with the Commission.

The improvement in the management of the Commission will be achieved by provisions for the appointment of the Chairman on a part time basis, and of a Managing Director who shall be the Chief Executive of the Commission and a Commissioner. This will provide a more appropriate division of control over the affairs of the Commission and be more in line with top management structures adopted in commercial enterprises.

The Government's direct involvement in the Commission's affairs is reduced particularly in relation to day-to-day autonomy such as the setting of freight rates, contractual arrangements and staffing. Freight rates and fares will be set by the Commission in accordance with general principles which will have to be approved by the Minister and which will meet other obligations under the Act.

Where Government requires the Commission to undertake a particular course of action for policy reasons, the Minister will be required to issue a Direction to the Commission. Any costs incurred because of such directions are recoverable.
A number of other minor amendments to conditions relating to the appointment of the Commissioners and the functions of the Commission itself are included.

There are also a number of other machinery amendments proposed to the Principal Act such as the adoption of finance provisions of the Audit Act and changes to By-Laws and Regulations. The requirements that ANL's officers must be British subjects is also being deleted.

Three redundant sections of the Principal Act are being repealed. These are concerned with the application of the British Merchant Shipping Act to Australian shipping, the purchase and disposal of ships by the Commonwealth and the requirement to obtain Ministerial approval for the normal commercial activity of selling and mortgaging of ships overseas.

Finally the legislation we are proposing will make no call on the revenues of the Commonwealth. However, improvements in the performance of the Commission from this legislation and the other initiatives of the Government, will be of benefit to all users of the Commission's services.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Rae) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 August 1983, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The River Murray Waters Bill 1983 is designed to give effect to an agreement between the Commonwealth and three States, those States being New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. The River Murray Waters Agreement relates to the management of the River Murray in terms of both quantity and quality of water. The Agreement itself is appended to the Bill. This Bill is the culmination of some seven years work in discussions with the States, the end points of which were these: In 1981 agreements by the States verbally with the form of words in the agreement; the signing by the States of an agreement last year; and, in that signing, an indication by the States that they would agree to the implementation of the Agreement even though it had not been incorporated in law. So in fact the terms of this Bill and the terms of the Agreement have been running as though they were enshrined in law for the past 12 months or more. The States have had to pass complementary legislation and they have directed their attentions to that. This is the Commonwealth's form of complementary legislation to enshrine the Agreement. It is, in fact, an agreement brought about by the Fraser Government. I was privileged to be the Minister responsible in the final years in which it came to pass.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me put the situation in perspective. The original River Murray Waters Agreement came into being in 1914. Legislation was passed in 1915 and the Commission was established in 1917. In the intervening period of almost 70 years relatively little change has taken place in the powers of the Commission. The Commission, in the early years, lacked a considerable number of powers. For example, it lacked the power to monitor water quality, to co-ordinate studies concerning water quality or to recommend water quality standards. The fundamental nature of this Bill is that it extends to the River Murray Commission very considerable new powers and responsibilities.

This is an agreement within a federation. It represents the coming together of three States and the Commonwealth to decide on what they will concede to each other in a plan of management. Inevitably, therefore, it is a compromise; inevitably, there will be those who would say that in a centralist system things could be done in a different way. I have to say that within the Federation of Australia, with all the understanding of the nature of the Commonwealth and the States, with all the understanding of the River Murray system, this Bill and this agreement constitute very significant gains in water management in Australia.

It has to be kept in mind that Australia has virtually no major river systems that compare with other river systems of the world. This is the most arid continent on earth. Its average rainfall annually is some 16 inches compared with the world average of 26 inches. If all of the runoff from all the rivers in Australia were tipped into a river, we would not get a river half the size of some of the great rivers of the world. It is significant, therefore, that we are dealing with a river system which is, in that perspective, the major system in Australia. If one takes it in the broader perspective of the Murray-Darling basin, we have a river system which provides 40 per cent of Australia's agricultural production. That is a magnitude to be considered. If we simply take the Murray system for which the Commission is responsible, almost 50 per cent of South Australia's water derives from the Murray.

So we are dealing with Australia's greatest water resource and, if I may say so , Australia's greatest resource. We are blessed with a wide range of mineral resources but water in Australia is precious. The reports of water studies that have been made at various times, including 'A Perspective on Australia's Water Resources to the Year 2000', all indicate that, whilst we are limited in our water supplies, the proper management and husbanding of those supplies can give us an immensely greater use of water. Indeed, the bulk of our water is used for agriculture and not for domestic or industrial purposes.

Against that background, the Murray River, by its very nature, is a slow flowing river. Its shape is such that if it is subject to floods it overflows its banks. It cannot take very large amounts of water coursing down it. The important thing to understand about the River Murray is that in the earlier part of its journey along the New South Wales-Victorian border, particularly along the Victorian side of the border, it follows the course of an old inland sea that extended east as far as Swan Hill. The concentrated salt, the saline content, of that inland sea, some two million years old, is high and is not far from the surface.

We are dealing with a river which has a number of very severe management problems. It has a tendency to draw salt from the surrounding country and from its own river bed. It has a tendency, because it is slow flowing, to develop other problems also. The salinity is one of its main headaches but as far as South Australia is concerned another headache is turbidity, that is, the suspension of organic matter in the water which makes the water turgid. Turbidity is an objectionable characteristic and requires massive filtration. The viability of the water to support plant and organic life depends upon its oxygen content. The nature of the water depends also on the nutrients and any toxic chemicals that may be in the river.

The River Murray is a major resource. We are dealing today with the management of that resource. As I have said, the big problem in the past was that whilst there was general agreement regarding quantity, the question of quality was not involved and, of course, the water quality deteriorated. A vast change occurred in the last 70 years in human life along the river banks. Industries tipped toxic chemicals into the river. There was run-off of petrochemicals into the streams. There has been a demand for agriculture and the techniques of irrigation involved in agriculture have affected the river. Bit by bit, a major change occurred. It became imperative that the River Murray Commission be given the responsibility for water quality.

One of the exciting achievements of this agreement was a consensus by the States and Commonwealth that the River Murray Commission should have the responsibility to monitor water quality. Indeed, the River Murray Commission during my time as Minister commenced to set up-it is now building it-a computer model of the whole River Murray. I understand that the model should be completed in a matter of months. When it is completed it will be possible to make a laboratory study of every aspect of the River Murray, including its quality. The main need to achieve such an agreement was to get the States to agree to provide advanced information to the members of the River Murray Commission of any significant change that would take place in either the quantity or quality of water in the tributaries feeding into the Murray. That in itself was perhaps the greatest achievement of this agreement. The States said that this will not be some minor agreement in terms of riparian rights. It will be a collective agreement dealing with a change in the volume of water or a change in the quantity of water running off the tributaries into the Murray itself. That is the fundamental situation entrenched in the agreement.

As I say, we need to look at the provisions of the past. In the early agreement problems arose from tributary rivers, from adjacent land use, from flood mitigation and protection, from erosion and catchment and so on, and of course, from the need to protect flora and fauna. In the River Murray it is of enormous importance to keep in mind the fact that there is an environmental responsibility of great magnitude. Those who know the unique red gum growths in the Barmah Forest will know that they depend on a stable ecology, on the river flooding in winter and spring, for their life cycle, and they can be threatened by bad management. So we have an enormous responsibility along the whole of the Murray.

Against that background the new Agreement has changed, in quite a number of ways, the old responsibilities. It has given power to the River Murray Commission to consider any or all relevant water management objectives, including water quality, in the investigation, planning and operation of works. That is of great significance. The Commission has been given power to monitor water quality. I stress that. It has been given power to co-ordinate studies concerning water quality in the Murray and to recommend water quality standards for adoption by the States, and to make recommendations to any government agency or tribunal on any matter which may affect the quantity or quality of River Murray waters. The Commission has been given power to make representations to any government agency concerning any proposal which may significantly affect the flow, use, control or quality of River Murray waters. It has been given power to recommend future changes to the agreement and to make recommendations for new water accounting provisions.

So the Commission has come a very considerable journey indeed. This in itself is by way of being a good start. But I have dwelt upon the nature of the Murray and the hazards involved. I have to say, to give some understanding of this, that the River Murray manages, in an average year, to tip about 1.1 million tonnes of salt into South Australia, with devastating consequences, and in a bad year, in a drought year, 1.4 million tonnes. I see Senator Jessop nodding his head. He has had an immensely active interest in the whole matter of the Murray. When one considers that South Australia manages inadvertently to add another half a million tonnes of salt, one realises that the gift to South Australia by the old inland sea and its consequences can be up to two million tonnes of salt a year. Furthermore, one has the problem, as I say, of the turbidity of the water on which so much of South Australia's domestic and industrial supplies depend, both in Adelaide itself and now out into the Iron Triangle through the pipeline.

To understand this, it would be quite wrong simply to say: 'This is great; we have put into place an agreement of historic consequence and therefore things will be right'. I think that 'historic' is not too exaggerated a description. It is true that in the course of the record series of droughts over the last few years, we have been able, by proper management and proper understanding on the part of the States, to so control the water flow in volume through the Murray that the quality of water going into South Australia was less in danger than we had ever thought. Fundamentally, that was primarily due to the fact that the Dartmouth Dam had been built. The wisdom of building it is now proven. In a series of seasons, it managed to fill to 70 per cent capacity. By filling to 70 per cent it was possible to tip water-I think it is down the River Mitta Mitta- to flow through the Hume.

The Hume Dam dried up to a point where the water level was 10 to 15 per cent; it was in fact a mud crab area, virtually waterless. But the flow of the water from the Dartmouth down to the Hume and into the Murray managed to keep the salination down to a tolerable level. Now, of course, the important thing is for the Dartmouth and the Hume to refill and one hopes that that will happen. But what is urgently needed is a large upper Murray storage so that more water can be held in reserve there, filling up in the lush times-in those rare years of lush times-to be used in the years of drought, so that not only the Dartmouth, but also an upper Murray storage, can add to the water supply. I regret very much indeed that a decision of the Fraser Government to undertake as a matter of urgency a feasibility study of such an upper Murray storage, to have been carried out by the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, has been set aside and rejected by the Hawke Government. What is more, it set it aside with ridicule. It claimed that the items in the bicentennial water resources program were irrelevant; that there were matters of higher priority; that they had no basis of efficiency or reason.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have talked about the Murray scheme for the last 30 years.

—I do not wonder that Government senators cry out in pain at the moment because, if ever there was a destructive action, it was the rejection of the feasibility study of the upper Murray. The Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation has the ability and the knowledge to do such a study. It could have been done within a period of six months to a year. The River Murray and its future have been set back years by that decision. It is fundamental that that should have been done. But the people of South Australia will not willingly forgive the Hawke Government for its remarks relating to the undertakings in the bicentennial water resources program, such as its statement that the filtration of Adelaide's water supply and the Iron Triangle were irrelevant; that they were frivolous things dreamed up by the Fraser Government and not important in any way. Those were the words tripped out by the Hawke Government when it rejected the program. This Bill has been introduced but there is no plan to study or to build an upper Murray storage. The pumping situation into South Australia has been discarded and along the way other measures relating to the Menindee Lakes and the study by Maunsell and Partners Pty Ltd were rejected as having no priority or low priority.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate of the words of the Hawke Government that the bicentennial water resources program of $350m consisted of a series of public works that were not of high priority, that were not advanced in any way in planning and which ought to be rejected. Of course, they included such things as the Split Rock Dam and the Glenbawn Dam. Let the Hawke Government tell that to the Wran Government because the Wran Government is now starting on such projects. The rejection of the program included the upper Murray storage and all the projects that are now very apparent as having some urgency. But the Hawke Government hid behind another alibi. It said a study was going on of the perspective of water needs to the year 2000. That study was set up by me as a Minister in the Fraser Government. The Hawke Government said that it would wait for the report and take its advice. I have read the study. It has not been formally tabled or spoken to. The Hawke Government said it would wait for release of the report. It has now had it for months. Everything that the Opposition had said, in terms of principle, is borne out by that study. Indeed, the actual projects that were put into the bicentennial program were shown to the chairman of that study beforehand, as they had been to the States. One by one, everything that the Labor Government said it would do about water, water resources and water storage storage has gone.

Let me take it further. The Hawke Government has said that it will at this stage indicate only that it will complete the fifth year of the five-year program of national water resources. It has said that it will not do as the Fraser Government did, that is, give a guarantee that--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are talking a lot of humbug, and you know it.

—My goodness, there is no reason in the world why Senator Gietzelt should cry out in pain today. One by one, everything the Government has said on this has failed. The Government said: 'We have looked at what the Fraser Government said on the national water resources program, namely, that it agreed to finish the fifth year and to extend it for four more years at a cost of $210m. We will give no undertaking on those extra four years'! In fact , the three States concerned have no guarantees at all that the water programs, including those that Maunsell and Partners had advised, will go ahead. What a proud record the Hawke Government has. It has rejected everything that is worth while with respect to water storage.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me go one step further and mention another fundamental matter. If we are to stop or reduce salinity in the River Murray it is fundamental that we get better farming practices along the banks, particularly-if I am not too insular in this- in Victoria where the inland sea makes its greatest impact. The greatest necessity is for action which will mitigate a rising of the water table. If the water table rises it will bring up salt and damage and destroy the roots of vegetation. Then the water table will move sideways into the River Murray. There will be two kinds of destruction: The destruction of the vegetation and salination of the River Murray. The Commonwealth Government, in my time as Minister, set up in conjunction with the States a working party to look at what practices ought to be encouraged and what incentives ought to be given to get better practices. The working party was to look at how to encourage drip irrigation, micro-jet irrigation, and laser beam levelling of land; and at how to discourage as far as possible flood irrigation. Flood irrigation is harmful in two ways: First, it is immensely wasteful of water; secondly, as it pours over the land, it lifts the water table and creates salination.

The working party has made its report. I am not aware that any initiatives- certainly there are none in the Budget-have been taken on this. Yet, if there is a lesson that the drought of recent years should have taught the Hawke Government it is that the Government ought to be now putting in place every kind of practice that would mitigate salination of the river itself, any practice, for example, that would ensure that evaporative salt pans are placed well below the level of the river itself so that in nature's flood times there is no comeback of salt. The management of this river is of such vital importance that the River Murray Commission needs the support of the Federal Government. I call upon the Federal Government to get the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation- SMEC-to do a crash course and recommend which of the upper Murray storages is the most likely prospect. Feasibility studies of down river flood mitigation and desalination activities and particularly of the Maunsell recommendations should be undertaken now. The Government should change its mind and provide money for South Australia to overcome its turbidity problems. Yesterday the Government announced that it would have money left over from what it expected it would have to pay in unemployment benefit. A few million dollars injected into programs for the Murray would change the whole situation.

What we have now is an agreement which is historic, which is a good example of federalism. There is every indication that the States want to co-operate. They have volunteered information on the significant effect of changes-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the first time you have used the word 'federalism' since your seven years.

—I can understand Senator Gietzelt's desire to interject on this matter because everything that the Federal Labor Government is doing today is aimed at centralising power and destroying the States. His previous Prime Minister said the States were irrelevant, and so did Mr Hawke, the present Prime Minister. Mr Hawke opposes the States, just as Mr Whitlam did. All this seeking of treaty powers is aimed at destroying the States. But that is a diversion which Senator Gietzelt, of course, knows is true and to which he is attracted. The fact is that we have a first class agreement; now what we need is support for that agreement. We need this upper Murray storage; we need the filtration in South Australia; we need the extra work down river in flood mitigation and desalination; and we need incentives for farmers to make sure that we do not raise the water table. If we do that, we will have undertaken for the first time a comprehensive plan in the management of what is Australia's greatest water resource and probably its greatest resource. I commend the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: — I welcome the opportunity of speaking on the River Murray Waters Bill 1983 because it gives me an opportunity not only to demonstrate my continued interest in this very important river system but also to focus attention on the national significance of water to Australia. I suggest, Mr Deputy President, that if you asked people throughout this country what they regarded as our most important resource they would undoubtedly say oil , then coal, uranium, bauxite and iron ore. I think the last thing they would mention with respect to our resource development is water. Without that commodity nothing in Australia would be able to develop for much longer. I give water a top priority and this Government ought to regard it as such if it is interested in continued economic prosperity and the creation of job opportunities.

SPEECH.PARA: The 103 years history of the dealings by colonial, State and Commonwealth governments over the River Murray has been characterised by parochialism, procrastination and bitterness. It is a history in which the States have been the almost exclusive authorities dealing with the Murray and a history in which the Commonwealth, by design and desire, has been prevented from taking an authoritative role. One of the things that I suggest we ought to be looking at in future with respect to this important resource is the Constitution. We mess around with Bills to alter the Constitution to provide, for example, for simultaneous elections for both Houses of this Parliament, something, which I think would create a serious danger for the Senate, and yet we ignore things such as water resources. I suggest that if we want to be constructive we ought to give the Commonwealth a major role in water resources because water knows no State boundaries and no State can develop without it. So the government that has the financial power, the ability to co-ordinate the States in this area, ought to adopt that role, and I will continue to advocate that course of action.

As a result of the prevailing atmosphere of self-interest which clouds State dealings on the Murray, attempts to solve the various problems associated with the issue have been either thwarted or rendered ineffectual. It is quite clear that the history of the River Murray has been devoid of a desire for national development, national well-being or national benefit. That is evidenced by the Bill we are looking at today. The question of the River Murray system has been dealt with ever since 1914. The measure which we are considering today, that is, giving the River Murray Commission some sort of say in water quality, was decided in principle in 1975 by the River Murray working party, yet eight years later we are taking action. I believe this is due to the problems of the plethora of State authorities that are dealing with this important resource. It is demonstrable that something much better has to happen if we are to survive in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yours is much more constructive.

—There is no excuse for Senator Gietzelt to interject. I am saying that in the past governments have neglected to take quick action in these matters. There is no excuse for Senator Gietzelt to disgregard the recommondations of the Fraser Government and brush them aside with the excuse that the Opposition has been in government more than the Australian Labor Party has. Thank heavens we have. That is no excuse for him to avoid and evade the responsibility about which I am talking. I ask him not to interject on what I am saying. I agree that we have to act more quickly.
—I said you were making a constructive contribution.

—I thank the honourable senator. I would appreciate it, however, if he would let me tell him a little more about this important subject. To use a hackneyed phrase, Austraila is the driest continent in the world. Our total stream flow is less than that of any of the major rivers in the world, such as the Amazon, the Mississippi or the St Lawrence. Senator Sir John Carrick made reference to that. He pointed out also that our average rainfall is about 14 or 16 inches a year compared with the world average of 26 inches. He is quite right . Of the water that falls on this continent each year, nearly 90 per cent is lost through evaporation or because it flows into the sea. In fact, 50 per cent of our average runoff flows into the Tasman Sea, the Gulf of Carpentaria and the Timor Sea drainage divisions. It is estimated that only 8 per cent of Australia' s total water supply is used. One per cent is used for domestic, industrial and municipal consumption. Seven per cent of that 8 per cent is used for the irrigation of one million hectares of land and for stock watering.

SPEECH.PARA: To demonstrate the importance of this natural resource, one needs only to look towards the long awaited and eagerly heralded resource boom that started, lapsed and will start again, I hope, once the Labor Party makes some decisions about uranium. We have to recognise that we cannot develop those resources without water. As an example I refer to a proposal to build a number of liquefaction plants. I think they are still currently being thought about in the Latrobe Valley of Victoria. Water consumption estimates range from seven to 30 gigalitres a year for a 100,000 barrel a day coal to oil plant. In the same area water will continue to be needed for Victoria's power stations. I think that about three years ago two researchers concluded, after a study into these proposed developments, that the entire average rainfall flow of the upper Latrobe River system would be committed by the year 2010 and after that date the water supply would need to be augmented by a diversion of water from other East Gippsland rivers such as the Thomson and the Macalister. If this development continues a total water supply of 1,000 gigalitres per year will be required by the year 2020, thus halving the annual flow into Lake Wellington. This would cause profound disturbances to the surrounding wetlands and could result in the destruction of water fowl breeding areas and other areas of interest such as natural flora and fauna. By the year 2039 it is suggested that the total flow of all these East Gippsland rivers would be required. So it is quite clear that the availability of water in the La Trobe Valley is of utmost significance to any future development.

However, we should not assume that that is an isolated instance because the Hunter Valley of New South Wales, the south-east of Western Australia, the Rundle project in Queensland, of course South Australia's Olympic Dam development at Roxby Downs, and the steady expansion of the northern Spencer Gulf area are, of course, examples that we should look at. It is important to recognise that it will not be a shortfall of capital, skilled labour, coal or minerals but a lack of water which will be a major constraint to the development of our resources.

When we talk about water, naturally we in South Australia are worried about salinity. Senator Sir John Carrick mentioned that in dry years 1.4 million tonnes of salt flows over the border into South Australia, added to by about 600 ,000 tonnes in our State. Therefore, we in South Australia believe that a lot more needs to be done to deal with the complex nature of the River Murray which stems from a number of factors. The first is the fact that the Murray and many of its tributaries are naturally saline for the historic fact that several million years ago the course of the river was an inland sea. That was pointed to by Senator Sir John Carrick. Therefore, the salinity in the river will never be completely overcome as it is part of its natural environment. Secondly, the existing salinity has been exacerbated over the years by inefficient irrigation practices and procedures. Structures, such as locks and weirs which raise water levels by up to three metres, tend to increase inflows of ground water to the river downstream. The clearing of land for agricultural purposes and the irresponsible wasteful irrigation techniques, particularly flood irrigation that Senator Sir John Carrick referred to, have increased salinity immensely. Thirdly , the fact that three States and the Commonwealth have attempted to exert influence over the Murray has added to the complex nature of its management. This has brought to the fore State rivalries and the ever present State fears of centralism. Clearly, such fears and rivalries are overshadowed, or should be overshadowed, by throughts of the national interest. Certainly, our current and past attitudes do not have regard to the long term development of the States.

Finally, the Murray situation has been clouded by the differing importance attached to it by the three concerned States. New South Wales and Victoria have irrigation lands totalling over 500,000 hectares which compares with South Australia's irrigation area of 40,000 hectares. Yet, in South Australia, Adelaide and the northern Spencer Gulf area-the Iron Triangle, as it is now referred to-depend upon the Murray for water for industrial and domestic uses, and this dependency has no counterpart in other States. I was able to get Mr Alan Wood the member for Swan Hill and the former Minister of Public Works, Property and Services in the Victorian Government, to come to South Australia at a time when the mouth of the River Murray was closed. The Senate Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment, of which I am a member, visited the area and subsequently presented a report. He, being a rural representative and a Minister in the Victorian Cabinet, recognised, as did the South Australian Tonkin Government, that a national approach ought to be the way to go with respect to this resource. He agreed with the South Australian Government and was going to exert his influence to try to get the Victorian Government to agree that the Commonwealth should take a much more significant role with respect to water resources in Australia.

The complexities I have referred to have confounded successive governments in their attempts to find solutions to the salinity problems of the River Murray system. In addition to these examples of waterway salinity in our system, areas of north east Victoria are severely affected by dry land salinity which has been caused by injudicious use of ground water. I think that anyone who considered all the points that I have mentioned would come to the conclusion that Australia 's water resources are in a parlous state. Given the fact that Australia is a dry continent with most of its water lost through either runoff or evaporation, having few inland waterways and with those in existence suffering pollution problems, one would reasonably assume that governments would attach much more importance to the preservation of our water resources. Regrettably, this has not been the case. I believe that it is a sorry state of affairs for us to continue to disregard the importance of this national asset to Australia. I regard it to be an indictment of goverments.

Australia's history of management of our precious resource has been characterised, I believe, by ad hockery and political expediency. The Commonwealth and the States in the past have failed to accept that water is a resource not only vital to the development of this country but also it is beyond the individual capacities of the States to manage. The high cost associated with this management and conservation has resulted in a piecemeal approach to water resources which is evident today. This position has been aggravated because of an understandable overriding inherent suspicion on the part of the States that the other States could get more than their fair share. I think that the Commonwealth should have an overriding influence in this area.

The River Murray Commission comprises representatives of the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia and makes recommendations to the respective governments on matters relating to the river. I compliment it on the work it does. I know officers of the Commission. I know Mr Johnson, the chief engineer, very well. The officers of the Commission do their best under the present system to achieve the results they would like to achieve. However, I think they are still inhibited because any one of the States can veto any recommendations that they make. As I understand it, the same will apply with respect to their new found power of being able to make recommendations with respect to water quality. The Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment, of which I was Chairman, supported the idea. The Committee, on page 32 of a report I presented in June 1979, stated:

The plethora of authorities involved is a source of great frustration to the persons with whom the Committee spoke along the river. Without exception, everyone urged the need for a single co-ordinating authority.

One of the witnesses, Professor Sandford D. Clark, the Harrison Moore Professor of Law at the University of Melbourne, stated in a submission to the River Murray working party that the River Murray Waters Agreement is not consistent with modern water management principles, and fails to acknowledge the hydrological interdependence of all parts of the Murray-Darling-Murrumbidgee system. He urged that more needs to be done with respect to co-ordinating activities in this area. When one thinks about it, when one realises that it is estimated that 22 per cent of the water that flows into the River Murray system come from Queensland, one can appreciate the seriousness and the importance of having a single co-ordinating authority to deal with the whole water resources of Australia.
In another report which I presented in September 1980, the Committee said that there was an urgent need to come to grips with the problem. The report stated:
The Committee shares the views of the Consultants-
the Maunsell consultants-
regarding the need for the co-ordinated management of immediate salinity and drainage problems, but the Committee also regards a co-ordinated approach as vital to such matters as:
water quality
irrigation procedures
flood mitigation
flood plain management
environmental and conservation matters
re-afforestation
recreation

Senator Sir John Carrick mentioned reafforestation. The red gum plantations have died in many areas but are being replanted in very few other areas. I think that ought to be a major project. A salt resistant red gum clone has been developed through the co-operation of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and, I think, Melbourne University. When fully grown, these trees can transpire through their leaves 200 to 250 gallons of water a day. Honourable senators can imagine what millions of trees planted along the river banks to replace those that have been degraded and destroyed could do to lower the water table considerably in the long term. In the view of my Committee that was a necessity.

I believe that the Commission's effectiveness is further reduced by the Commonwealth's policy of providing finance directly to the States for works associated with River Murray problems. It appears that an even greater deal of co-operation and co-ordination in River Murray matters would have resulted if finance for all those works was channelled through the River Murray Commission. I think the River Murray Commission's role ought to be expanded and developed, perhaps along the lines of the Delaware River commission in the United States of America. I visited that commission last year and learned that it has extraordinary powers with respect to how much water is used, environmental controls and industrial pollution. I found those powers quite incredible. That commission is in a similar situation to that of the River Murray Commission. It deals with four States in the United States of America. Perhaps some of its significant powers have been weakened in recent years but that is no excuse that we should not be looking towards the development of a River Murray Commission along those lines.

I go further and suggest that we ought to upgrade the Commission's role in Australia. We should reconstitute the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Authority as an engineering and practical arm of the River Murray Commission. The Commission ought to be able to make recommendations with respect to water quality and quantity and the Snowy Mountains Authority ought to be the engineering instrument whereby these engineering feasibilities are carried out. Senator Sir John Carrick said the Fraser Government had approved a feasibility study to be conducted on a water storage on the upper Murray. That is essential. Senator Jones said the Bradfield scheme was pie in the sky. He may be right but I think schemes of that character have got to be looked at. We have to divert the waters that are currently running to waste into the oceans surrounding Australia. We have to look at the proposition put forward some time ago by Mr Jack Beale of New South Wales. He suggested that a good bicentennial scheme would be a $4 billion project entitled 'Green Australia'. He suggested that six New South Wales rivers, the Clarence, Macleay, Manning, Shoalhaven, Tuross and Snowy be diverted to join up with the upper reaches of the existing westward flowing rivers. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard part of a paper dealing with water diversion schemes that was prepared by the Parliamentary Library research service. I would also like to incorporate the results of investigations of Bradfield's water irrigation plan by Mr W. H. R. Nimmo in the publication Commonwealth Engineer, dated 1947. I seek leave for those two documents to be incorporated.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
Water Diversion Schemes

Since the beginning of this century, Australians have spoken glibly of '' watering the dead heart'' of Australia and ''making the desert bloom''. Such schemes involve diverting Queensland coastal rivers through the Great Divide into rivers which feed Cooper's Creek and ultimately Lake Eyre. Various schemes have been proposed since the first such plan by E. A. Leonard in 1887,5 but the proposals of Dr J. J. C. Bradfield5-9 have captured most attention. Despite the engineering and climatological impracticabilities,2, 10-13 the Bradfield scheme still has supporters.14, 15 Nimmo's assessment11 of the Bradfield plan concluded that: parts of the scheme were impossible; those parts which were feasible would be enormously expensive and could deliver only a fraction of the water originally proposed; and the coastal waters (Tully, Herbert and Burdekin Rivers) could be more effectively and economically used for irrigation and hydro- electric power generation along the coast.

The full Bradfield plan involved construction of large reservoirs in the interior of the continent to catch occasional floods on the inland rivers, in addition to the diversion of coastal rivers. It was suggested that such reservoirs would allow irrigation of large areas of suitable land, and that evaporation from reservoirs and irrigated land would affect a climatic change by increasing rainfall in the arid interior. The hoped for climatic improvement is a key part of the popular appeal of the scheme. The reality is that such a climatic change would not occur. Air humidity is only one factor involved in rainfall, and there is clear evidence in many parts of the world where desert areas border large natural sheets of water (for example, the Red Sea) that an abundant supply of atmospheric moisture is not in itself sufficient to cause rainfall. Another related factor overlooked by Bradfield is the volume of water which would be evaporated from the proposed arid region storages.13 The annual replenishment would require a volume of water equal to about 40 per cent of the total runoff of the whole of Australia. Further, Bradfield's proposal for inland irrigation using coastal water involved using 600mm (2 feet) of water per year,7 an amount which seems totally inadequate for an area with annual evaporation losses of 2500mm.

The only large scale water diversion scheme constructed in Australia is the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Scheme, which is a dual-purpose hydro-electric and irrigation complex which impounds south-flowing waters of the Snowy River and diverts them inland to the Murray and Murrumbidgee Rivers through two tunnel systems. This water, together with the headwaters of the inland rivers, is harnessed and regulated for hydro-electric generation and irrigation purposes. On average, about 1130GL of water per year is diverted from the Snowy River to the inland rivers. The scheme was constructed between 1950 and 1974 at a cost of $1000 million (including interest charges), and repayments of Commonwealth loans and operating costs are funded by sales of electricity to NSW, Victoria, and the ACT. No charge is made for irrigation water diverted inland. If all the annual costs of the scheme (1981-82, $86 million) were recovered from charges on irrigation water (and the electricity free), the water would cost $76/ML. This cost may be compared with irrigation water costs of $0.50, $2.60, $4.50, and $37 in NSW, Victoria, Queensland and Western Australia, respectively.13

The NSW Water Resources Commission (and its predecessor) has in the past considered preliminary proposals for diversion of water from coastal to inland rivers. In 1981, the Commission engaged consultants to carry out a preliminary review and update of previously identified inland diversion schemes.17 Of the 22 coastal river basins, 9 were suitable for inland diversions, though 4 of these ( Hunter, Hawkesbury, Shoalhaven and Bega) did not have water available for diversion due to present and future needs in the coastal regions. The most favourable scheme involves diversion of over 750 GL from the Clarence Basin to the Border Rivers system (and thence to the Darling River), but at an annual cost of $140/ML. Another proposal involves diversion of water from the Barnard River (in the Manning River Basin) to the Hunter River Basin for power station cooling water.18 No details of this scheme are available. However, it seems likely that future water demands in the Hunter Basin will exceed available resources, especially if coal liquefaction plants are constructed, and the above diversion may ultimately be an economic proposition.
Results of Investigation of Bradfield's Water-Irrigation Plan
Study of Scheme for Irrigation in Western Queensland . . . . Several Steps in Plan not Practicable . . . Huge Expenditure
Abstract of Report by
W. H. R. Nimmo, M.E., M.I.E.Aust.
Chief Engineer, Stanley River Works Board, Queensland

THE BRADFIELD SCHEME, which was put forward in 1938, proposed to divert the waters of the Tully and Herbert rivers, combine them with the waters of the Upper Burdekin, and pass the whole across the Great Dividing Range with the object of utilising them in a vast irrigation project in Western Queensland.
The scheme (see map) provided for:-
(1) Construction of a dam on the Tully river and the diversion of this water through a short open cut to the headwaters of Blunder creek, a tributary of the Herbert.
(2) Construction of a dam on the Herbert river and the diversion of the combined Tully and Herbert waters, by means of a tunnel 13 miles long, to the Upper Burdekin river.

(3) Construction of a gigantic dam on the Burdekin river at Hell's Gates with the object of backing the combined waters (of the three rivers) up the Clarke river to a point where it could be taken off in a tunnel through the Great Divide and discharged into the Upper Flinders river. (It should be noted that although this reservoir would actually contain an enormous quantity of water it would not be available for use inasmuch as only the topmost few feet would be drawn off through the tunnel.)
(4) Water received into the Flinders would be stored in a number of smaller reservoirs and be taken thence through an open cut to Skeleton creek, and thence to the Thompson river.
(5) From the Thompson the waters would be used in irrigation and diverted to other western streams.

Since this scheme was put forward, important information bearing on the proposals has become available in the form of military contour maps, produced from aerial surveys, further ground surveys, and extended records of rainfall and stream flow. It is now known that some portions of the scheme, as proposed in the Bradfield report, are physically impossible, but further surveys will be necessary to determine the physical possibility or otherwise of other portions of the scheme.

Utilising the additional information now available, a re-examination of the scheme has been made and is described in some detail herein. In the following summary the principal findings of the investigation are, for purposes of ready comparison, set out opposite the relevant proposals of Dr Bradfield.
Comparison of the Bradfield Proposals with the Results of Investigation by Queensland Engineers
Dr Bradfield's Proposals
Results of Investigation
1. A dam 120 ft high to be constructed on the Tully river above Tully Falls.
Estimated average annual flow of Tully river at 562 cusec of which 500 would be diverted.
Building a large dam on the Tully river above Tully Falls will make a continuous flow of some 300 cusec available for diversion to Blunder creek, a tributary of the Herbert.
2. Water to be conveyed from the Tully to Blunder creek by open cut half a mile long.
It is probable, though not certain, that water can be diverted from the Tully to Blunder creek by a tunnel about eight miles long. It cannot be conveyed by open channel.

3. A dam 100 ft high and 1,000 ft long to be constructed on the Herbert river about a quarter of a mile above the Herbert Falls. Estimated average annual flow from Herbert catchment 2,677 cusec of which 2,300 cusec would be diverted in addition to the flow from the Tully.

There is no suitable site for a storage reservoir on the Herbert river near Herbert Falls. A very large reservoir can be created by a dam on the Herbert at a point two miles above Cameron creek. The continuous flow made available by this reservoir may be 700 cusec, exclusive of the water from the Tully.
4. A tunnel about 13 miles long to convey combined Tully and Herbert waters to the Burdekin river at Wairuna.
It is probable, though not certain, that water can be diverted from above the Herbert Falls to Wairuna on the Burdekin river.

5. A dam 400 ft high and 2,000 ft long to be constructed on the Burdekin river, at Hell's Gates, to back water up the Clarke river a distance of about 60 (?) miles, whence it would be diverted by tunnel 70 miles long, to the Flinders river.

A dam at Hell's Gates on the Burdekin cannot be built to the height of 400 ft provided for in the Bradfield scheme, the practicable limit of height being 300 ft. Even if the dam could be built to a height of 400 ft, the surface of the reservoir would be too low to permit of diverting the water to the Flinders river.
6. Estimated average annual flow from Burdekin catchment 3,678 cusec of which 3 ,200 cusec would be diverted in addition to the flow from the Tully and the Herbert.

Even if it were possible to divert water from Hell's Gates to the Flinders, the small storage capacity in the upper few feet of the reservoir and the great evaporation from the huge reservoir surface would limit the continuous flow available from the Burdekin catchment to a few hundred cubic feet per second, exclusive of water from the Tully and Herbert.
7. Possible modification not considered in Bradfield's scheme.

It may be physically possible-though this is not certain-to divert the water of a smaller part of the catchment of the Burdekin from a dam near Lake Lucy to a reservoir formed by a moderately high dam at ''The Rockies'' on the Flinders. The conduit, which would be about 200 miles long, about half of it being in tunnel, would be on a very small gradient and would have to be lined with concrete throughout.
8. A number of dams on the upper Flinders would create a series of reservoirs, or ''coolamons'', which would store the waters from the Tully, Herbert, Burdekin and Flinders rivers.
The gorge of the upper Flinders is steep and narrow and does not lend itself to the creation of reservoirs or ''collamons'' of large capacity.

9. Dr Bradfield claimed that after releasing sufficient water to satisfy riparian needs on the Tully, Herbert and Burdekin below the proposed dams, a continuous flow of 6,000 cusec could be delivered into the Flinders and that, allowing for losses in distribution, 4,000 cusec could be used in actually watering land under irrigation.
Quantity of water that can be diverted into the Flinders by the modified scheme will not exceed 1,250 cusec of which not more than 700 cusec can be actually used in watering land.
10. Estimated cost of the scheme is not stated in the report under review but has been given elsewhere as #40,000,000.

The cost of the modified scheme to the point of delivery of water into the Flinders, is estimated to be about #100,000,000. For a 50-year loan period the annual charges would be about #6,000,000. If 500,000 ac.ft per annum, equivalent to a continuous flow of 700 cusec, could be actually applied to irrigated land, the cost of water delivered at ''The Rockies'' would be #12 per acre foot to which must be added the annual charge on a costly distributing system. (It may be noted that in Victoria and N.S.W. irrigation water for fodder production is delivered for 6/- to 10/- per acre foot.)

11. The Bradfield scheme envisages the diversion of the whole of the available waters of the Tully and Herbert and the northern part of the Burdekin watershed. This would prevent generation of hydro-electricity and irrigation of the coastal lands.
There are important uses for much of the water east of the Divide.
About half the available flow of the Tully will be required for the generation of electric power within 15 years. All the flow that can be regulated will ultimately be used for power.
Waters of the Burdekin can be impounded in a large reservoir near the Burdekin Falls and be utilised for the irrigation of a large tract of country.

12. An alternative scheme proposed by Bradfield is to convey water from Hell's Gates reservoir in two 26 ft diameter pipes 175 miles long, southward into Lake Webb, and thence westward into Torrens creek (at Aberfoyle) down which it would flow to the Thomson river.

This scheme appears to be physically possible. Since the full height of the Hell's Gates dam would be required to send water through the pipes, there would be no useful storage and the continuous flow in the pipes would be little more than 1,000 cusec. By lowering the draw off level at Hell's Gates dam by 200 ft and passing under the Divide in a long tunnel, it would be possible to utilise 200 ft depth of storage. If the reservoir site be a distinctly favourable one, the continuous flow to Torrens creek might thus be increased to about 1,800 cusec. The cost would be very great.
The acompanying map shows the places referred to in this memorandum and illustrates the schemes as proposed by Bradfield and the possible modification referred to above.

No reference is made in Dr Bradfield's report to the costs involved in diverting waters from western rivers through a network of distribution channels to irrigated fields. Nor is any reference made to the costs of accurate grading of such fields. These matters have consequently received no attention in the examination of the report, but it must be borne in mind that these additional costs would run into many millions of pounds.
The Feasibility of Building the Proposed Dams and Conduits and the Quantity of Water Which Can be Obtained
In this section some of the proposed major works are dealt with in more detail.
The Tully Dam

A dam can be built a short distance upstream of Tully Falls to a height of 120 ft. The best site for a dam and the storage capacity which it will create can be determined with more certainty when surveys, now being carried out by the Cairns Regional Electricity Board in connection with the proposed Tully Falls hydro- electric power scheme, have been completed. The examination by the investigating committee, based upon military contour maps, indicates that a dam 120 ft high may impound 200,000 ac.ft of water and produce a steady regulated flow throughout the year of 300 cusec.

If the conduit leading from this reservoir be very large with a capacity of about 1,000 cusec, then the average rate of diversion may perhaps be increased to 350 cusec, but the flow would vary from less than 20 cusec to 1,000 cusec.
Diversion Conduit to Blunder Creek

The watershed between the Tully and Blunder creek rises to 260 ft above the Tully at the proposed dam site where the elevation is about R.L. 2,210. It is therefore impossible to divert water to Blunder creek in an open cut as proposed by Dr Bradfield.

A tunnel to carry the 300 cusec regulated flow to be made available by the Tully dam would have to be lined with concrete and extend to a point where the bed of Blunder creek is not higher than R.L. 2,200.

Accurate levels have not been taken but military contour maps indicate that the tunnel will have a length of eight miles. The construction of a very large tunnel having a capacity of about 1,000 cusec might increase the average quantity of water diverted by about 50 cusec but the quantity in excess of the 300 cusec of steady flow would vary rapidly from 1,000 cusec during the passage of a flood down to zero and this intermittent flow would have to be regulated by the provision of additional storage capacity on the Herbert or elsewhere in the system. Such additional storage would increase the loss by evaporation so the net increase in the quantity of water available for diversion to West Queensland would be very small and not commensurate with the great increase in cost of the large works.
The Herbert River Dam
