The Bradfield report provides for construction of a dam 100 ft high immediately upstream of the Herbert Falls. As no information is given regarding the volume of water to be impounded, earlier investigations were based on the assumption that the reservoir would be of average capacity for a dam 100 ft high and would hold 50,000 ac.ft. This volume is far too small to regulate adequately the run- off of the Herbert catchment, so a very large tunnel would be necessary to deliver an appreciable proportion of the Herbert run-off to the Burdekin.

The proposed dam site was later inspected by engineers of the Main Roads Commission who reported that there is no practicable storage site between Cashmere and the Herbert Falls, this being subsequently confirmed by military contour maps. Military maps, however, have revealed the possibility of creating a very large reservoir by building a dam on the Herbert river, at a point about two miles upstream from the confluence with Cameron creek. This reservoir would control a catchment area of only 1,720 sq.mile as compared with 2,038 sq.mile at Herbert Falls, and water released from it would run down the Herbert to a diversion weir above the Herbert Falls.

When the investigation now being carried out by the Herbert River Investigation Committee has been completed, there will be available a more accurate estimate of the quantity of water, which can be diverted continuously to the Burdekin but it is unlikely that it will exceed 700 cusec which, added to the 300 cusec from the Tully, would make a total of 1,000 cusec.
Herbert Burdekin Tunnel

The difference of level of 46 ft between the Herbert at the Falls and the Burdekin at Wairuna, given in the Bradfield report, apparently depends upon some isolated barometric observations which are liable to error and conequently require confirmation by survey before it can be definitely determined that the proposed diversion is possible. The tunnel will be 13 miles long.
The Hell's Gates Dam

The elevation of R.L. 1,000 given for the Burdekin river at Hell's Gates is approximately confirmed by a reconnaissance survey by the Main Roads Commission. Bradfield's scheme includes raising the water level of the Budekin to R.L. 1,400 by a dam 400 ft high, thereby backing water up the Clarke river as far as its confluence with the Broken river.

Since the principal function of the dam is to raise the water level to permit of conveying water to West Queensland only a few feet of depth at the upper level of the reservoir could be used as a regulating storage and consequently the continuous flow that could be drawn from the reservoir would be only a small proportion of the average run-off of 1,320 cusec.

The extensive surface of the reservoir, which is to be maintained continually close to its full level, will involve a very large evaporation loss and during severe droughts this loss may exceed the contribution from the catchment of the Burdekin. Since it is shown later that the proposed diversion from the reservoir is not possible and the storage capacity is unknown, a detailed analysis to determine the continuous yield is not warranted but it is unlikely that it could exceed a few hundred cubic feet per second.
The continuous combined flow from the Tully, Herbert and Burdekin rivers at Hell's Gates would therefore not greatly exceed 1,000 cubic feet per second.
The Tunnel Under the Main Divide

This tunnel from the confluence of the Clarke and Broken rivers to the Flinders river above ''The Rockies'' will be 70 miles long. The elevation of the Divide, under which the tunnel would pass, approaches 3,000 ft.

Barometric levelling, during a reconnaissance of the upper Flinders river by the Queensland Bureau of Investigation of Land and Water Resources, shows that the water level at ''The Rockies'' is about R.L. 1,400. The reconnaissance survey by the Main Roads Commission shows that the maximum height to which a dam can be built at Hell's Gate is only about 300 ft, raising the water level to R.L . 1,300.
It is therefore impossible to divert water to the Flinders, as proposed, from a reservoir at Hell's Gate.
Bradfield's Alternative Scheme

An alternative scheme, proposed by Dr. Bradfield, is described in a statement by Mr. H. P. Moss in the Eighth Report of the Rural Reconstruction Commission and is indicated on the accompanying map (page 447).

It is proposed to convey water from a dam at Hell's Gates in two 26 ft dia. pipelines south to Lake Webb. From Lake Webb the water is to be conveyed in a westerly direction to Torrens creek down which it will flow to the Thompson river. The distance in a straight line from Hell's Gates to Lake Webb is about 165 miles but a pipe could not be constructed on that line without much tunnelling.

Levels on roads and railways indicate that by adopting a more easterly location , it may be possible to convey water from Hell's Gates to Lake Webb almost entirely in pipes in a distance of about 175 miles.

Bradfield's proposal to deliver 6,000 cusec through two 26 ft dia. pipes represents a velocity of 5-2/3 feet per second and for this a total head of 200 ft would be required. The elevation of Lake Webb is shown on the map by Mr. Moss as R. L. 1,100 but this appears to have been interpolated from other information and needs confirmation. The draw-off level at Hell's Gates reservoir must therefore be R. L. 1,300 which, as stated previously, is the maximum level to which a dam can be built. Consequently there would be practically no storage and the continuous output from the reservoir would not be much greater than the 1, 000 cubic feet per second to be diverted from the Tully and Herbert rivers.

Levels taken in connection with the survey of the artesian basin show that Torrens creek falls rapidly and is below R.L. 900 near Aberfoyle. Levels on roads and railways indicate that it may be possible to draw off water from the proposed Hell's Gates reservoir and convey it in a conduit passing under the Great Northern Railway in a long tunnel in the vicinity of Balfe creek, then crossing the Campaspe and the Cape rivers and their tributaries and finally tunnelling under the Divide to Torrens creek near Aberfoyle.

Such a conduit would probably have a total length of about 200 miles, much of which would be in long tunnels and the remainder partly in open channels and partly in pipe. This would make it possible to utilise the storage in Hell's Gates reservoir in the 200 ft of depth between R.L. 1,300 and R. L. 1,100. What this storage capacity would be is not known, but, taking an optimistic view, and assuming that the reservoir site is a favourable one, it might be about 1,000, 000 ac.ft. Such a reservoir might permit the continuous diversion of 800 cubic feet per second out of the total estimated average run-off at Hell's Gates of 1, 320 cusec.

The total quantity of water delivered to Torrens creek by this scheme would not exceed 1,800 cusec. Unless the Hell's Gates reservoir site proves to be a good one, this scheme will be no better than the modified scheme described earlier. In any case the quantity of water delivered will be only a fraction of the 6,000 cusec claimed by Bradfield and the cost will be enormous.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The Bradfield scheme probably is a bit ambitious. Engineers would probably say that a lot of evaporation would occur as a result of the original scheme which Bradfield contemplated.
—It is cargo cultism, and you know it.

—The Minister comes in here and talks in a very nasty way. I have a lot of regard for his ability. If he could restrain himself from making inane comments like that he might get a little bit of encouragement from this side of the chamber so that he would not have to resort to personal attacks. I regard Senator Walsh as one Minister of the Government who, despite his unpleasant behaviour in this place, has something going for him. He knows in his heart of hearts-I think he has one-that we should be developing uranium and water resources. I believe that Senator Walsh is an able and competent fellow. I think he will vote for such development. I endorse it. I know he supports Mr Hawke. I certainly do.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister to listen to what I say and recognise that I am, in effect, supporting the philosophy of the Australian Labor Party with respect to national water resource development. I was accused at one time of not supporting Mr Ralph Jacobi and his proposed institute of freshwater studies. I think it is a magnificent idea. I have spoken on the same platform as Mr Jacobi on this resource development. I have demonstrated a non-partisan approach to it. My approach to national water resources is possibly a little centralistic because I believe that is the way Australia must go. I am not suggesting that we disregard the States, not at all. But the financial capacity which the Commonwealth has at its disposal can be used to influence the States on these matters having regard to the importance to State development of the water resource and the fact that the artesian waters and our rivers know no State boundaries. I have adopted that attitude and I will continue to adopt it.

I suggest to Senator Walsh that, rather than interject on me-I am trying desperately to be helpful to him-he pick up some of the suggestions I have made. The Fraser Government at last recognised that the diversion of some of these rivers ought to be looked at. In the last election campaign, I think a few years too late, we were to authorise the expenditure of about $500,000 to examine the economic and engineering feasibility of turning back some of those eastern rivers. I think it is feasible. Do not talk to me about the cost. Even if it runs into $4 billion or $5 billion it is going to be well worth it, because if we do not spend that sort of money right now, by the year 2050 our water resources will be fully committed. Now is the time to encourage communities to introduce water harvesting projects throughout Australia so that in the winter time, when the rains fall, those waters can be diverted into holding dams to be used for watering parks and gardens and places such as those. We ought to be looking at all sorts of things, including the future possibility of requiring nuclear power stations in Australia for desalination purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Icebergs.

—Okay, icebergs. That suggestion is all right. It is not silly either, because when we are desperately looking for water the question of towing icebergs from the Antarctic is not an unrealistic possibility. The Minister will say that there are problems associated with it. Sure, we will lose about 40 per cent of the iceberg in the towing process. What do we do with it when we get it here? It becomes a navigational hazard. The point is that there is a technique available by which it can be melted quickly and piped to holding tanks ashore. I hope Senator Elstob was serious because it is not beyond the realms of possibility that we will have to look to that sort of technology as well. Professor Schwerdtfeger of Flinders University believes that it is a possibility . In fact he went to the Middle East not long ago with a lot of other scientists to attend a symposium in, I think, Saudi Arabia with the object of studying very seriously the feasibility of that technique.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I also support the River Murray Waters Bill 1983. As has already been stated, water is Australia's most valuable asset; there is no doubt about that. Australia is the driest continent on earth, and South Australia is the driest State in the driest continent on earth. Senator Sir John Carrick said that 50 per cent of South Australia's water supply was dependent on water from the Murray. I dispute that. The Murray River is South Australia's lifeline and it provides 80 per cent of South Australia's surface water which is delivered to over one million people, which is 90 per cent of the State's population. It is also distributed over two-thirds of the State's settled area. Up to 80 per cent of Adelaide's water supply and up to 90 per cent of the water supply for the Iron Triangle is derived from the Murray. By contrast, the Murray provides water for only 350,000 people in both New South Wales and Victoria. It provides the bulk of South Australia's water supply for irrigation, stock and domestic and industrial purposes and it helps to provide an environment for conservation and recreation. It is unequalled in South Australia. Therefore the Murray is of vital concern to the State, and South Australians are not only unhappy about the poor quality of water that is delivered by it but also about the quantity of water. The quality and quantity of water are of great concern to them.

SPEECH.PARA: Much has been said about the Murray River, but it is Australia's greatest river . It flows through a great area of Australia, and it provides so much. If we look at the geography of the river we see that the catchment area of the Murray- Darling system is 1.06 million kilometres-that is, one-seventh of the Australian continent. The Darling section covers 650,000 kilometres. The length of the Murray is 2,530 kilometres, of which 637 kilometres is in South Australia. In the early days naturally all the European settlement in the inland of this country was along the edge of the Murray, and that was because of the inefficient pumps that were used in those days. If there had been efficient pumps in those early times it would have been far more preferable not to have settled along the edge of the Murray. All settlement or irrigation systems would have been far better out of the Murray Valley itself. Over 80 per cent of the land in this country has a salt content. When we replace deep rooted vegetation with shallow-rooted vegetation a capillary action occurs which brings the salt to the surface of the land. That is why we have a great salinity problem in this country. It is simply taking out what nature has provided over many years.

TALK.START.PARA: —It contributes to turbidity, too.

—I will come to turbidity at a later stage. It is also important. Salinity is a very serious problem and it should be seriously considered. It is important to replace the red river gums and other deep-rooted vegetation along the Murray. This will not be easy because much of the land is now saline and will have to be drained at great expense to get anything to grow. Once that land has been destroyed many millions of dollars will have to be spent on deep drainage to get rid of the salt from that affected land.

SPEECH.PARA: Much has been said about the irrigation systems, and I agree with a lot of it. Flood irrigation was the worst thing that ever happened, especially along the Murray River. Ten times the quantity of water is put on the headlands to get water down to the lowlands. Consequently there is a build-up of the water table. That also has an effect on salinity in this country. It is the worst irrigation system. Drip irrigation in theory is a great idea, but in practice it is very costly to work. The impure water that we get, especially in South Australia, has a tendency to clog up the microfine drip system. Growers are very worried about using it. If the drip system fails, because of the evaporation that occurs in a very hot climate, such as in South Australia, the fruit trees or vines or whatever is being irrigated will be lost in a very short time. They cannot survive, especially as the drip system supplies a very minute quantity of water. To operate that system successfully the water has to be purified and cleansed. The majority of growers prefer low level sprinkler irrigation systems. The reason of course is that in times of high salinity the salt does not get on the leaves and destroy the plants which are being irrigated. That is probably the best system. Unless we can come up with a cheap method of cleansing the water to make a drip system operate efficiently I do not think it will be possible to convince growers to turn to that system.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about small filtration systems?

—Filtration is a very costly system for agricultural purposes. I think the cost of cleansing the water for the purpose of producing agricultural products woud be too high for the growers. I think one would have to be very careful in working out the economies of such an operation.

SPEECH.PARA: Water is the life-blood of this nation. If the Murray River became badly affected by salt, pollution or a lack of water, it would be very doubtful whether South Australia could carry a population of more than half a million people. That would be totally disastrous. It has been assessed by experts that by 2000 probably 80 to 90 per cent of the world's population will suffer from a shortage of water. That proportion will increase. Much of the world's surface is being carelessly polluted. This Bill goes some way towards improving that situation but it must be understood that it is not the final answer. I agree with Senator Jessop that there should be more input by the Federal Government. The Federal Government should use its financial powers in this area. I believe that the States and everyone else have rights, but when it comes to the point, if we are destroying our water I believe that this Government has a responsibility that it cannot walk away from. The Federal Government must have the power to intervene to stop States from irrigating in areas where they should not be irrigating. In Victoria, as we know, there are areas where irrigation is pushing large amounts of salt back into the river. That should be stopped. I believe that the exercise of power by a Federal Government authority is the only possible way to do that. The history of the States and how they have managed their affairs over the years shows that management has not always been in the best interests of the nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —They build sewerage schemes on the flood plains.

—That is absolutely correct. There is no overall plan. As with transportation in this country, it has been messed up. Water is a very vital aspect of this nation. In the near future, water will limit the population of this country, not only in South Australia but in all States. Not only will we have to protect our valuable water supply and keep it clean and palatable but we will also have to look to other methods of supplying water. It is probably not unrealistic at the moment to bring icebergs here. I interjected when Senator Jessop was speaking and said that many people consider that that is unrealistic. Eventually we will have to find the technology to do things such as this or find a cheap way of desalinating water. I agree that we should be spending more on research in this area. It will not be possible to develop this country, and I believe that we should be doing this, unless we improve and increase our water supplies.
—Will you use uranium to desalinate sea water? It might be the cheapest method.

—I believe that many methods can be used. I am not satisfied at the moment that that is a possibility. I think we should be putting more funds into research and scientific know-how to overcome our pollution of rivers, the air and everything else. That may entail uranium. I want to see a safe world for my children and my grandchildren and their children. The decisions we make here today will affect future generations. I think we should face that responsibility . In a place like the Senate I think there should be an interchange of views and co-operation between political parties. I have always believed that resources such as water should be utilised in the best interests of the nation as a whole, not in the best interests of a State or an individual. We have to have a look at the overall plan. That is something that many politicians are failing to do in this country-to look at a national project to see whether it is workable and feasible. I am pleased to say that that sort of sense is creeping into the atmosphere of politics, especially in this Senate. That shows some promise for the future but we have a long way to go. We are here to improve this country.

SPEECH.PARA: South Australia is allocated 1.85 million megalitres of water a year from the Murray. We often get that allocation, in the dry period, and we can only plan on the dry years. Last year we were running very short. If we had another drought year, South Australia would be in desperate trouble. That situation has to be taken into account. I have here a list setting out the details of the annual flow, evaporation rates, irrigation areas and salinity loads in all States on the Murray.
