TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is important that people other than politicians should have this information. I take it that some people read Hansard, boring as it may be, and it is important that people have an overall perspective of what is going on.
—What do you think about the idea of additional water for South Australia to be flushed through the system to keep the Murray mouth open?

—That has got to happen. It is happening now. At present the water has a very low salt content. As we all know, all the people along the Murray are very happy this year. But they are also aware that the Murray actually floats on a layer of salt which in some places is less than a metre and in other place two metres below the fresh water. That is how delicate the balance is. It is frightening. Most South Australians really understand the situation. When we get a good flow of water it is essential, as Senator Jessop said, to flush the Murray out. A good flow of water keeps the salt from flowing back into the river. Millions of tonnes of salt are waiting to be flushed back into the sea. But man brought about this salt problem.

SPEECH.PARA: I have spoken to experts about this matter. They say that it will take thousands of years to flush out the salt. It cannot be done in a short period. It is an impossible project but we can live with what we have if only sensible exploitation takes place along the Murray, if we permit people to irrigate only in places that do not have a high salt content. A great deal of money has to be spent in other places to re-establish deep-rooted vegetation along the Murray. That is important. Not only are trees nice to look at but, if we are to keep the salt out of the Murray, deep-rooted trees and other plants have to be re- established.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Fraser Government was going to spend $100m on that. It is a good idea.

—Promises were made that money would be spent on many things. I ask honourable senators to look at the deficit with which we were faced when coming into government. To be realistic, I do not think the Fraser Government could have gone ahead with many of these projects. Governments of all political persuasions should be planning on a long term basis. Problems of this magnitude, whether they concern water or anything else, cannot be solved in one year, five years or 10 years. The expenditure of large guaranteed sums of money should be planned on a continuing basis. Without such planning, we cannot overcome the very severe problems that we all recognise exist. This cannot be done overnight. I think the idea of the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi) to establish an institute of freshwater studies was a great one. I still believe that it is a good idea. Many people in my Party understand that. One does not only have to look at the River Murray situation to realise that. We are polluting--
—It should be incorporated as a national authority.

—It has to be a national authority. It is wrong to pollute water in any part of the world and it is certainly wrong to pollute water in any part of our country. The underground water in the south-east of South Australia is starting to become polluted. That has always been a very good supply of fresh water, particularly around the Mount Gambier area. Ineffective programs and the use of certain fertilisers on the land are contributing to the pollution of that water. We have to be careful about it. Water is a vital commodity. We cannot waste these assets; we do not have enough of them.
—Senator, will your State Government agree to a transfer of power as did the last Liberal Government in your State?

—I believe that all State governments of every political persuasion are very parochial. The responsibility rests with the politicians in the Federal Parliament. I believe that we have a duty to convince not only governments but also the people that we should have a transfer of power to overcome many of these problems. It would be quite easy to show the people of all the States that water management by the States has been very inefficient. I think that is what it comes down to. I think we have to be tough in our use of power and in our determination. If any Federal government allocates money, the States have to toe the line, whether it be South Australia, New South Wales or any other State. I note that New South Wales intends to increase substantially its use of land for irrigation. I think it already has in production 255,448 hectares and it proposes to use another 189,559 hectares. That area is along the Murray, the Murrumbidgee and the Darling rivers. I think with that sort of attitude it may be possible to make progress but I do not know. Experts need to be able to inform us whether irrigation areas are in the right position. I believe it is vital for the States to have that information. Nobody owns a river .
—You really need a national authority, don't you?

—Yes, we need a strong authority. I agree that all those things are necessary if we are to proceed to reach some arrangement with the States. Nobody owns a river. The River Murray is not owned by New South Wales, Victoria or South Australia for that matter. It belongs to the people of this country. If the River Murray dried up and half the population of South Australia dispersed into New South Wales or Victoria the situation would be chaotic. That is the reality of the situation. Without water many people would not be able to live in South Australia. If the Murray was suddenly cut off from South Australia because it became so badly polluted half the population would have to leave that State. The people would have to go somewhere else. What would happen to the other State governments then? They would suddenly be faced with a huge influx of people. Would the States say: 'You cannot come here'? Of course they could not. The States would have to face those problems. The Federal Government has a real responsibility in this field.
—We need a strong national authority.
—I agree with all of that to some extent. This Bill, as I said, goes some way towards improving--
—We are all centralists now, are we?
—It surprises me that honourable senators opposite are now all centralists.
—The last State Liberal Government in South Australia supported it.

—It looks as though only the South Australian honourable senators opposite believe in centralism. But they do understand the problem. I think they understand how dangerous the situation could be. I think that is probably why they would now support a centralist policy on water. All South Australians understand the problem better than people in other States. As water becomes more scarce in the other States the people in those States will have the same outlook as South Australia. In the next 20 years or so, as I said, water will become scarce in the majority of countries. It will become more scarce in places like New South Wales, Victoria and even Queensland to some extent. People will be made aware of the problem if the rivers and dams start drying up. We cannot allow that unfortunate situation to happen. I believe that with good planning we can prevent such an occurence.

SPEECH.PARA: It will be interesting to see how this River Murray Waters Agreement works. If it does not work I think this Government has a duty to come back to this Parliament and introduce better legislation. I think we may even have to hold a referendum on this issue. If the Commonwealth does not have the necessary power it needs then I think it is vital to hold a referendum. I do not believe this matter can be left to the States any longer. If we can reach agreement that is well and good, but if we cannot reach agreement, if this agreement does not work or if the River Murray or any other river starts to deteriorate we have to be very vigilant and, as I said, perhaps even take it to a referendum. I would hope that all political parties would support such a move. I think that may come about one day. Nevertheless, this agreement is to be implemented. As I said, I hope that it works. I have some doubts about it but nevertheless we will all watch it closely.

I think I have covered the main points I wanted to raise. I think a lot more research has to be carried out. Unless we know the facts we cannot legislate. I think we have to seek professional help in this field. We have to spend a lot more money on scientific research. Politicians have to be better informed. When we have all available knowledge then I think we can prepare decent legislation to cover that situation. I think all honourable senators support what has been said in this chamber in one way or another. Certainly honourable senators on this side of the chamber support the Bill and hope that it works. I say to the Government that we should be vigilant. If the agreement does not work the Government should not dilly-dally too long because every month and every year things will get desperately worse. I think we have to take drastic actions in respect of the build up of salt that is present. I urge all politicians, especially those in this place, to think about that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to contribute to the debate on the River Murray Waters Bill. I appreciate that most of the points that can be made have already been made this morning, and I do not want simply to be repetitious. Therefore, I trust that I can be a little briefer than previous speakers. The first point I wish to make is that this Bill and the agreement upon which it is based must be seen as a credit to the former Government, particularly to the former Minister, Senator Sir John Carrick, who was the first speaker in the debate this morning, although the Bill has been introduced by the present Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the previous Government's contribution contrasts dramatically with the contribution of this Government to date. That contribution could be summarised by, first, the decision to scrap the four-year extension to the national water resources program, which was to provide a $40m contribution in each year. I remind the Senate that that program has included in excess of $8m that has been spent to date on Murray Valley salinity and drainage works in South Australia. Secondly, this Government's contribution might be summarised in its decision to scrap the bicentennial water resources program, which was aimed at accelerating new water resource and development projects towards our bicentennial year, a program that was to make a contribution averaging in excess of $70m a year.

Instead, we have been told by this Government that it is preparing its own program. I appreciate the arguments that we hear that the Government has had only seven months in office and is entitled to look to its own program. But one must state a concern that this will not be simply another example of the expedient of deferral which we seem to have seen in relation to uranium and to a crimes commission, and so on. So it is all right for the Government to say that it is looking to its own program, but we on the Opposition side of the Senate are most anxiously looking towards that program to ensure that it will come to reality.

South Australians are regarded as somewhat neurotic in relation to the River Murray. It is not a coincidence that three of the four speakers in this debate have been South Australians, and that senators from South Australia, such as Senator Teague, have sat patiently through the debate. We welcome the presence of Mr Jacobi in the gallery. We usually see him present for water resource debates in the Senate. But it is necessary for the Senate and for those who might read Hansard to appreciate the significance and importance of the River Murray to South Australia. The phrase has been used-it is true and it is worth repeating-that it really is our lifeline. It provides the water necessary to irrigate over 40,000 hectares a year. It provides 50 per cent of South Australia 's domestic, industrial and stock requirements. In dry years that figure is in the vicinity of 62 per cent. In 1977-78, for instance, 83 per cent of Adelaide's water requirements were met by the River Murray. I think that that indicates just how critical it is to the future survival and development of our State.

We have had in the past in South Australia a problem with quantity of water. Whilst we shall never have enough water in South Australia and, as Senator Jessop has said, we are wrestling with the problems of the larger quantities of water that will be necessary for the development of such natural resource projects as Roxby Downs, we now recognise that we have reasonable security as to quantity. For that security we are particularly thankful for the contribution made by the River Murray Commission and by the Act that it has to administer. In passing, I might say that an example of the gains that we have made as a result of the existence of the Act and the Commission has been an extra 23 per cent, which we now have as a result of the completion of the Dartmouth Dam.

But our complaint in more recent times has related to quality and, as has been said this morning, particularly to salinity. In drought years-I refer particularly to 1967-68, when salinity levels caused permanent damage to orchards-the cost of salinity to domestic users and secondary industry in South Australia has been estimated at about $10m. That is $10m in one year. In terms that are easily understood, the Maunsell report showed that from 1966-67 to 1977 -78 the annual salt loads entering South Australia from upstream varied from 610 ,000 tonnes to 4,370,000 tonnes-massive figures for salt entering South Australia from further upstream. The former South Australian Government, the Liberal Government, produced a graph which indicated that between 1962 and 1964 there was only a 40 per cent probability that water would be safe for all irrigated crops, and there was a 15 per cent probability that the salinity level would exceed the World Health Organisation criterion for the highest desirable salinity for potable water.

To the extent that the salinity level in South Australia arises from natural or artificial practices within our State, we must, of course, accept our responsibility. To the extent that it arises from the upper States, we require the good will of those States. The River Murray Waters Agreement incorporated within this Bill is, therefore, an historic agreement, as Senator Sir John Carrick mentioned. It is historic not only because it is the first major review of the legislation since 1914; it is historic because finally the Commission has a responsibility for water quality as well as water quantity. The history of the development of the Bill and of the Act to date, which I shall briefly outline, indicates its historical significance.

It was in the 1960s that salinity problems were becoming evident in the middle and lower reaches of the Murray, and this was recognised by the Commission. Although the Commission appreciated that it did not have a responsibility for combating salinity, it is to its credit that it nevertheless engaged the consultants Messrs Gutteridge, Haskins and Davey, in conjunction with Hunting Technical Services, of London, which produced the report 'River Murray Salinity Investigation 1970'. That report identified sources of salinity and proposed engineering and agricultural solutions. It showed also, most importantly, that data available was limited. Because of its limited charter, the Commission reported the need for remedial action, the execution of which was seen as the responsibility of the States and the Commonwealth.

The subject was again considered by the River Murray Commission in 1971. At that time the Commission accepted a responsibility for monitoring and reporting salinity in the Murray and streams entering the Murray, which was a considerable advance, and a responsibility for investigation and implementation of remedial measures where an increase in salinity arose from Commission works. Then in 1973 , on the initiative of South Australia-so many of the initiatives on this subject have come from South Australia-the Prime Minister convened a meeting of heads of the government party to the River Murray Waters Agreement to discuss the future of the river, particularly in relation to salinity control. This led to a working party being established to examine and recommend the types of measures needed to be taken to improve water quality in respect of long term salinity control and other forms of pollution, and to recommend changes to the agreement to enable the Commission to undertake such measures. That was back in 1973.

Although the working party's recommendations were accepted, with the governments agreeing that they should form the basis of the preparation of a new agreement, there was still some opposition nevertheless expressed that the Commission should not deal with pollution other than salinity. The Commission forwarded its recommendations for a new agreement to the governments in July 1978, and since then the governments concerned have considered the proposals and ministerial meetings have been held, finally culminating, after a further three years of debate, in the agreement that was reached on 16 October 1981. So it has taken a further two years from the reaching of that agreement to this Bill being debated in the Senate. It is comforting to note, as Senator Carrick mentioned in his contribution this morning, that in the meantime, nevertheless, the governments concerned and the Commission have been acting within the spirit of the agreement. It has, therefore, been a long and tortuous task. But, also, it is a milestone in the history of River Murray management.

What does it mean, particularly for South Australia? It means that the River Murray Commission can now formulate river quality objectives or standards as appropriate for various locations on the river. South Australia has long sought that. In particular, we have sought an accepted quality objective for water crossing the South Australian border. Once standards of water quality are stated , the next step is to determine what steps are necessary to achieve those objectives. To assist the River Murray Commission a computer model of the river has, I understand, now been constructed. All the studies are complete and I understand that a meeting will be held this week to determine when that computer model will come into operation. It will be able to calculate on an ongoing basis what is necessary to achieve the agreed quality objectives. It will have to take into account what has been and what is being achieved in salinity control even without the agreement now reached. What has been achieved includes the full operational impact of the Dartmouth Dam and the specific salinity control and drainage works recommended by the report of Maunsell and Partners Pty Ltd on which in excess of $36m has already been spent.

The Commission may find that it can substantially reduce salinity by manipulating the storages it has. This will be the great value of the computer model because it will be able to predict the effect at any one place on the river of what is happening elsewhere, whether that be natural or artificial. Further major works be shown to be necessary. Two of such works identified by the Maunsell report and pressed by the former South Australian Government include the Lake Tyrrell scheme and the Kerang region dewatering scheme. The removal of poor irrigation practices may substantially improve the water quality . That view has been confidently put to the Senate today. South Australia has believed for some time that poor irrigation practices in the Murray-Darling area have substantially contributed to the level of salinity crossing the South Australian border.

Improved irrigation systems and practices will, it is claimed, improve water use and efficiency and reduce excessive saline ground water backflows to the River Murray and its tributaries. That has been dealt with in some detail by both Senator Sir John Carrick and Senator Elstob. In that regard South Australia can claim to have led the way but it recognises that some extra incentive may be necessary when the benefits will be gained in South Australia, particularly in Victoria. I remind the Senate that in the United States of America, in a similar program with the Colorado River, the federal government meets 75 per cent of the cost of on-farm improvements.

We should recognise the taxation incentives that were offered, I think in 1980, by the previous Federal Government for improvement of irrigation practices. We should also recognise that, subsequent to this agreement being reached, it was announced that a Commonwealth-State working group would review the extent to which irrigators are adopting improved irrigation practices and to assess the possible need for additional incentives. That report was brought down in June of 1982. Its conclusions and recommendations are particularly important. They are brief but a little longer than I would want to read into the transcript today and I therefore seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the summary and conclusions and the recommendations of that working party.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
REPORT OF THE COMMONWEALTH, NEW SOUTH WALES, VICTORIA AND SOUTH AUSTRALIA WORKING GROUP ON INCENTIVES FOR FARM BASED MEASURES IN SALINITY AND DRAINAGE CONTROL IN THE MURRAY VALLEY
SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS

The Murray Valley continues to have salinity and drainage problems affecting both the water and land resources and the industries, towns and cities that depend on the river system. The problem in the lower river Sunraysia and Riverland areas is primarily one of, at times, high river salinities which can result in reduced crop yields, while, in the mid-Murray areas, the problem is basically one of high and often saline water tables which may inhibit plant growth by salting of the soil. In total, these form an increasingly significant national problem.

Agricultural practices in the Valley since white settlement have exacerbated the natural salinity of the river and have resulted in a substantial rise in groundwater levels. Major studies of salinity problems in the Valley have all identified improved irrigation and drainage practices at the farm level as necessary for the long-term solution to the problem and to enable irrigators along the lower river, who will inevitably be exposed to periods of high salinity irrigation water, to mitigate the impacts. Current land use has developed over a long period of time and, while in general, it is appropriate to the soil types and climate of the area, the continuing existence of some enterprises may be questioned. In addition, there are particular areas that may be considered unsuitable for irrigation.

The Gutteridge, Haskins and Davey report of 1970, the River Murray Working Party report of 1975 and the Maunsel and Partners report of 1979 all recommended a range of necessary works and measures to combat salinity and drainage problems , including action at the farm level. The three States, with Commonwealth financial assistance, have commenced engineering works to lower watertables and prevent saline effluent from entering the river system.

As an integral part of the plan of action recommended by Maunsel and Partners, measures at the farm level were seen as complementary to publicly-funded engineering works and, in some cases, perhaps a substitute for public works. The consultants were concerned that on-farm measures should not lag behind, particularly as benefits can be achieved in a relatively short time, and that it is generally more cost effective to achieve an equivalent degree of control on farms than to rely solely on publicly-funded large engineering works.

Adoption of improved irrigation and drainage practices in the upper river areas would lead to increased efficiency of water use with a consequent reduction in accessions to the watertable and thus lead to reduction of saline inputs to the Murray River. In the lower river areas, an additional reason for their adoption is to reduce the adverse effects of high irrigation water salinity.

While the States involved have proceeded to offer assistance in the form of enhanced research and extension facilities, together with direct financial incentives such as grants and concessional loans, they have been severely constrained by limited finance. To date the Commonwealth has not become directly involved in assistance to farmers for improving their irrigation and drainage practices, apart from limited funding of farm improvement loans under the Rural Adjustment Scheme and through offering concessions to primary producers under the Income Tax Assessment Act. In view of the national importance of the Murray Valley it is necessary that the Commonwealth Government continues to act in concert with the States in dealing with the problem.

Precise data on the rate of adoption of improved irrigation and drainage practices on farms are not available. However, there is evidence that, particularly in the last three to four years, there has been a large increase in interest in and adoption of improved practices. In most cases, the technology of improved irrigation and drainage methods is available-such as drip, micro-jet and other forms of sprinkler irrigation, tile drainage techniques, laser grading for improved layout for flood irrigation, re-use systems for farms to utilise drainage flows, and other methods. The limits are the communication of technology and the funds to adopt it.

Also, there is evidence that producers currently adopting improved irrigation and drainage practices are typical of the early-adopter class of farmers and it cannot be assumed that the current rates of adoption of improvements in practices will continue.

There are producers who appreciate the need to improve their irrigation and drainage practices, for which they require sound technical advice. Their adoption of improved irrigation and drainage practices would be speeded by financial incentives.

Regrettably, there are also those who do not have the resources or the incentive to change, and who are the main contributors to salinity problems. In the interests of the resource, these landholders should be offered strong incentives to change their practices or be encouraged to leave irrigated agriculture.

Options examined to encourage greater adoption of improved practices ranged from indirect measures, such as taxation concessions and water pricing policies, and direct assistance like the Rural Assistance Scheme and a range of special measures to stimulate improvements. These include grants and loan concessions, such as subsidised interest rates, long-term loans, repayment holidays and concessions on loan security.

In the case of taxation concessions, many farmers undertook investments in the belief, or on the advice of their accountants, that they would be eligible for the new concessions announced in 1980. However, the impact of the concessions on investment in new technology will be limited, given recent determinations of the Commissioner of Taxation. The Working Group concluded that taxation concessions are appropriate for some farmers but require a broader interpretation to be effective. Many farmers are not in a position to be able to take advantage of taxation concessions.

The Working Group concluded that a broader approach to direct funding for improved irrigation and drainage practices was necessary. Such an approach should include the current provisions under the farm improvement section of the Rural Adjustment Scheme; an interest rate subsidy scheme, subject to eligibility and operating through the commercial banking system; concessional loans from government sources for those farmers who do not meet criteria for commerical loans; and a grant component in financial packages, where necessary, to provide an incentive for group schemes. Significant factors in any loan scheme were seen to be loan periods that are consistent with the type of investment undertaken, repayment holidays to overcome early cash flow constraints and concessional iterest rates, subject to ability to repay loans.
On the best available information, such a scheme would require an injection of some $3.269m per annum as follows:
New South
South Wales Victoria Australia Total ($)
To be eligible for inclusion in the scheme, a whole farm plan approach should be a pre-requisite and the loans should be tailored to suit individual cash flow situations.

The Working Group also concluded that additional advisory effort is required to ensure that farmers will receive adequate information on the latest technology and to ensure the most effective use of funds. This would require some $300,000 per annum. Additional resources would also be required in each State for administrative and design support for the scheme. Furthermore, funds, under other programs, will be required for research, to overcome problems which develop as currently available technological information reaches its limits.
RECOMMENDATIONS
The Working Group recommends that:
1. Governments consider the following options for providing financial assistance to landholders:

1.1. A broader interpretation of the Income Tax Assessment Act be employed to clarify the situation relating to Section 75B and 75D by increasing the scope for concessions on expenditure in water conservation technology, salinity and drainage problems and to prevent exacerbation of the problems in the future.
1.2. Current financial assistance schemes involving unrealistically low interest rates should be amended.
1.3. A broader approach be made to direct funding for the adoption of improved practices to include:

a scheme to subsidise interest on commercial loans be introduced; the interest subsidy should be on a sliding scale according to ability to repay so that the net amount will be not less than 9 per cent or more than 4 per cent below commercial rates of interest;

for those unable to attract direct commercial funding, the current provisions under the Farm Improvements Section of the Rural Adjustment Scheme should be maintained and augmented by direct government loans to farmers on concessional terms tailored to suit individual requirements; and
grants should be considered as an incentive, where necessary, to implement group schemes which, in some cases could replace the need for publicly-funded works.
Assistance is recommended for an initial period of five years, subject to review at the end of this period.

2. Advisory services be upgraded in each of the States to assist in assuring an increased rate of adoption of improved irrigation and drainage practices. (The provision of such services for the three States would require an additional $300 ,000 per annum for the next five years, together with additional resources for design work and administration.)

3. Provisions of the Rural Adjustment Scheme be examined to facilitate effective rehabilitation or relocation of those farmers who are unable to, or do not wish to avail themselves of assistance measures and wish to leave irrigation farming.

4. Studies be continued in each State to ascertain optimum land and water use policies, updating of land capability investigations, implications for agricultural industries, marketing policies and government irrigation and drainage infrastructure.
5. Data be collected on the cost to revenue of taxation concessions to enable assessment of their effectiveness.

6. Any planned extension or intensification of irrigation should be subject to careful and detailed examination and future industry adjustment schemes seriously consider retirement of, or alternative landuse for, badly drained areas, consistent with long-term land capability.
7. Appropriate water pricing and allocation policies be pursued, as an incentive to farmers to optimise water use.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a matter of interest, I understand that so far only the former South Australian Liberal Government has responded to that report, which is disappointing. I understand that the Commonwealth Government is still waiting for the responses of Victoria and New South Wales and feels that it cannot respond until it has those responses. That report recognised that the Commonwealth has not been directly involved in assistance to farmers for improving their irrigation and drainage practices, apart from limited funding for on-farm improvement loans under the rural adjustment scheme and the offering of the taxation incentives that I have just mentioned. It said that in view of the national importance of the Murray Valley, it is necessary that the Commonwealth Government continue to act in concert with the States in dealing with the problems. It made a series of recommendations dealing with such matters as a suggested interest rate subsidy scheme, concessional loans from government sources and incentives for group schemes. It is something which I believe is worthy of considerable study and I trust that it will not be long before the Labor governments in Victoria and New South Wales and the Commonwealth Government can give us a response to that report.

SPEECH.PARA: There are limitations and reservations to the agreement reached that is incorporated in this Bill and I think they should be mentioned. The principal reservation is that the River Murray Commission cannot regulate; it can only recommend. It does not have a power to impose sanctions. That is true of the States, of course, but the States to date have not been prepared to yield their sovereign powers. They have not been prepared to agree to the setting up of a full national waters authority. It appears that they will not do so, although, as I mentioned to Senator Elstob in interjection, the previous South Australian Liberal Government, representing the State that is most affected and, therefore, not surprisingly the leading agitator in the field, indicated that it would be prepared to yield such powers to a national water authority provided there was reciprocal agreement by the other States and, of course, such agreement was not forthcoming.

However, that does not mean that this agreement will not work. We have noted that it has worked in relation to quantity and there is no reason why it cannot work in relation to quality. All the States have now agreed to the principle of quality control. It is hoped that no one State will now frustrate the implementation of that principal. The experience of the last two years has been favourable and therefore can give us some hope. To achieve such objectives the River Murray Commission would, with its powers of persuasion, be assisted by the fact that now water quantity to a State will take into account its performance in areas of water quality, that is, in relation to tributary flows. I think that is a major advance which should be recognised.

Two further limitations to the new Bill deserve mention. It does not include the participation of Queensland, which is a weakness in view of the importance of the upper Darling River basin to the quality and quantity of the River Murray waters. Also, the River Murray Commission's functions are limited to the main trunk of the river and tributaries above the Hume. Both of those limitations cry out for attention in the future.

It is clear that in the last year or so nature has given us a short respite from the perilous situation that we appeared to be getting into in South Australia, particularly in relation to water quality. The water is now flowing fast and much of the build-up of salinity has been flushed out. With that, there comes a natural tendency to relax. I suggest that we must particularly guard against that. If there is drought for the next few years, which is quite possible, in South Australia we could face a calamitous situation.

It was the earnest desire of the previous Liberal Government in South Australia that a permanent solution to the problem of water quality of the Rivery Murray be achieved by Australia's bicentennial year, 1988. South Australia saw the first step as being the amendments to the River Murray Waters Agreement which we are now getting and which, in practice, had been in effect for two years. The second step we saw was to determine quality standards. Now that the computer model has been completed, we trust that that step will be rapidly advanced in the near future. The third step will be to carry out the works which will be necessary to meet those quality objectives. I trust that this new Commonwealth Government will show greater spirit in this area than it has shown to date to ensure that such works are carried out.

I doubt that a totally permanent solution will be found without a national water authority and a transfer of powers. Senator Elstob mentioned the massive increase in irrigation that is being sought in New South Wales. It is a fact of political life that great pressure can be brought to bear on State governments, particularly in difficult political circumstances. Without a national authority to overcome such parochial pressures I doubt that a truly permanent solution will ever be found. Such a solution would have to include Queensland and the power to impose sanctions. Nevertheless, on the basis of the agreement that has now been reached, I believe that with diligence and goodwill there is no reason why by 1988 South Australia cannot be as secure in quality as it is in quantity in relation to water from the Murray. That, for South Australia, would be a tremendous advance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — Failed politicians have a well-earned reputation for self-indulgence and self- justification. We had another demonstration of that phenomenon when Senator Sir John Carrick attempted to justify the bicentennial water resources program which the previous Government produced in its terminal months. It was, in fact, a cynical election stunt, one which, moreover, failed. As the present Deputy Leader and clearly leader-aspirant of the Liberal Party of Australia has had the decency to acknowledge, it would have been repudiated had the Fraser Government been returned. Mr Howard has publicly acknowledged, for example, that the funding of the Burdekin scheme along with all other items of government expenditure would have been up for review had the Liberal Party been returned to Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sir John Carrick is already known as the politician chiefly responsible for talking up the Rundle twins, the market capitalisation, to a value of about $1,200m. The last time I bothered to look at the market capitalisation, it was something like $300m, and it has fallen a good deal since. Now, apparently, by his stubborn defence of the cynical election stunt which was dubbed the bicentennial water resources program after it had been produced, he has shown that his current ambition is apparently to join that list of cranks associated with the Premier of Queensland, including such notables as Stephen Horvath and Milan Brych. By Senator Sir John Carrick's endorsement of the ridiculous Bradfield scheme, he puts himself in the same category as disciples of the Premier of Queensland, in such company as Stephen Horvath and Milan Brych. I will not bother to say any more about Senator Sir John Carrick because I really do not think his importance justifies any more comment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except the credit you could give him for the Bill and for the agreement.

—I was about to do that. I was about to acknowledge that the Bill itself is a bipartisan measure. As Senator Hill and probably Senator Sir John Carrick pointed out, it was in fact prepared by the previous Government. The principles embodied in it had the support of the Labor Party in opposition, just as Labor in government has the support now of the present Opposition. I do not think its importance should be overstated. It extends the ambit of the River Murray Commission to monitoring water quality and to the tributaries of the river. Even that relatively modest advance took 10 years to negotiate, which is testimony, as Senator Elstob and Senator Jessop have both noted, to the impediments to rational policy-making and administration which are imposed by our Federal system of government.

SPEECH.PARA: The point has been made that Australia is the driest continent in the world, excluding Antarctica, which has the lowest mean precipitation. It is not entirely correct to extrapolate from that fact that Australia has a crucial shortage of water. Water needs are subsequently a function of population. On that basis, as Davidson pointed out almost 20 years ago, only Brazil is better endowed with water than Australia. There are two major problems in the availability of Australian water supplies. Most of the stream flow is in the relatively unpopulated northern half of the country. Seventy-five per cent of that which is currently stored and available is used for irrigation, invariably at prices below the cost of supply. Often the end product can be marketed only with difficulty, if at all. In some cases the end product then significantly contributes to salinity and other environmental problems.

Of the potential water supplies which have already been harnessed, the most important are connected with the Murray-Darling system, which is the subject of this Bill. Much of that water is misallocated by price discrimination in favour of irrigators and against urban industrial consumers and, in particular, against the residents of country towns. The Government notes with considerable satisfaction that most States-now there are Labor governments in all but one of the States concerned with the Murray-Darling system-are moving to rectify that inequitable and inefficient system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you urge them to put up the price of water?
—Yes. I am about to do so. In fact, two State governments had the common sense to do what no Liberal government or National Party government has ever had the courage or decency to do.
—Would it not be better to ask them to pay for what they use? Is that a common pricing policy?
—No, he is going to put up the price.

—A correct pricing policy even in isolation would provide sufficient additional water through the more efficient use of water by means of the termination or partial termination of present waste to ensure that at all times the Murray River had fresh water-as far as salinity is concerned-available for South Australia. There is little doubt that a saving of 10 per cent on present consumptions would provide at all times sufficient water in reserve to ensure that the Murray was flushed out as far as salinity was concerned. There is no reasonable doubt that--
—In hard droughts?
—In past droughts, yes.
—In hard, continuous droughts, in a drought lasting three, four or five years?

—A 10 per cent saving on present consumptions over the long term would ensure that at all times the Murray River had sufficient water for South Australia which was not unduly contaminated by salinity. It would not guarantee that it was not muddy. I point out to Senator Sir John Carrick that a correct pricing policy means higher charges for irrigators. At least two States have publicly announced their intention to move in that direction. That is something that this Government notes with considerable satisfaction, since the States have control of these matters. They have done that because they have responsible and rational Labor governments, as distinct from the government which they unfortunately have habitually had. If the higher income produced by those charges were used to fund or subsidise superior irrigation technology such as laser land levelling, trickle irrigation and superior drainage, that, in itself, would make a significant contribution to overcoming the salinity problem. The turbidity problem, raised by several other speakers, is not so easily overcome. As Senator Jessop noted, a proper attack on the turbidity problem would necessarily involve the State of Queensland, which is at least at some times the major source of turbidity in the lower reaches of the Murray, below the Darling confluence.

SPEECH.PARA: By any rational assessment, what is needed is not, as the cargo cultists such as Senator Sir John Carrick assert, more storages, but a more efficient use of what water is already available in the Murray-Darling system. The rationality of this argument is not compatible with that assertion. The points made by Dr Geoff Miller, when he was Director of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics some years ago-he is currently the Director of the Economic Planning Advisory Council-are important and valid. He said that existing capital expenditure in irrigation schemes is sunk and therefore what would be a rational pricing policy for a proposed irrigation scheme would not necessarily be a rational pricing policy for a scheme already built and operating and into which capital had been sunk. He nevertheless made the point that more efficient pricing policies, and, yes, for Senator Sir John Carrick's benefit, that does mean higher water charges to irrigators; apparently he thinks there is some great advantage in getting me on the record saying what two State goverments have already announced as a policy objective-

TALK.START.PARA: —Which States were those? Did you mention the States?

—Both New South Wales and Victoria have announced intentions to move in that direction. South Australia may have as well but I am not aware of it having done so. Of course, Senator Sir John Carrick is yesterday's man and continues to follow yesterday's policy-that water should be deliberately underpriced in a way which both leads to misallocation of water and induces serious environmental problems and external economic costs, the principal one of which is salinity. As Miller pointed out, the criteria which a rational economist would apply to a proposed scheme and an existing scheme are not the same. Nevertheless, he pointed out, more efficient pricing policies ought to be used, to ensure a net economic gain from a State, regional or national perspective. A rational economic assessment of projected projects would insist not only that full operating costs be recovered in water charges but also that at least some return on invested taxpayers' funds be provided.

SPEECH.PARA: The usual answer, the sort of attitude displayed by yesterday's man the former Minister, in the Senate again today, is that rational water pricing policies, or full cost recovery pricing policies, will stop development. In some circumstances that may be so. If a return on capital of, say, 5 per cent in real terms were required, water charges would have to be pitched at a level sufficient to provide that return on public funds. That is the publicly announced objective of the Government of Victoria. The Australian Treasury believes that a 10 per cent real rate of return is more appropriate but I will not pass judgment on which of those figures is the more appropriate. If we take the lower one, a 5 per cent real rate of return, even that may mean that some projects are sub-economic. If for some other reason a government intends to proceed with them, that is the business of that government. It would entail value judgments as well as economic judgments.

However, one thing of which we can be quite certain, which cannot be rationally disputed-that does not exclude the possibility of Senator Sir John Carrick disputing it-is that water charges can be increased, and I put this in the context of new projects, to the point where the capital appreciation in land prices normally associated with water rights in an irrigation scheme is entirely eliminated. Such a policy would have no effect on regional development. Of course, such a policy is stoutly resisted by those who stand to gain from the traditional practice of supplying water not only at below cost but also at a price so low that windfall capital gains accrue to those who are arbitrarily allocated the rights to that water. I note that, with the Burdekin scheme, the Queensland Government continues to attempt both to pay excessive compensation for land which must be resumed and to provide windfall capital gains to selected favoured clients of the National Party Government of that State.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could have put that in the agreement, if you wanted to. You could have put a caveat against that in the agreement if you wanted to, but you did not do it.

—Senator Sir John Carrick is now singing a different tune. He was telling us a few weeks ago that the previous Government had taken on a binding commitment to fund the Burdekin scheme. Now he tells us that the present Government was the one which had control. He cannot have it both ways.
—You did the written agreement-the written agreement as it stands now.

—The only one that was binding! What the honourable senator had for the Burdekin was what he announced at the end of January, in that mirage designed to shimmer on the horizon between then and 5 March. That is what his bicentennial water resources program was. He made a promise which his deputy leader has since acknowledged that he would have broken had they won the election. That is what he had for the Burdekin scheme, and that is what he had for everything else. The honourable senator is yesterday's man; I will make no more comment on his puerile contribution to this debate. This Bill is a step in the right direction. As I noted earlier, it has bipartisan support now, as it had bipartisan support when it was prepared by the previous Government in 1982. I do not intend to delay its passage any longer.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 2 November 1983.
GROUP B
Department of Social Security
Proposed expenditure, $653,298,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked a number of questions at the hearing of Estimates Committee B to which I believe I have not received satisfactory answers. I asked what the total cost would be for the assets test. I do not know how to identify the answer but it states:

SPEECH.PARA: Information Sought . . . Senators Messner and Walters asked a series of questions about the estimates of costs for the administration of asset testing of social security pensions . . .

The answer went on to deal mainly with the $20m from the Advance to the Minister for Finance. I want to know the total cost. According to the Department of Social Security, it is possible to compile only broad estimates of the likely cost of the administration until the Government makes up its mind what it is doing about the assets test. I do not think the answer is quite satisfactory. A breakdown of the $20m is given, but many things which normally would be attributed to the cost of the assets test have been left out. I want more detail . I think the Minister would acknowledge that there is not enough information.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, I repeat briefly what I said last night. We are in the process of framing the details of the assets test. Legislation will be coming forward in a couple of weeks. The departmental estimate of $20m is listed in the answer which I have here. It includes everything from salaries to that famous entry 'miscellaneous' which appears in all such estimates. Senator Walters said that certain items which she felt should be included were not included. I am afraid I do not know what they are.
—Perhaps I could tell the Minister.
—The honourable senator had better give me some idea.

— Can the Minister inform me what amount is involved for posting? I cannot see that item in the list. There must be some costing for the postage involved in sending out to the various pensioner groups information forms, et cetera. I would like also a breakup of the estimate of $1m under the miscellaneous item. I think that even Senator Grimes would acknowledge that that item is a bit broad. An estimate of $0.25m is given for the item, forms. Does that involve the printing of the forms? I do not know what it is. Does it involve printing or postage, or a combination of those two? The way in which the breakdown is set out is not satisfactory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —While I can understand Senator Walters's curiosity, I cannot quite understand what she seeks in respect of posting. Postage and telephones are generally included in the same vote. Senator Walters referred to the posting of forms. There is no actual breakdown of the amount of money which will be required to post the forms. The Department has not at any stage pretended that this is an exact and final costing for a program which has not yet been introduced and which will be introduced gradually over the next year provided the legislation is in place. I do not think the Department or anyone else could be expected to be held to whether the estimated expenditure of $20m will end up being an actual expenditure of $22m, $23m, $17m or $18m.

SPEECH.PARA: I will seek from the Department its estimate for the postage involved in sending out those forms. As I understand it, the amount includes printing and design of the forms and does not include postage. That is my information. I suspect that the postage may be included along with telephones. But I have no confirmation of that. However, I have asked the officers to seek that information for the honourable senator. We do not have a breakdown of the miscellaneous item. I will seek the information for the honourable senator.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just raised the item of postage off the top of my head. I am quite sure the Department will come up with a few other items which have been left out. The Minister said that postage may be included under the telephone item. That may be the case. This information has been poorly put together by the Department. I thank the Minister for seeking to obtain the information for me in a clearer fashion. Secondly, the next page of the answer states:

SPEECH.PARA: The salaries estimate provides for staffing in excess of 2,000 officers . . .
That is a terribly broad statement. What does 'in excess of 2,000 officers' mean ? It could be 500,000 or 2,100.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe in the Estimates Committee report it was estimated that the maximum number of people who would be employed would be up to 2,400, although all of them would not be employed at the same time or for the full year. I think the figure averaged out at 1,240-odd, but that was for the first year only. The first thing that has to be done in any of these measures, as the honourable senator knows, is to establish all the entitlements and put the assets test in place throughout the year. The Department's estimate was finalised in conjunction with the Public Service Board, which has the experts, after discussion. The best estimate, as I say, is in excess of 2,000. It could be as high as 2,400. It may be a very little over 2,000. I believe I need not make any apology for the Department for not being able to pin that down to the number of people. It is a new program.
—It is an estimate.

—As Senator Primmer says, it is an estimate. It is a new program which was announced and is being developed in consultation with the various pensioner groups. We are talking about an estimate in the order of $20m and about 2,000 officers or, if one likes, 2,400. I do not think anyone can expect in a new program such as this any department to pin down the number of staff involved, especially in the light of the fact that there are some two million pensioners and that we have not collected information on assets from pensioners since 1976. I remind the honourable senator that there are 16,000 employees in the Department. We are talking about a big department and a big project which involves the whole country. I cannot give any more accurate estimates than that. I think honourable senators will find estimates of this order in every department when any new program comes in. What the Budget is about is giving an estimate of how much money will be spent and on what it will be spent, but it is always an estimate. In this case no one is pretending it is anything else.

—If it is difficult to estimate how many people will be needed to administer the assets test, will the Minister for Social Security please tell me how a decision was made on what the savings could be and how much the Government will make out of changes in the pensioner area?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That equally is an estimate. But what we have done has been to look at certain facts and certain things and extrapolate from them. For instance, in 1976 the previous Government decided to remove the assets component from the means test. It told this Parliament and the people of this country that that was a no cost option. In fact it cost the revenue something like $70m. We know that since then there has been a great burgeoning of the contrivance schemes about which I talked last night. We know that all of the advertisements which the good senator, like everyone else, reads in the Australian Financial Review, the National Times, the Pensioners Weekly, the Australian Pensioner and Prime Time cost money and we know that the promoters of these schemes are not putting the advertisements in these publications without getting some return from them. We know there is a considerable amount of money there. We know from the Department of Veterans' Affairs, which has collected some assets information since 1976, that there are a certain number of people who have large assets holdings and still get the full pensions and full fringe benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: We made a decision to introduce the assets test in the light of the fact that we realise, like anyone else in this community who thinks about it realises, that we have an aging population and that we have an increasing number of people , including people in receipt of the age pension and other pensions, who are dependent on pensions and benefits and a decreasing number of people who are paying taxes and have the capacity to support that area. So we realised, again like anyone else who thinks about it, that we had to take certain steps to ensure that we had an income support system based more on need, and one of the ways in which we could do that was by the reintroduction of an assets test. But that is not the only thing we will do. One of the things we realised in doing that was that we could make savings in the order of a couple of hundred million dollars in both the veterans' affairs area and social security area.

We know that that is a rough estimate. No one pretends it is not. The Department of Social Security then sat down and worked out what capacity it would need, first of all, to train people, what capacity it would need during the year to set the assets test in place and what number of support staff would be needed in that area. The Department, with the assistance of the Public Service Board and so on, has come up with an estimate of just in excess of 2,000 people. That is the way things are always done. That would be done in any large organisation, be it public or private. But no one is pretending that the figure will be exact, that one can be pinned down exactly to that figure.

Senator Walters may wish somehow to pin the Department down this year so that next year when we are considering next year's estimates she can say that the estimate was 20 or 100 above or 100 below. But I put it to the Committee that that is not a reasonable approach. I think that the Department has put its cards on the table. In some ways it has put its reputation on the line in respect of these estimates. We will just have to see, in carrying out government policy, how accurate those estimates are.

However, in view of the record of the Department of Social Security, all I can say is that those estimates are likely to be very accurate within the limitations and the difficulties which the Department faces.

TALK.START.PARA: — Could the Minister for Social Security then tell me, perhaps to simplify the staffing situation, how many extra permanent, temporary or part time staff will be required-in other words, staff in every area and every facet? Can he tell me what is the estimate in those three categories? The Minister might remember that I also asked for the total number of staff in the whole of the Department. If the Minister looks at the Hansard record he will find that I made that request. I was given information for the period June 1983 to June 1984 in regard to Division 560. I want the numbers for the whole of the Department. Is the Minister able to provide me with information on both of those requests?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the answer set out on the second page of the document containing written replies to questions asked during the sittings of Estimates Committee B is that the peak staffing level is expected to be 16,971 at 30 June. Although normally the peak staffing level is at the end of February as a result of an increase in the number of unemployment benefit applications, there is expected to be an increase in the number of staff later in the year because of an increase in the training program for automatic data processing upgrading. The assets testing is not included in that estimate, as I understand. However, I am informed by my officers that the figure of 16,971 is in fact for the whole Department. Of course, the permanent head is only one of those included in the areas that are chargeable to the appropriations, other than the appropriations that the honourable senator mentioned.

SPEECH.PARA: The rehabilitation component is charged to the National Welfare Fund. The staffing level is 1,803 and is not expected to increase this year. The Socal Welfare Policy Secretariat, which is contained in division 561, had a staff of 18 in 1983. It is expected to have a staff of 21 in 1984. Therefore, in fact these are the only areas that I understand are not in the appropriations about which the honourable senator was talking. No increase in the staff is estimated for the rehabilitation area this year. There is to be an increase of only three staff in the Social Welfare Secretariat.

TALK.START.PARA: — Can the Minister for Social Security give me the total cost for all areas of public information? For instance, is there anything in the Special Minister of State area that would apply to the social welfare area? I think that there are already two areas of expenditure in regard to public information. Can the Minister let me have the total costs? Can he tell me whether the Department of the Special Minister of State is involved?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the latter part of the honourable senator's request, I believe that she will have to ask the Department of the Special Minister of State. That Department certainly co- operates with the Department of Social Security and other departments in regard to public information services. However, my officers and I do not have any information about the breakdown of that Department's budget. I think that the honourable senator had better ask for that information when the estimates for SMOS are dealt with. I am not saying that the information should not be available; it is just not available from our estimates.

SPEECH.PARA: As to total expenditure, I will get the departmental people to add the various areas together. I do not know whether this can be done very easily but I daresay we can do that for the honourable senator. However, our information will not include any expenditure from the Special Minister of State.

TALK.START.PARA: — Will there be a financial impact statement?
—A financial impact statement on what?
—On all the various programs that we have been promised.
—There will be a financial impact statement on any legislation that I bring into this place. That is what we have promised.
— Will there be a financial impact statement on the assets test and everything else that flows from today?
—Yes.
—Why was there no financial impact statement on legislation that has already been introduced?

—The financial implications of all the social security listed were clearly in the Budget. I think the honourable senator is asking a bit much if she wants an extra financial impact statement on budgetary legislation. The estimated costs for the social security amendment legislation which was brought into this place have been stated quite clearly in the Budget. The costs are supplied not only for this year, but also for next year. I think ongoing costs for two years are usually included in the Budget Papers. If the honourable senator wants us to reproduce budgetary figures in Budget legislation and call those figures a financial impact statement, fair enough. But certainly we have said that any legislation that is introduced outside that area will have a financial impact statement. I certainly intend, in bringing in the assets test, to make clear to the Senate what we believe can be gained and cannot be gained. I certainly will not pretend now, nor will I then, that I can be as accurate as, perhaps, Senator Walters would like or as I would like. She knows that one of the things that bedevils us in this country is a lack of information on people's asset holdings and also on their capacity. We have enough trouble knowing what the income and assets are of those who earn incomes let alone those who have assets.

—I asked whether we could have a financial impact statement. The Minister for Social Security told me that we could not have one on Budget matters as that had already been done. In answer to my question during the Estimates Committee hearing as to how much the assets test would cost altogether, I was told that it is possible to compile only broad estimates of the likely costs of administration for assets testing until decisions are taken by the Government about the detailed form of the assets test and the related legislation is considered in Parliament. If the financial impact statement on the assets test is part of the Budget Papers and we will not have a further financial impact statement because I am so dumb that I do not understand the Budget Papers, I do not know what we are talking about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me spell it out in words of one syllable. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) on Budget night announced the intention of introducing an assets test. The second thing he announced was that we would be, in the first two or three months after the Budget, consulting with various pensioner groups and community groups as to the detail of the assets test. He gave an outline of the assets test. The assets test will not be in place or have effect until the end of next year. The aspects of the assets test which affect this year's Budget are the estimates for the number of staff that will be needed to establish it. Those figures are clearly in the Budget Papers. Senator Walters may not like the figures; she may think that we should be more accurate, but they are there. Legislation will be introduced into this place shortly which will contain our final proposals for the assets test. That legislation will be introduced for consideration in this place as it will be introduced into the other Chamber. Quite clearly we will have then, as best we can, the estimates of the impact of the assets test on the budgetary situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind Senator Walters that the final figures for the assets test will appear in next year's Budget, not this year's Budget. The assets test will not start until the end of next year. I will not come in here and say that we are introducing an assets test and try not to tell honourable senators what effect it may have at the end of next year but of course, it will be affected by what we do with pensions next year and by all sorts of other budgetary decisions which will be taken next year. We really will not have any final or accurate figure until next year's Budget. We have never pretended otherwise. Certainly, when the assets test is introduced I will be making some attempt to inform honourable senators what its budgetary impact will be.

Senator Walters suggested that a financial impact statement should be provided when we bring in a social security amendment Bill to put into place the decisions which we made in the Budget when those figures have been listed in the Budget. I believe the figures were provided in the second reading speech or at least, were available. We said in the Budget that we would index the unemployment benefit for single unemployed people and increase that benefit by $ 2 in November and $2 in May. There was a specific figure in the Budget Papers. There was a specific figure in the Budget Papers for everything we did. If that is not a financial impact statement I do not know what is. Sure, if we lifted all the figures out and listed them carefully the honourable senator could say: 'Well, you have saved me a lot of trouble, Senator Grimes. I do not have to go back to the Budget Papers and look up the figures'. But to suggest that there is no financial impact statement in Budget legislation I think is a nonsense.
Progress reported.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 October 1983, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the understanding of the Senate that honourable senators can speak on various matters of concern to them on the first readings of Bills. Briefly today in speaking to the first reading of the Radiocommunications (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments ) Bill 1983, I wish to speak to a report. It is not a Senate report or a Federal Government report which has been introduced into the Senate and on which time is allowed for debate. I take the somewhat unusual step today of bringing forward a report which relates to the Northern Territory. It is my intention later to table the report. I believe that honourable senators will find the report quite interesting as well people who are concerned with the trachoma eradication and eye health work being carried out at present.
—Which report is it?

—It is the Northern Territory Trachoma Eradication and Eye Health Committee Report 1982-83. It is that Committee's first report. It is a remarkable report. So much has been achieved in the space of one year that I take this opportunity to discuss it briefly in the Senate. Honourable senators will be aware that trachoma has been quite widespread in Australia's outback particularly among Aboriginal communities although I can remember that years ago the disease was very prevalent in small towns in the outback where sanitation and health were not as good as they are today. For quite a while the responsibility for the eradication of trachoma came under the Royal Australian College of Ophthalmologists, but because of distance, communication and financial problems there was some lack of activity and loss of time. I was critical in the Senate a year or two ago of the lack of activity and the lack of results due to that lack of activity. Previous trachoma surveys were costly and, as I said, ineffective. In fact they drew considerable criticism not only herein the Senate but also in the Northern Territory, Queensland and other places. I believe that towards the end of the campaign the medical team was withdrawn. There has been a re-enactment of the trachoma eradication campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to refer now to the report of the Northern Territory Trachoma Eradication and Eye Health Committee. It now comprises seven Aboriginals and three non-Aboriginals. The three non-Aboriginals are doctors-Dr Dayalan Devanesen, affectionately known as DD through the southern part of the Territory and amongst Aboriginal people; Dr Mahmood, an ophthalmologist who has just resigned; and Dr Ella Stack, who belongs to the Northern Territory Aboriginal Health Division. The Chairman is Mr Mace, the Principal of the Katherine Institute for Aboriginal Health. He is an Aboriginal person. The other Aboriginal members are: George Kruger, senior Aboriginal health worker; John Briscoe, President of the Apatula Council; Mrs Abbott, an Aboriginal health worker; Willie Clayton, of the National Aboriginal Conference; Mr Jambadjimba of the National Aboriginal Conference; and Mr McGuiness of the Central Australian Aboriginal Congress. The report states:

The original program as determined by the Royal Australian College of Ophthalmologists was abandoned by the committee. In its place, a new program was adopted, involving first the training and then work of Aboriginal Health Workers in trachoma control, with headquarters at Katherine Institute for Aboriginal Health. All health workers now receive training in trachoma control in their basic skills course. Some selected as Aboriginal Health Worker supervisors- Trachoma, are further trained. They then travel, teach, screen, and promote both personal and community hygiene throughout Northern Territory Aboriginal communities . . .

Funds from the National Trachoma Committee have now been released to the Northern Territory. As a result, the trust fund AOTA number 6291-41 has been closed. The Northern Territory Department of Health, which has been funding this program for some months, has been reimbursed and a new trust account has been opened at . . . Darwin. Members of the Committee who have been authorised to countersign cheques and a Member of the Royal Australian College of Ophthalmologists (Father F. Flynn)-
a most famous ophthalmologist.

TALK.START.PARA: —Frank Flynn.
—Frank Flynn, yes, and he is associated with this Committee. The report continues:

SPEECH.PARA: GENERAL OBJECTIVES OF THE NORTHERN TERRITORY TRACHOMA ERADICATION AND EYE HEALTH COMMITTEE:
1. Raise awareness of trachoma in all members of Aboriginal communities by: visits by Aboriginal health workers . . .
2. Stress the importance of personal and community hygiene in transmission of diseases by: checking on provision of ablution facilities . . .

Two four-wheel drive vehicles have been purchased. One is used exclusively by Mr G. Kruger in the northern region of the Northern Territory and the other is based at Alice Springs and is used by Johnny Briscoe (Senior Aboriginal Health Worker, and President of Apatula Council, Finke) . . .

It is interesting to note that Dr Mahmood made several visits to outlying areas of the Territory, screening and teaching Aboriginal health workers and trachoma supervisors. At present a computer program is being developed to enter 11,000 consultations with Aboriginal trachoma patients in Central Australia. It is also interesting to note that Dr J. Rogers, specialist ophthalmologist, visited the Northern Territory twice during the year, spending a month each time instructing health workers and medical personnel. He has been a member of the Royal College for some years and I am sure that the people in the outback of the Northern Territory and particularly the Aboriginal people owe this specialist a considerable amount. The report continues:
Mention must be made here of the NT Department of Health Schools Trachoma program, which is carried out in conjunction with the NT Trachoma Eradication and Eye Health Committee's program . . .

The schools program has been adopted and recommends mass treatment with topical antibiotics and such. There is considerable activity throughout the outback. Most of the visits are now undertaken by the health worker trachoma supervisors. These are Aboriginal people, and this is where I believe that the trachoma survey and treatment are getting such a boost now. With the large number of Aboriginal health workers who are involved, considerable success has been achieved in just one year. It is interesting to note with all the various settlements that have been visited, whether they are in the north or south, whether they are in the centre or on the coast, the incidence of trachoma is quite high. In some places it is perhaps not particularly high--

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the report give any percentages?

—Yes. They are 43, 45, 52, 27, 36 and 38 per cent. Indeed it goes up, senator, to as much as 80 per cent to 100 per cent. The interesting thing is that in some areas, particularly on the coast-I look at Angurugu on Groote Eylandt-the survey showed a most interesting picture because the prevalence there is only approximately 4 per cent. The Committee believes that this is due to the presence of running streams and the fact that the children play most of the day in clear freshwater streams.
—Perhaps there is not so much dust there.

—The lack of dust perhaps too brings about this lack of incidence of trachoma. This very comprehensive report is signed by Michael Mace, who is the Chairman of the Committee and, as I said, an Aboriginal person. He incidentally is in charge of all Aboriginal health workers in the Northern Territory, which now number some hundreds. It is also signed by Ella Stack, the doctor who has done much work in the Northern Territory not only for Europeans but particularly for the Aboriginal people. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Recorded in this report are 2,965 examinations in 1982-83. Several populations were re-screened, but results of only one screening are included here.
Each and every examination was part of the training of Aboriginal health workers and other medical staff. So each case was examined by the trainer and several others.
In spite of delays in funding and unnecessary argument-I have referred to that- that has dogged the efforts of the NT Committee, the members are proud to present this report.

I think they can be justly proud. As well as that report, a little book has been developed by the Aboriginal health workers in the field of trachoma control entitled Trachoma Control for Health Workers. It is a simple book which has been distributed throughout the Northern Territory and which displays very clearly information on the disease and treatment. This little manual is bringing tremendous relief to the very many Aboriginal people who suffer from trachoma in the outback. It is of interest to note that Dr Rogers, in summarising his trip, said:
I feel the trip has been worthwhile. We have done about 25 teaching sessions and taught about 150 people . . .
He went on:
It will be a long time before much effect will take place-but it is a start in the right direction to get grass roots checking underway.

I would also like to refer to a letter which is of interest and which is annexed to the report. It is signed by George Kruger, senior Aboriginal health worker, Institute for Aboriginal Health, Katherine. He said in part:

I have been with Dr Jim Rogers visiting Aboriginal communities and rural centres teaching Health personnel about trachoma. Dr Rogers and I have given talks and demonstrations to 125 Health workers, 25 Sisters and Doctors, dissecting eyes to teach anatomy and examining people to show and detect Trachoma.
They have visited 30 places. He said:

Also, I think the only way that we are going to stop Trachoma is by having a person like Dr Jim Rogers who is devoted to his job, and who is the only Doctor who really showed and taught people what Trachoma is all about.
He got on very well with the people and they got on with him, understood what he was talking about and all said he was a very good teacher.
