That is very high praise indeed from the Aboriginal people. This is just a brief skim though this most interesting report. I point out to honourable senators that in one year a considerable milestone has been reached in the treatment of Trachoma. I think this will be of interest to those who have visited the outback and seen the large number of children, in particular, who suffer from this dreadful disease. One can see now that relief is in sight. Relief is coming from the European professional staff but the main inroads in the fight against this disease are being made by the Aboriginal people themselves. I think that is a pointer for the future. People must have faith in the Aboriginal people finding their own way in the rather difficult and stressful life that we lead these days . They have the ability for self-management. They have the ability, as instanced by this committee, to look after their well-being, to run their settlements and gradually, by degree, to bring better health to their own people throughout the outback and the Northern Territory. I commend this report to honourable senators . I seek leave to table the report.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I want to discuss the question of some of the orphans who are presently in refugee camps in Thailand and the policy of the Australian Government on bringing them to Australia. The policy is perhaps a matter to be dealt with separately, but the particular plight relates to those orphans who have been expecting to come to Australia. I understand that there are about 100 refugees in Thai camps who, for about the last year, have been identified as orphans who may come to Australia under a policy of the former Liberal Government which was carried on, initially at least , by this Government. One of the problems that arises for these young people is that, having been identified as orphans perhaps coming to Australia, they were not then eligible for consideration by other countries. They are young people who, in a sense, have already lost many years of their lives because of the circumstances under which they have lived and the time that they have spent in the camps in Thailand. Many of them, as a result of the change of policy, may now finish up going absolutely nowhere if they are not eligible to come to Australia. If there is to be a change of policy, perhaps that is something that needs to be put into effect after this particular group has been dealt with. Whether we should restrict the number of orphans to 30 is, as I said, perhaps the subject for a separate debate. It is the plight of those who have already been identified to which we need to pay attention.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a report on this matter. I would like to ask whether it is a secret document or a public document. I refer to the Lloyd report, which is in the hands of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. In some newspaper references, it is suggested that the report is secret. In one other newspaper article, the reporter said that he asked for a copy and got it. I think it is a report that ought to be made fairly widely available so that those who are interested can have the opportunity of perusing it and commenting on it.

I think it is clear that the settlement of orphans in the Australian Capital Territory area has been successful because of the extent to which community support has been given to settling young people in this area. One newspaper report indicates that in Melbourne perhaps the settlement has not been as successful. But it would be helpful, I think, if this report were made more widely available so that people could take an interest in it and present their views. I would ask the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs what discussions have taken place with the Vietnamese, Khmer and Lao communities in Australia about the recommendations set out in a report in the Canberra Times of 30 October. The report claims:

Some minors have not settled well into Australian life. Some had serious employment problems. Many might be permanent social-welfare cases. As a group they had a higher incidence of crime. Repatriation should have been more of a consideration before they had been sent to a third country such as Australia.
It may well be that all of those recommendations are right. It may well be that they apply to only certain areas, but the matter needs to be discussed.

As far as the 100 orphans are concerned, as I said, I think the matter is urgent. To be left in a refugee camp not knowing what one's future is is something that few of us could actually contemplate. If they are being brought to Australia, the arrangements for them to be properly looked after need to be thought through. The group of seven that arrived in Australian not long ago, was apparently taken to the Burnisde Homes for Children at Parramatta. The allegations in the Sydney Morning Herald were that the Burnside hostel had only a few days notice from the Department that these young people would be arriving. Very short term arrangements had to be made for house parents to be installed. It is not a particularly good or inviting welcome to Australia for this to occur . Something needs to be sorted out to make sure that the young people we bring here are properly looked after and are given every opportunity to settle in this country and not finish up in the categories to which the Lloyd report apparently refers to. I would think the Canberra experience shows that that is not necessary if the job is done properly.

Other questions that I should like to put are: How many dossiers on Khmer orphans are presently being processed by the Australian Embassy in Bangkok? Do we interview and select young adults from among the Khmer orphans who have turned 18 years and have no relatives in Australia? If the change is to be that young people over the age of 15 cannot come here, I think we need to be quite sure that we are not being very unfair indeed, at least to those who have been expecting to come this country.

Once they are here, of course, we need to see that they are given every opportunity to settle. I know that Senator Grimes, who is present in the chamber at the moment, is aware of the difficulties of getting a proper education program for young people here without their families. They are given the special benefit for a period of six weeks. They then go on to unemployment benefits, under which they are supposed to be studying for only a period of 8 hours a week . Of course, the one thing that they desperately need is education and an opportunity to learn. At the moment, many of them are on unemployment benefits and are studying full time, so the unfortunate fact is that, although they are perhaps getting the education, they are also being taught to manipulate the system from the time that they arrive. As I said, I know that Senator Grimes is aware of the situation and is looking at the prospects of working out some means whereby this can be avoided. If there is an older child who can then for the younger one get the double orphan's benefit, this assists, but of course the older child is then at a disadvantage.

A number of issues concerning young refugees need to be addressed. Those who have expected to come here should be brought here. For the future we need resettlement programs which make it possible for young refugees to fit into this country so that they do finish up like those described in the Lloyd report. I ask that the Lloyd report be made available so that it can be given full consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will refer the matters that Senator Reid has raised to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West). As she knows, I have an interest in the education and welfare of young refugees when they come to this country. I will try to keep her informed of what is going on. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the debate be now adjourned.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Sitting suspended from 1.10 to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES: EARLY RELEASE OF PRISONERS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question which is addressed to the Attorney-General relates to the transcripts which have been the subject of some questions earlier this weeks. Did any part of the six to 10 pages of transcript closely studied by him record conversations between any of the following persons: Mr Keith Harris, Mr Howard Hilton and Mr Frank Hakim?

—I do not propose to answer any questions of that kind. As the honourable senator would be well aware, it is utterly inappropriate to canvass anything that could conceivably reveal details of a Commonwealth narcotics investigation.

—My question, which is also directed to the Attorney-General, is about something that will be of interest to the Opposition. Has the Attorney- General seen the report in today's Sydney Morning Herald in which Sir Garfield Barwick is reported as saying that the dismissal by Sir John Kerr of the elected Prime Minister on 11 November 1975 was non-justiciable? Is it the case that Sir Garfield's defence of his action in advising Sir John Kerr rests wholly on this proposition of non-justiciability, that is, that the dismissal of the Government could not have been the subject of court proceedings? Have there been any developments since 1975 supporting this view, having regard to the fact that in his 1975 opinion all Sir Garfield was prepared to say was that it was unlikely that the issue would come before the High Court of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the extract in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald from the forthcoming book Sir John Did His Duty, which must rank as one of the most tendentious titles in Australian publishing history. I have seen the passage in the course of that extract in which Sir Garfield says that the question as to whether the Governor-General could lawfully withdraw a Prime Minister's commission 'was not a question which a court could decide as it did not involve a justiciable matter'. I note that that extract is in marked contradistinction to the language he employed in his letter, also quoted in the extract, of November 1975 in which the most that was said by the former Chief Justice at that stage was that it was 'unlikely' that the matter would come before the Court.

ANSWER.PARA: I further accept the honourable senator's reading of the extract that it is perfectly clear, at least on the basis of the material published so far, that Sir Garfield rests his defence for his own unprecedented action in purporting to advise the Governor-General of the day about these matters wholly on the basis of the claim that the matter in respect of which he was advising him was non- justiciable, that is to say, it would be a matter which would be not only unlikely to come before the courts and would not come before the courts but in fact could not come before the courts. It is against that background that it is fascinating to contemplate the validity of the proposition that Sir Garfield is now asserting.

The answer to the honourable senator's question is simply this: Not only are there no developments since 1975 supporting Sir Garfield's view that the matter was non-justiciable but in fact such developments as have occurred since 1975 all point in the contrary direction. Indeed, it was clear enough in 1975 itself, prior to 11 November, that that was Sir Garfield's own view of the matter to the extent that his judgment in the Petroleum and Minerals Authority case in June 1975 made it perfectly clear that he regarded the question as to the exercise of the Governor-General's power under section 57, the double dissolution provision of the Constitution, to be a matter that was in fact justiciable. But demonstrating that flexibility which made him so notorious a judge in his judicial life and which now is so evident in his post-judicial career, we see the situation of his now claiming a position which is quite at odds with that which he adopted in 1975.

Moreover, since 1975 there have been major developments in the law, which I will not stop to retail in detail-the Toohey case in 1981 and the FAI case in 1982-which suggest that matters of Executive Council decision making may well be subject to the closest scrutiny by the courts. Moreover, there is the interesting consideration that in 1977 Standing Committee D of the Constitutional Convention, of which Mr Ellicott was a member at the time, acknowledged that an adjudication by the High Court would be possible if similar events should occur in the future. The truth of the matter is that there is no foundation and never has been any foundation whatsoever for the claim being so brazenly asserted by Sir Garfield Barwick now, eight years after the event, in a futile attempt to justify what is now, and always was, a massively indefensible involvement in the process of the dismissal of the Government.

I make the further point quickly that the matter in issue as to justiciability is, of course, whether the Governor-General's power under section 64 of the Constitution to appoint and dismiss Ministers means what it says. It may be that had the matter been taken to the Court on 11 November a rather short answer would have been given. It is less clear that a short answer would be given now in the light of further legal developments. What is clear now was clear in 1975 and always has been clear, and it makes utter nonsense of what Sir Garfield Barwick is saying, that section 64 and actions taken under it by the Governor- General can indeed be the subject of scrutiny by the Court.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES: EARLY RELEASE OF PRISONERS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Will the Attorney introduce as a matter of urgency an amendment to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act to make it clear that transcripts relating to the early release of prisoners can be made available to the special commission of inquiry being established by the New South Wales Government?

—I have not yet reviewed closely the terms of that Act to satisfy myself that such an amendment is in fact necessary in order to ensure that such material as may be relevant and in the Commonwealth's possession can be given to the New South Wales Commission of inquiry. To the extent that it becomes apparent that an amendment to the Act is necessary in order to ensure that such material can be readily and quickly made available, I will certainly do my best to ensure that such an amendment is introduced and carried through the Parliament with the greatest possible dispatch.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. A number of stories have featured in Australian newspapers over the last few weeks or so featuring problems of families who need progestimil and now face large bills of $50 to $100 a week to afford this necessary food supplement for their child or children. The article seemed to suggest that this is due to a Government decision to remove progestimil and nutramigen from the pharmaceutical benefits schedule. In fact, this decision was necessitated by Bristol-Meyers Co. Pty Ltd increasing the price of these goods by 50 per cent or more and demanding that the Government follow its increase. Can the Minister say what steps are being taken to cope with this attempt to blackmail the Government? What efforts are being made to provide for those families who need these supplies? When will the new arrangements be in place?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Crowley has said, progestimil and nutramigen are Bristol-Meyers products. They are baby food substitutes. They were in fact removed from the list because of the unilateral action of Bristol-Meyers in increasing the price of these substances by something like 60 per cent. The Minister for Health and the Government believe that if any Government were to allow a firm like Bristol-Meyers to get away with this sort of behaviour it would have been quickly followed by other drug companies and by Bristol-Meyers itself by unilaterally increasing the price of drugs by very large amounts and, therefore, creating an impossible situation. It was interesting to note that Bristol-Meyers and another drug company in fact increased the price in two cases . In the first case, it increased the price of a substance necessary for some children. In the second case it increased the price of an anti-cancer drug by this large amount obviously hoping that the Government would in fact back down because of the nature of the substances and because of the outcry that was likely to occur.

ANSWER.PARA: However, the Government persisted in insisting that drug companies such as Bristol-Meyers negotiate properly with the Government. These substances were delisted. Arrangements were being made to provide that these substances should be made available at a reasonable cost. But since then the development has been that Bristol-Meyers has now cut the increase in price by about half. The Minister for Health announced a couple of days ago that these substances would now be listed. I believe that that is to be in a couple of weeks' time, but I am not sure of the date. I would hope that in future Bristol-Meyers and other drug companies would act in a responsible way and not make unilateral decisions of this type, which affect not only the people who need the substances but the Government and the taxpayer generally. Now that the companies are aware that the Government is determined to act firmly in these areas, I believe that we will have a more sensible approach in the future.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES: EARLY RELEASE OF PRISONERS

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Attorney-General. In the light of his refusal to now answer Senator Chaney's question in relation to the six to 10 pages of tape transcript, about which he has been answering questions for several weeks, and in view of the fact that the National Times of 28 October claims that Australian Federal Police transcripts actually record details of conversations between Mr Keith Harris, Mr Howard Hilton and Mr Frank Hakim, will he re-examine the material in a more thorough fashion before the Senate resumes next week and will he reconsider, first, whether he stands by the answers that he has given as to the nature of the matters in that material and, secondly, whether he will answer the question asked by Senator Chaney today?

—There are no grounds whatsoever for me either to re-examine the material in question or to reconsider any of the answers I have given. If the honourable senator regards that answer as constituting a forensic triumph on his part, let me assure him that it would be of a kind greeted with profound indifference in a magistrate's court in Woop Woop, let alone in the Parliament of this nation.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. It relates to the very high incidence of burn victims amongst the casualties of modern-day wars, such as those in Vietnam, the Middle East and the Falklands, as well as casualties from such causes as bushfires and industrial accidents. Does the Minister regard the burn treatment facilities available through the repatriation system as adequate and, if not, what steps will he take to upgrade those facilities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been concerned and alarmed for some time at the inadequate specialist facilities in Australia, both within the repatriation system and in the community generally, for the simultaneous treatment of large numbers of burn victims. At lunch time I attended a meeting of the parliamentary group on peace and disarmament. One of my colleagues in the Senate raised the very question of what would happen in the event of a nuclear blast in this country. It must be said that in the face of that possibility we, as a community , are very ill-equipped for the provision of such medical facilities as would assist us in helping victims of such a blast. Not only from a military point of view but also from a civilian point of view, recent incidents have shown and highlighted the need for the urgent improvement of such facilities. I refer in particular to the terrible Ash Wednesday bushfires that occurred earlier this year and to the many burn victims of the sinking of warships in the Falklands war.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind the Senate that during the Vietnam war Australian casualties affected by burns could not be accommodated in Vietnam or in Australia; in fact, they were flown to Texas for treatment. Clearly, therefore, there is a need for some specialised national burns centre to be established in Australia to meet any of these eventualities. Almost every year in our capital cities situations develop in which many fire fighters and civilians suffer burns during the bushfire period. As a result of this, there is an increasing recognition in the community of the problem. This is reflected in the recommendation from the Standing Committee of the State Health Ministers Conference to establish such a national burns centre. The New South Wales Government is early off the mark and is establishing a burns unit at Westmead in Sydney.

Within the repatriation system there is a small three-patient burns unit at Concord Repatriation General Hospital, the only one that is effective within the repatriation system, but it lacks the size, the aseptic environment and the specialised monitoring and treatment equipment to cope with any such major emergency. So, in recognition of this shortcoming, I have asked the Department to approach the New South Wales Health Department in order to establish the feasibility of developing a major burns unit at the Concord Repatriation General Hospital. I would envisage that that unit would be of at least 10-bed capacity, with the capacity to expand rapidly in the event of any emergency. I have done that in respect of New South Wales not because I believe that New South Wales should have any particular priority but as part of a pilot scheme that would eventually be established in the other States as well. Similarly, in Victoria, Tasmania and South Australia we have had very extreme problems of burns as the result of bushfires in recent times.

We need a national burns centre because burn care typically involves long patient stays. Such a unit would require above average staffing, including a full-time medical director and additional nursing staff. Of course, the facility would need to be community oriented and would complement the units that need to be established by the State governments. Such a burns unit in New South Wales, at Concord, would complement the unit which is to be established at Westmead. So , in answer to the honourable senator's question, this is a matter which requires an initiative by the Commonwealth Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to Senator Walsh, in two capacities, first, as Minister for Resources and Energy and, secondly, as Minister representing the Minister for Trade. Is Cabinet locked in and must approve of the two new Energy Resources of Australia contracts to sell uranium to the United States, as claimed in today's Australian Financial Review? If it is locked in, can the Minister explain why he told Senator Macklin in the Senate on 3 June that the reason for the authorisation to ERA to continue negotiations was simply 'to maintain a market presence' and that 'the authorisations do not imply approval of any uranium sales contracts that might eventuate'? Can he now confirm to Parliament that no assurances were given to ERA on the contracts being approved prior to the conclusion of the Government's policy review on uranium? Why have the contracts negotiated been given privileged status by Cabinet?

—First, the report upon which Senator Chipp based the first part of his question is by definition speculative. Even if it were not speculative, I do not believe that it would be appropriate for me to answer that question as to whether Cabinet is locked into any decision. I shall refer that matter to the Prime Minister and see whether he wants to comment on it. In respect to my statement on 3 June-

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. I take this point of order at this stage of the Minister's answer to ask you, Mr Deputy President, what privileges a senator has in this Parliament? I have asked Senator Walsh a perfectly straightforward question about a decision by Cabinet. The Minister tells me that the report is speculative and that he will not answer the question . Can you, Mr Deputy President, advise me whether I have any rights in this matter in anticipating an answer from the Minister on this most vital question?
—A senator has the right to ask questions. He has no right to demand an answer. The Minister may answer as he thinks fit.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I think it would be appropriate if I made some comment on Senator Chipp's point of order. The question of whether Cabinet or Ministers were collectively locked into a decision would, by definition, be a decision of Cabinet. There is a long-standing precedent here that Ministers are not necessarily obliged to reveal to the Senate decisions of the Cabinet on any matter. That is why I said that I would refer the question to the Prime Minister. I think he is in a special position. If he chooses to reveal a decision of Cabinet, I think he has a right to do so. But the general principle which has been followed by various governments is that not all Ministers ought to do so.
—We are entitled to be kept in the dark-is that what you are saying? It is not a very important matter; it is only selling uranium.
—What did you do when you were in Cabinet, you hypocrite?
—I am saying that I will not take it upon myself to disclose decisions which may or may not have been made in Cabinet without the authorisation of Cabinet to do so.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy President. An interjection from Senator Tate was that Senator Chipp was a hypocrite. I suggest that he withdraw the interjection.
—Senator Tate should withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw, Mr Deputy President.

—At the end of his question, Senator Chipp asked me why Cabinet made a particular decision. I do not think that I should reveal who said what in Cabinet about that or any other issue. In respect of my statement on 3 June, essentially I think Senator Chipp quoted me as saying that the fact that the Minister for Trade had issued negotiating determinations to Queensland Mines Ltd and ERA-Senator Chipp's question was asked sometime ago now; I cannot remember exactly what it was, thanks to all the interruptions we have had-it did not necessarily imply that the Government would approve any contracts which may be negotiated as a result. That still stands. The issuing of the negotiating determinations does not necessarily imply that the Government will approve any draft contract which may be put before it; the Government will make decisions on a case by case basis. To my knowledge no assurances have ever been given by the Minister for Trade to ERA or Queensland Mines at that time or at any other time that the Government would approve particular contracts. But to be certain, I would need to check with the Minister for Trade, which I will do.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr Deputy President. Am I to understand from the Minister's answer that this Government believes it is quite regular for authorisation to be given to companies to negotiate overseas to sell Australian products, but that after the contract has been negotiated the Cabinet reserves the right to renege on that contract if it so chooses?

—I am not saying that at all. Governments in a wide variety of areas for many years have refused particular producers the right to supply. The Fraser Government established a precedent with respect to Fraser Island, for example. The company there had not only negotiated contracts to sell the product , but also for some considerable time had been actively engaged in mining it. That contract was cancelled. The Minister for Trade in the previous Government, Mr Anthony, likewise refused to approve a contract which had been negotiated between Pancontinental Mining Ltd and the Central Electricity Generating Board of the United Kingdom on the ground that the pricing arrangements were not satisfactory. I do not think there is anything particularly radical or startling in the proposition that for a variety of reasons governments have declined and are likely to continue to decline to approve contracts which may have been negotiated by companies for sales of a number of commodities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I ask: Does the proposal by the Attorney-General to revise the Letters Patent for the Governor-General, as reported in the Australian on 1 November, represent, as the honourable member for Denison has claimed, 'one of a series of sinister moves to convert Australia into a Republic and against the wishes of the overwhelming majority of Australians'? In the report, the honourable member for Denison also said, among other things:

QUESTION.PARA: Last week it was God and the Queen, this week it's the Governor-General. I guess next week it will be the flag . . .
Is there any justification for these claims by the honourable member for Denison , or are they merely the comments of a man seeking publicity at any cost?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —With friends like the honourable member for Denison, the Queen of Australia and her Australian representative have little need to fear the Irish Republican Army. There is no justification at all for the comments of Mr Hodgman. They represent what has become all too familiar, just the florid and slightly unhinged frothings and ravings of a man who is totally irresponsible in his contributions to public debate.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy President.
—Order! Senator Evans, those remarks were unparliamentary. You should withdraw them.
—Which remarks?
—Your remarks about frothings and ravings were quite inappropriate.
—Would it be acceptable to withdraw the words 'slightly unhinged', Mr Deputy President?
—No, withdraw all the relevant remarks and continue your answer.

—I withdraw. The situation is this: The powers and status of the Governor-General are set forth in the Constitution and cannot be affected by anything in the letters patent or anything that may be done with respect to the letters patent. The proposed revision and updating of the letters patent does not and cannot involve any alteration of the powers or status of the Governor-General. Under section 2 of the Constitution, the Governor-General is the Queen's representative in Australia. He does not become so by virtue of anything in the letters patent. The proposed revision is designed to reflect the proper constitutional position and to remove the archaic way in which the old letters patent refer to and express the Governor-General's powers. The proposed revision will deal only with matters appropriate for inclusion in a formal document of this kind, namely, the appointment of Governor-General, the issue of dormant commissions to administrators, the clarification of the circumstances in which an administrator may undertake the administration of the government and the appointment of deputies by the Governor-General or an administrator. The revised letters patent in the present proposal will also clearly affirm the Queen's position as Queen of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: I repeat that there is simply no need for anyone to fear that the occasion will be used for any purported reduction of either the actual or conventional powers of the Governor-General; nor is there any justification for those at the other end of the political spectrum to hope that such may result from this exercise. It is a merely technical exercise, as I have said elsewhere, to remove some of the archaic mumbo-jumbo that surrounds the expression of these things. Because of the need for consultation with the Palace in this respect, it is not possible to give a precise timetable as to when this will occur, but we are aiming to have new letters patent issued as soon as possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES: EARLY RELEASE OF PRISONERS

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to his answer yesterday when he said that Federal Police telephone conversation transcripts had 'an element of ambiguity about them' in relation to whether payment of money was discussed. I ask: Can the Attorney say whether the reference or references giving rise to the alleged ambiguity occurred only in the course of a conversation or conversations with the former Minister, or were other conversations relevant?
—I do not propose to add anything further to what I said yesterday in answer to that question.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to a report in today's Australian in which it is claimed that an airline pilot, who did not wish to be named, said that he paid more than $40,000 a year in tax and that he stood to lose nearly $100,000 as a result of the Government's plan to increase tax on superannuation lump sum payments? Is it possible that these claims are accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is possible that such claims are accurate. One circumstance under which such a claim could be accurate has already been nominated by my colleague Senator Grimes. It is, however, so unlikely that it could not be accepted as being true by any reasonable person, particularly the second part of the assertion.

ANSWER.PARA: On the first point-that a pilot is allegedly paying more than $40,000 a year in income tax-that would be correct if the pilot, or anyone else, had a taxable income somewhere in excess of $80,000 or $82,000. It is certainly possible that a pilot would have a taxable income in excess of that amount; that is well within the bounds of possibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not bad for 37 hours a month.

—If all the income were derived from flying aeroplanes-which I do not think it could be, but someone in that position could well have income from other sources-as Senator Grimes points out, the rate of pay for the number of hours worked is extremely high.

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of the second figure, the liability to pay almost $100,000 in tax on a superannuation lump sum payment is not credible. It is well beyond the bounds of possibility. For that to be correct the pilot in question would have had to accrue since 1 July this year a superannuation lump sum entitlement of the order of $360,000. I understand that the superannuation schemes for domestic airline pilots are fairly generous, but I do not think they are so generous that they allow someone in a period of five months to accrue an entitlement of $360,000 or thereabouts.

However, if the pilot in question, or other pilots, are so dissatisfied-I do understand that there are surplus pilots in both the major domestic airlines- they always have open to them the option to resign their positions with either of those airlines if they believe that the conditions under which they are now employed are unacceptably harsh.

In regard to pilot's political activities in the Moreton by-election, their campaign may succeed in securing an anti-Government vote from all pilots who have incomes of $82,000 or thereabouts a year, and it may do something to secure the votes even of other people with incomes of $82,000 a year. If the claim made by one of those anonymous pilot spokesmen is correct, I should say the Opposition would be certain to get the votes of all those who accrue in a period of five months a lump sum superannuation entitlement in the vicinity of $350,000 , which would have to apply if the statement of that unnamed pilot were true.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of a delegation from the National Conference of State Legislatures of the United States, led by Representative William Passannante, President of the National Conference of State Legislatures. The delegation includes senators or representatives of the States of New York, Colorado, South Dakota, Illinois, Mississippi and Tennessee. On behalf of honourable senators I extend to all members of the delegation a warm and friendly welcome to Canberra and the Senate chamber. I trust their visit to Australia is an enjoyable and interesting one.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES: EARLY RELEASE OF PRISONERS

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Attorney-General whether he is aware of the following statement by Premier Wran in an interview with Channel 10, Sydney, reported in today's Australian and replayed on this morning's AM program:

QUESTION.PARA: I had what you might call a briefing, just like Senator Chipp.
I further ask the Attorney: Who has been briefed on the contents of these highly sensitive Australian Federal Police transcripts?

TALK.START.PARA: —To my knowledge the only politicians who have been briefed as to the contents of the transcripts in issue are Mr Beazley, the Special Minister of State, and me.
—State and Federal?
—At the Federal level.
—Not the Prime Minister?

—Not the Prime Minister, to my knowledge, no. It may be that he has been; I said to my knowledge. I do not believe so. That is the situation. I have no knowledge whatsoever of who has been briefed about what at the State level and suggest that that is a matter that might be more appropriately directed through anyone whom the honourable senator can find in the New South Wales Parliament who is prepared to canvass this matter there.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employ- ment and Industrial Relations. It refers to those community youth support scheme projects which have a large number of young unemployed Aboriginals participating in them. Can the Minister say whether more resources will be made available to CYSS officers experiencing complex problems in assisting Aboriginal youth? Has consideration been given to assessing the training needs of those officers so that they can provide more practical and effective guidance to youth with special needs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations that it has commissioned a detailed national study into ways in which CYSS projects might more effectively meet the special needs of young unemployed Aboriginals. This independent study is being undertaken by the CYSS Koorie research committee based in Sydney, which is representative of a wide range of Aboriginal organisations. The results of the study are expected later this year and are expected to include recommendations on appropriate training to assist CYSS project officers working with young Aboriginal people.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has already made available $350,000 this financial year for the training of CYSS personnel. These funds should enable any such recommendations to be put into effect. I should also point out that a number of CYSS projects operating in areas with high Aboriginal unemployment already employ Aboriginal project officers. Substantial subsidies are also available under the national employment strategy for Aboriginals to enable CYSS projects to employ additional Aboriginal staff as trainees.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES: EARLY RELEASE OF PRISONERS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. I note his earlier refusal to answer a question I asked, I think on the ground that it might touch on the question of the drug inquiry. I note his preparedness to answer, until today, questions arising from the transcripts relating to the release of prisoners. Did any part of the six to 10 pages of the transcript closely studied by him record conversations, relevant to the release of prisoners, between any of the following persons: Mr Keith Harris, Mr Howard Hilton and Mr Frank Hakim?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney can fish as much as he likes, as can his colleagues, but the position will remain that I will not add any further detail to that which I have already put on the public record as to the detailed content of the transcripts in question and as to the personnel involved. Of course it was a matter of public notoriety that at least one of those conversations did involve a Minister of the Crown, who was subsequently revealed to be Mr Rex Jackson. It was in that context that I answered questions previously with the degree of detail that I did.

ANSWER.PARA: To go any further than that, to accept the invitation of the Opposition, would be to expose me, quite properly, to a charge of total irresponsibility in putting on the public record matters which must remain in the private domain unless and until they are the subject of a proper judicial inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. It is one in the Christo Moll series. Has the Minister seen a letter to the Editor of the West Australian of 22 October signed by Mr John Gillett, the senior partner of a Perth based law firm Northmore Hale Davy and Leake? Is the Minister aware that in that letter Mr Gillett claims that the statement made to the Senate by the Minister, namely, that Northmore Hale Davy and Leake had set up the first tax evasion scheme for Christo Moll, was 'untruthful'? Is Mr Gillett's assertion accurate? Does the Minister have any more evidence of misrepresentation of a possible tax liability of shareholders and former shareholders in Westwools Holdings Ltd?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen that letter from Mr Gillett and the allegation that what I had said in the Senate was untrue. I have a number of comments to make. Firstly, Senator Chaney has placed on record officially in the Senate that Christo Moll was a client of that firm. Secondly, some laywers make a living through casuistry. Mr Gillett has used the term 'tax evasion'. Many lawyers would quibble about what is evasion and what is avoidance. That is another possibility. I recall receiving some two years ago a similar complaint from a solicitor in Melbourne called Ian Collie, who challenged the veracity of some comments I had made regarding the two State and one Territory share shuffle arranged for a number of companies formerly owned by Mr Vic Garland, now Sir Victor Garland. Mr Collie claimed that I had misrepresented the facts in the Senate. I replied to Mr Collie saying that it was not my wish to misrepresent the facts about anything and that I would be quite happy to receive from him the full and accurate version of the facts and any relevant documents. I received no response to that request. I publicly make a similar offer now to Northmore Hale Davy and Leake. If that firm would like to supply me with the documents-Mr Moll has already publicly requested it to release the documents pertaining to his affairs which are held in its files-I would quite happily retract any unjustifiable aspersions which I may have cast upon that firm, but I do not believe I have cast any. I make two further comments: Firstly, Mr Collie, to whom I referred earlier, is now facing criminal charges in relation to tax evasion; secondly, it would be very interesting to know on how many Christo Moll documents the signature of Mr Gillett may or may nor appear.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the second part of Senator Cook's question regarding the misrepresentation of facts to shareholders in Westwools Holdings Ltd, I have received some additional information from a Mr David Parker, who wrote on behalf of himself and his brother, Mr J. R. Parker. I have a letter which I will seek leave shortly to incorporate in Hansard with, I stress, the prior approval of Mr Parker. Mr Parker informed me that he and his brother were named as members of the representative classes of shareholders of Westwools Holdings Ltd. Other persons named were Denis Horgan, Mr Blakiston and Mr Hughes. With the two partners, they made the representative class of five.

Mr Parker told me in this letter that he was not a party to the circular letter sent out by Messrs Lavan and Solomon on 4 October 1983 to all shareholders in Westwools. The subject of that letter was itself highly misleading. I have no doubt that it was deliberately designed to mislead those shareholders. Mr Parker informed me that in the letter Lavan and Solomon purported to be acting for the majority of members of the representative classes, representing all shareholders of Westwools Holdings Ltd. While, strictly speaking, it could be correct, as Lavan and Solomon assert, that they were acting for the majority of members of the 'representative classes', I suggest it is highly misleading to couch a letter in those terms when, in fact, they were acting at the most for three out of five members of the 'representative classes', particularly when two members of the 'representative classes', that is the Parker brothers, had on 1 October 1983 written to Mr Hughes saying that they did not favour the circulation of a letter written on Lavan and Solomon's letterhead and that, more importantly, if such circular was to be mailed it was to be made quite clear that Mr Parker had no connection with the letter and was unaware of its contents. In the letter Mr Parker states:
Unfortunately, my wishes in this regard were ignored.
I seek leave to incorporate the letter.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
David L. Parker B Ec AASA Rona 6 Ginahgulla Road Bellevue Hill N.S.W. 2023 Australia (02) 327 4055 31st October, 1983
Senator P. A. Walsh,
Minister for Resources and Energy,
Parliament House,
Canberra 2600
Dear Senator Walsh,
WESTWOOLS HOLDINGS LIMITED
TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL, 1983
In closing the debate on the second reading of the above legislation in the Senate on Wednesday, 19th October, 1983, you are reported in Hansard (p. 1790- 1791) as saying:

''In closing, there is one important point which should also be stressed. There has been a great deal of Press publicity recently regarding the Westwools company and a scare campaign stirred up by the representative clients of Westwools. I think they are five in number. They were approached by the Australian Taxation Office. They then, appearently, circulated everybody who held shares in Westwools at the time in a way which substantially misrepresented the facts concerning this legislation. I have in front of me a letter from a person. I will not name the person concerned but-
Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle: Why not?

Senator WALSH: All right, I will. His name is Edward Henry McHugh of 54 William Road, Nedlands. He informed me that he is an age pensioner. He gave his social security number as well. He said that he is faced, so he has been informed, by Westwools with having to pay $87.63 under this legislation if it is passed. That is indicative of the degree to which the representative clients of that company have misled the shareholders of the company because, of course, if there is a liability of less than $100, irrespective of all other circumstances, nobody has to pay. Nobody has to pay a liability of less than $100. Finally, no assessments have been issued to companies which have had a lot of publicity. No assessments have been issued as yet to the shareholders in either Westwools or Metro Industries Ltd. The facts have been, at least in the case of Westwools-I do not know about Metro Industries-quite clearly substantially misrepresented to small shareholders in that company by people who are major shareholders, directors or controllers of that company for reasons which are not too difficult to identify. ''

I am one of the five 'representative class' shareholders of Westwools Holdings Limited. I was appointed to that position by the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation , Perth, without my foreknowledge or consent. I have never been a director of the company, either in fact or in law.

You should know that I was not a party to the circular letter dated 4th October , 1983, mailed to the former shareholders of Westwools Holdings Limited by Messrs. Lavan & Solomon, Solicitors, of Perth. In their letter Lavan & Solomon purported to be acting for ''the majority of members of the Representatives Classes'' representing ''all shareholders of Westwools Holdings Limited''.

On 1st October, 1983, I wrote to Mr W. J. Hughes, leader of the representatives class, that I did not favour any circular written on Lavan & Solomon's letterhead; and that more importantly, if such a circular was to be mailed out that it was made quite clear that I ''have no connection with the letter, and that I am unaware of its contents.'' Unfortunately, my wishes in this regard were ignored.

In view of these matters (which you could hardly be expected to have been aware of) I would ask you to seek an opportunity of making my position quite clear to the Senate. Mr J. R. Parker, who is in the same position as myself, would be equally appreciative of clarification as well.
Yours faithfully,
DAVID L. PARKER

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES: EARLY RELEASE OF PRISONERS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. I refer to the fact that the Attorney-General has not read 690 of the 700 pages of the transcript material which might be relevant to the resignation of Mr Jackson. I refer to his refusal today to answer questions on the material whereas he answered questions yesterday. I refer to the fact that he has refused to read the material in the transcripts to which the Opposition has referred him. I ask: Is it not a fact that the Attorney-General cannot, of his own knowledge, give the Senate any assurance about what the tapes reveal? Why does he intend to remain in ignorance? Does this not effectively amount to a cover-up by the Attorney-General.

—I both can give an assurance and have given an assurance to the Senate based on the parts of the transcripts which dealt explicitly with conversations between the relevant New South Wales Minister and other persons dealing with matters that have come into public contention. I have indicated as candidly, forthrightly and repetitively as I am able to do the circumstances of those conversations, the suspicions to which they gave rise and the course of action that the Government thought it accordingly appropriate to follow. There is literally nothing else that can or in any reasonable universe should be said in this place on this issue. Mr Deputy President, might I suggest that although there is no provision in the Standing Orders guaranteeing against boring honourable senators with tedious repetition of questions, you might care to draw to the attention of the Leader of the Opposition and those of his colleagues who are still minded to pursue this non-existent hare that there is literally nothing more that can be achieved by the tendentious and tedious course of action which they are now pursuing in this place.
—I should make it clear that the Chair has no control over questions, provided they are in order.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations seen the latest figures on industrial disputes released recently by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, which show that the number of working days lost through industrial disputes in July was 27 per cent lower than the number for July 1982? Whereas a total of 105,200 workers were involved in industrial disputes in July 1982, only 58,200 were involved in disputes in July this year. Can the Minister confirm that one of the major reasons for the sharp decline in industrial disputation is the Hawke Government's concensus approach to national economic management and its abandonment of the boots and all approach of the former discredited Fraser Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the figures to which Senator Foreman referred. In some respects they are encouraging. The Government does not wish to crow unduly about the industrial dispute situation in Australia, but it does seem clear that there has been some diminution in the level and extent of disputes in recent months. One has to be careful about these matters because often a reduction in the level of industrial disputation has been thought to have some correlation with the level of unemployment. I would simply make the point that what is encouraging about the figures to which Senator Foreman refers is the fact that in the past three months there has been a very encouraging slackening in the rate of increase in unemployment.
—Slackening?

—I apologise to Senator Macklin if he has to apply his pedagogic skills to my prose. But the fact of the matter is that the Government did earlier set about a prime task of reducing the rate of increase in unemployment in this community. That has happened and the fact that there has been a substantial--
—You promised jobs, jobs, jobs. You have not delivered.

—Senator Teague says that we promised jobs, jobs, jobs. I think he is confusing, as he often does, State and federal politics. It is true that Mr Wran at the National Economic Summit Meeting said that one of the prime purposes of the Summit was jobs, jobs, jobs. The honourable senator says we promised jobs, jobs, jobs. We did not promise jobs, jobs, jobs, in the words of Senator Teague's interjection. But if that is a matter of concern to him, I might say that the increase in employment that has taken place in the last two months is consistent with the Government's estimates and undertakings. We are very gratified about that.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Foreman's question, of course, was related to the question of industrial disputes. The point I am making is that it is encouraging to see the substantial fall in the level and extent of industrial disputation in this country at the same time as the employment situation is improving. I seek to take it no further than that. However, I think this is important and significant .

I agree, and the Government agrees, with the implication of Senator Foreman's question which is simply that the approach adopted by the Government at the National Economic Summit and in relation to general questions of economic management is far more likely to ensure that industrial disputation is kept at a lower level than the former confrontationist approach adopted by the last Government. This Government, for the first time and in spite of difficulties, has in place a coherent wages policy-something which the Opposition sadly still totally lacks-and is proceeding with a number of other consultative mechanisms, the establishment of which is designed to ensure that there is as much agreement as possible between the work force and industry in relation to changes which are taking place in this society. I think they are very important measures which are directed towards, and will have benefits in terms of, lessening industrial disputation in this country.

I simply make the point that not only are they necessary as policy mechanisms to achieve that result but also they are necessary in an environment in which industry is restructuring, where massive technological changes are taking place in industry and so on. For the first time in this country a government has set in place mechanisms which will ensure that these changes take place in a consultative environment rather than by chaos, as they have taken place in the past.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES: EARLY RELEASE OF PRISONERS

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the suddenly coy Attorney-General. I remind him of the quite short statement which he made at the end of Question Time yesterday in these terms:

QUESTION.PARA: Yesterday Senator Chaney asked me whether the communication between New South Wales Minister Mr Jackson and Mr Harris, which has achieved subsequent notoriety , was about the prospective release of prisoners. I have asked for the transcript to be checked on this particular point and I can confirm that, as I indicated yesterday was probably the case, the answer is yes. I also mention for the record that the prisoners in question were from Broken Hill, not from Bathurst as I inadvertently said in my answer.
I ask the Attorney: Why is it that he was yesterday prepared to check the transcript and provide answers on these matters whereas today he is only prepared to cover up?

TALK.START.PARA: —Simply because yesterday's question addressed matters which we had been discussing, with varying degrees of politeness in this place, for the previous two weeks, whereas the matters in respect of which the honourable senator has wanted to question me today raise new matters, new personnel, new names and new circumstances. I have indicated with absolute clarity, and I will do so again, that I do not propose to put on the public record any information of any kind whatsoever as to the content of those transcripts other than what has already been put on the public record in order to explain the propriety of the Government's actions in relation to the particular matters which have become the subject of public controversy and public notoriety. If Senator Chaney is unable to appreciate that distinction, perhaps he had better hang up his whip, too.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs seen Press reports that foreign powers and foreign organisations have tried to influence the outcome of the elections in Vanuatu? Can the Minister confirm or deny these allegations?

—I am aware that allegations have been made in the course of the Vanuatu election campaign that foreign organisations sought to interfere in the elections which were held on 2 November, just yesterday. I am advised by the Minister for Foreign Affairs that he has noted these allegations but he has no particular comment to make other than that the Australian Government would, of course, deplore any such interference in the affairs of Vanuatu should those allegations prove to be correct. We have no further knowledge which would enable us to substantiate the allegations in question. However, the Government notes that there has been no suggestion of involvement by any Australian organisation.

—Has the attention of the Leader of the Government in the Senate been drawn to a statement made on Tuesday on the program AM by the South Australian Deputy Premier, Mr Jack Wright, in which he suggested that the Minister should keep his mouth shut about penalty rates, holiday pay loadings, et cetera, and do more research and become more learned on the subject? Does the Minister intend to take the advice of his distinguished State colleague?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention was drawn to the comments made by the learned Deputy Premier of South Australia in relation to this matter. As a man of natural curiosity, I took advantage of obtaining a copy of his speech and reading it in some detail. I must say that, consequent upon reading my South Australian colleaugue's speech, I sent him a telegram in which I indicated to him that as he called in the speech for informed discussion about this matter I would be grateful if he would inform himself as to exactly what I said in the future before making public comment about it. I do not think I need take the matter any further than that. However, I have had an exchange of views, if I can put it in those terms, with the Deputy Premier of South Australia and the essence of those views is as I have just indicated.

ANSWER.PARA: I might say that in all the discussion which has taken place recently about penalty rates, I was not a contributor until Senator Peter Rae started to ask me some questions about this matter in the Senate last night. Throughout the discussion, which I suppose I initiated, I have been concerned about the generality of on-wage costs in industry in Australia. I initially made the statement that Australian on-wage costs were very little different from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average, but nonetheless they were issues which had to be addressed in determining the competitiveness of Australian industry. I have conveyed that view to a number of people, including the Deputy Premier of South Australia. I think it is a view which continually has to be discussed. The appropriate place to discuss it is between governments, State and Federal, and between unions and employers in an effort to reach the most beneficial relationship for all concerned in considering these matters. So I think it is important for Senator Jessop not to rely entirely on reports on the AM program but to look at the matter, as I advised the Deputy Premier of South Australia to do, on an informed basis.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS: ALLEGATIONS OF CORRUPTION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In light of the fact that speeches and questions concerning allegations of corruption in the Department of Foreign Affairs were carried in the departmental magazine Background under the previous Government, will the Minister give an explanation for the omission of my speech of 13 October? Will the Minister give an assurance that, in future, Background will give coverage of all parliamentary references to this issue?
—I will draw the honourable senator's question to the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, but I do not like his chances.

—Is the Minister for Industry and Commerce aware of the surreptitious transfer of import quotas for shoes from independent shoe wholesalers to the major retail chains and that the effect of this is to reduce the range of shoes available to local shoe retailers, particularly in country areas, as the number of wholesalers diminishes? Will the Minister review the quota system to prevent the sale of imported shoe quotas so that quotas not used are issued by the Department to genuine independent wholesalers or alternatively allowed to lapse thus giving a boost to the manufacture of Australian shoes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of any surreptitious transfers as the honourable senator described them. I remind Senator Evans that the quota transfer provision is an integral and important element of the seven-year textile, clothing and footwear assistance plan which is designed to provide flexibility within the quota system. I am also aware that concern has been expressed regarding quota speculation. That matter has certainly been drawn to my attention. The Department has recently taken steps to try to minimise this practice. I understand that the steps taken by the Department have been, by and large, successful. I announced on 2 June this year that there would be no changes in the basic elements of the textile, clothing and footwear sectoral plan. Because it provides for a high level of assistance to these labour intensive industries and also regular reductions in the rate of tariff protection accorded, the Government has left that plan basically in place. Unless there are significant changed circumstances we will continue to do so.

ANSWER.PARA: I point out also that various elements of the aspects of the assistance plan are regularly examined by a committee each year. The Textiles', Clothing and Footwear Advisory Committee, under the chairmanship of Mr David Elix, has just completed a round of discussions and consultations with the industry and will report to the Government in the near future. My understanding is that, in the course of those consultations, the committee received representations from footwear importers and retailers on certain features of the quota arrangements. The Chairman of the Committee will be including comments on that in his report when it is forwarded to me very shortly. That report will, as usual, be a matter for discussion by the membership of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Advisory Council at which representatives of importers, retailers, manufacturers and so on are present. It provides a useful forum for discussion of that kind.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MOUNT ISA: MOBILE OUTBACK SUPPORT TEAM

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, during Question Time, Senator Reynolds asked me a question about the Mount Isa mobile support team. I have sought the information that she required. This project was initiated during the International Year of the Child as a proposal from the isolated parents' association. It was originally a pilot project for two years under the sponsorship of the Queensland Country Women's Association. The work done by the workers in the project was so highly regarded by the community and the previous Government that the project was put on to permanent funding last September through the Office of Child Care.

QUESTION.PARA: The situation referred to by Senator Reynolds yesterday was the unexpected dismissal of the project workers, Terri Ormiston and Pat Teasdale, by the State President of the CWA, Mrs Fitzherbert. Their terms expire on 28 November next. At this stage I do not know why they have been given notice. But I have asked my Department to make full inquiries and I understand there will be a meeting next week. I have had the opportunity of meeting this team in Cloncurry. I know how highly regarded their professional work was by the community. The work of organisations like this is very important in outback and isolated areas. The Mount Isa support team seemed, to most people, to be an excellent model. It worked well with the National Mission of the Uniting Church. I personally will have some regrets as will the local committees if the problems suddenly perceived by the CWA are not ironed out. I hope to be able to get further information on this incident next week. Certainly, one would not like to see a support team like this abandoned for other than very good reasons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Last night, in my absence on the resumption of consideration in Committee of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1983-84, Senator Messner accused me of failing to demonstrate the courage of my convictions. He was referring to assets test discussions which took place during that debate. He referred in particular to statements that I had made before various Returned Services League conferences and elsewhere in which I spoke of wealthy service pensioners who had contrived their financial affairs in order to meet the income test on service pensions. It is true that I raised the misuse of welfare funds by some beneficiaries at RSL conferences and elsewhere and invited the reaction of such organisations. Senator Messner alleged that I said I would name those people who were involved and that I had subsequently reneged on this undertaking. He claimed that this proved that the assets test issue was based on misinformation on the extent of abuse of the current income test.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out to the Senate that the honourable senator was wrong on both points. I did not undertake to name the abusers; I merely stated that this was an option which was being considered in order to highlight the extent and ramifications of the abuse. I assure the Senate that the abuse is very real, widespread and a great financial burden on the community, costing my Department scores of millions of dollars per annum. I decided against naming these wealthy rip-off merchants simply because no useful purpose would be served by so doing. When the assets test is introduced they will immediately cease to receive the service pensions to which they have no moral entitlement and my naming of them would not speed this process up by a single day. However, I still keep that open as an option.

However, as the honourable senator doubts that such persons even exist, I am quite happy to provide him with the details of their financial affairs while preserving their formal anonymity. For example, there is the case of one of Australia's best known tax avoiders. His name, I assure the Senate, would be known to millions of Australians. This man was granted a service pension at the then maximum single rate of $102.90 per fortnight on 30 April 1976. I remind the Senate of the significance of 1976. His wife subsequently claimed and was granted a service pension as his spouse on 21 December 1982. Each is paid at the maximum married rate which also entitles them to full fringe benefits. The only income for which they are assessed is $3.09 per fortnight from three small savings accounts. The veteran and his wife have a 60 per cent share in an import business with gross sales for the year ending 30 June 1982 of $1,000,473.31 and a total trading profit of $426,654.22. After expenses a net profit of $159 was declared, the 60 per cent share of which was paid into a family trust.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Gietzelt, I think you are getting away from your personal explanation. You are going into a great deal of detail which is all a matter for debate. Can you confine yourself explicity to where you were misrepresented? That was the purpose for which you got leave.

—Mr Deputy President, I remind you that the honourable senator said I was not prepared to come into the Parliament and name them. He claimed: ' . . . he had all the courage of his convictions, but he failed to name them'. I am not naming them, but I am giving the details upon which I made my assertions at conferences of the Returned Service League. Among the expenses incurred by the company were $44,429.51 in travelling expenses, and about $10,000 in car leases and related costs. The veteran and his wife have arranged that they receive no salary or director's fees from the company. I ask Senator Messner simply whether he approves of the payment of a service pension to these people and other similarly financially placed persons or whether it is the policy of his party that their entitlement should not be challenged by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That, unless otherwise ordered, the hours of meeting of the Senate on Tuesday, 8 November 1983, be 2 p.m. to 6.30 p.m. and 8 p.m. to 10.30 p.m.
(2) That the sessional order relating to the adjournment of the Senate have effect at 10.30 p.m. on that day.

I think there is a uniformity of view about this motion, if not enthusiasm. I simply make the point that it has been agreed between the parties that the Senate sitting on Tuesday night will be occupied with debate in such a way that there will be no divisions or quorums. I hope that is helpful to the Senate in terms of other honourable senators seeking to fulfill functions associated with this chamber but not necessarily in it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, the Opposition will not oppose this motion but I should just clarify our position. The Opposition has not had an opportunity, as a group, to consider the specific proposal but on behalf of the Opposition, as I said, I will not be opposing it. I should make it clear that there has been no undertaking on behalf of the Opposition with respect to quorums or divisions. It would, however, be my anticipation that the Government would list for consideration a lengthy second reading debate. I understand it has in mind listing the Sex Discrimination Bill, which certainly should give no cause for divisions on Tuesday evening, given the number of interested speakers.

SPEECH.PARA: It would not be my intention to call quorums but I have no undertaking or commitment from the other members of the Opposition because it is not a matter that has been considered by them. However, again I think that many would be very interested in any event in listening to the debate on the sex discrimination legislation, and no doubt we will have a very full House for that interesting debate. I also indicate on behalf of the Opposition that our non-opposition to the proposal is also in part based on the fact that the Government chose, because of its program, not to sit on Friday and therefore we think it is appropriate to make up some additional time for debate which might otherwise have been held on that day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Deputy President, I rise to comment about the motion before the Chair. I am moved to do so by the comments just made by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) in which he informed the Senate that the Government, because of its program, had decided not to sit tomorrow. We , after all, had been expecting to sit tomorrow. It was indicated to us that we would be required to sit on the Fridays of the first and third weeks of each sitting period. Quite frankly, we had expected that the debate on the Sex Discrimination Bill would proceed tomorrow. Now we are told that the second reading debate on the Sex Discrimination Bill will probably proceed on Tuesday night. If it is the Government's program to have a second reading debate on the Sex Discrimination Bill on Tuesday, when it was scheduled to be on Friday, why did it suggest the abandonment of the expected meeting tomorrow? The Government is proposing to have a special sitting time on Tuesday night to debate the very matter we were supposed to debate tomorrow. It just does not make sense except, of course, if we think about the Moreton by-election. That would not have crossed the minds of the members of the Government, I am sure, having regard particularly to what Mr Keith Wright said about the adverse affect on the Labor vote of some of its social policies, including its attitude on the Family Law Amendment Bill and the Sex Discrimination Bill.
—Come on, Senator.

—Did he not say that? Well, I must have read it wrong then. Honourable senators will recall that the Senate sat on one Friday and dealt with the family law legislation and on another Friday, the day before the Queensland election, it dealt with the Sex Discrimination Bill. The attitude to both of those Government measures amongst ordinary people is most adverse. I ask the Senate to consider whether it is appropriate during the special meeting on Tuesday night to consider the program which the Government had scheduled for consideration tomorrow and which it, in the words of the Leader of the Opposition, had abandoned. I think the Government ought to come clean and tell us why it is doing these things to us.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Fourth Report 1983
Debate resumed from 20 October 1983, on motion by Senator Collard:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment very briefly on the tabling of the fourth report of the Commonwealth Grants Commission for 1983 on special assistance for the Northern Territory. I am sure honourable senators are aware that the Grants Commission is the independent arbitrator for assessing the financial requirements of the States and the Northern Territory. In this case the Grants Commission has concluded that the Northern Territory requires some $16.9m in addition to the tax sharing entitlement to provide government services at the same standard as the States without having to make an unreasonable revenue raising effort. It is well known that the Northern Territory is different from the States in many important respects. As a result it faces various cost disabilities which cause the costs of government to be quite a lot higher than those of the States. These include the small scale of operations, the dispersion and other features of the population such as age, sex , structure and social composition, the relative isolation from the rest of Australia and, finally, the physical and economic environment within which services are provided.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it most pleasing to see that these special circumstances have been recognised by the Grants Commission in deciding the need to top up the Territory 's tax-sharing entitlement. Given that the independent arbitrator has now reported I trust this will remove any lingering doubts that honourable senators may have about the adequacy of the Territory's funding. On Tuesday 1 November I had some comments to make when the authorising Bill for this payment was passed through the Senate. On that day I made reference to the concern that was being expressed by people of the Territory and by those in government in the Territory that the Government had seen fit to review the financial arrangements that had been made between the Fraser Federal Government and the Everingham Northern Territory Government. In the second reading debate I voiced my complaint and concern. I also answered various criticisms of the accounting procedures of the Northern Territory Government in regard to the expenditure of Federal Government funds through the Commonwealth Grants Commission. As I had completed my speech on Tuesday, I have nothing further to add to this report. I am pleased that the Grants Commission has seen fit to prop up the Territory's tax sharing entitlements along the lines of the financial formula.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1982-83
Debate resumed from 2 November 1983, on motion by Senator Harradine:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a couple of comments about this most interesting document. The matters to which I wish to refer relate to content of programs, complaints about programs and advertising, references to which are contained on pages 61, 62 and 63 of the report. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: As part of its responsibilities in regard to the determination of standards and to overseeing stations' compliance with these, the Tribunal receives comments and complaints from the public. All such representations are considered, investigated where necessary, and provided with a written response.
In all cases in which a station's compliance with the Standards may be an issue , the substance of the complaint is referred to the station for comment . . .

The report indicates an increase in the number of complaints concerning program standards and details the categories of these complaints. That is quite revealing, but I believe that one of the big problems about this matter is that there appears to be no overall surveillance of program standards by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. As you know, Mr Acting Deputy President, some time ago the broadcasting information office was starved of funds. Most people now think that there is some body somewhere, some authority, which is taking some note of programs on television and radio. That appears not to be the case. The responsibility now rests on the shoulders of the ordinary citizen to complain to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. It appears that the Tribunal does very little monitoring of program standards of its own volition. Under section 99 of the Broadcasting and Television Act, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has certain responsibilities as regards programs.
