I believe that it is incumbent upon the Tribunal and indeed incumbent upon the Government to provide sufficient funds for this sort of monitoring to occur, rather than to allow the important aspect of monitoring of television and radio programs to be left to the haphazard complaints that may come from the people. As all honourable senators know, on many occasions people think: 'What is the use of picking up the phone and complaining? What is going to be done about it?' I have heard many people express an attitude of futility in regard to this. They should not, of course. The more complaints or even positive suggestions that are made by viewers and listeners, the better. They should be encouraged to make these complaints or suggestions. It is my view, having examined the Tribunal report, that the Tribunal does not see as one of its main objectives the regular monitoring of program standards on television and radio. I believe that this is a problem that the Tribunal should look at. It should not be prepared just to take whatever complaints come to it from the public; rather it should honour, as it were, its obligations under section 99 and take some positive steps in regard to the regular monitoring of program standards.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to speak for 4 or 5 minutes on this matter, which has to do with the putting down of a statement by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) on the migration program undertaken by this Government. This Government has undertaken what I believe is a very fine program of a non-discriminatory nature. It has maintained that tradition which Australia has so proudly earned, of giving weight to family reunion and to humanitarian motives in the composition of migration to Australia. It has made smaller the category of those who can come to Australia to be part of the work force. In other words, it has set its face against what was, unfortunately a trend-namely, the use of the migration program-instead of proper work force planning and the provision of training and apprenticeships for young Australians . Too often in the past Australian employers have turned for their skilled labour to overseas countries, rather than encourage the acquisition of skills by young Australians. That being the case, I think the humanitarian aspects are further to be commended in that greater reliance has been put on refugees coming to Australia from Central and South America, the Middle East, East Timor, Indo- China and East Europe. They are people who suffer from human rights difficulties under their respective regimes. To that extent, I think the Government is to be commended.

SPEECH.PARA: The real reason I wish to speak today is to answer some of the hysterical nonsense which has been peddled around the community concerning the proposal by the Government in response to certain consultations with ethnic communities initiated by the previous Government which led to the floating of the idea-it is not a matter to which the Government is committed but it was thought it should be put on the table-that the term 'relating to the Almighty' ought to be deleted from the oath of allegiance. Indeed, it has also been suggested that swearing allegiance to the Queen of Australia should not be required of those who are being encouraged to take up citizenship in this country but that they should declare their allegiance to the democratic society of Australia. After all, Australia has a political system which guarantees the freedoms of speech, association and political activities which are so dear to us. Our political system, our mixed economy and all the things that make up Australia are what we wish migrants to give their allegiance to by taking out citizenship. The reference to God or the Queen might cause difficulty for some people and it is proposed to give consideration to the deletion of those terms.

I was shocked to see in the Tasmanian Press an attack by Bishop Newell, an Anglican bishop, on this particular proposal. He claimed that only those who tend towards atheism would not wish to take the oath with the term 'God' within it. Even less defensible, he claimed, was the deletion of reference to the Queen , which of course is an Establishment view which confuses loyalty to Australia with loyalty to the monarchy. I think that is an unfortunate comment to come from the lips of a bishop. But even more than being politically misguided, of course, his statement is theologically unsound. This is why I, as a Christian and as a senator, refused to take the oath in this chamber and took the affirmation. It is quite clear from Matthew 5:36 and 37, as Senator Macklin will know, that according to the prescription set down there one ought not to take an oath invoking some divine intervention in order to back up one's integrity, validity or strength of one's promises or undertakings. Indeed, I believe that if the bishop wishes to peddle a watered down version of the Sermon on the Mount he should say so. I for one will not allow claims that I would be an atheist cow me into taking an oath which I believe ought not to be taken.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS (NUCLEAR MATERIALS AND HARDWARE PROHIBITION) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 October 1983, on motion by Senator Chipp:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The effect of the Customs (Nuclear Materials and Hardware) Prohibition Bill 1983 would be, from the date of proclamation, to terminate the export of all uranium oxide and other nuclear products and, from the same day, to end the importation of a number of other pieces of equipment associated with the nuclear industry. At the beginning of my speech I point out that all responsible people, by definition, must be concerned about the long term dangers of nuclear waste storage and, of course, the dangers of nuclear war. Some people are very emotionally committed to what they see as particular moral views to this question. There are in my view completely legitimate differences of opinion as to whether the proper response to that concern about the dangers of nuclear waste and of war ought to be the complete withdrawal of Australia from the nuclear industry. To the best of my knowledge, even the most committed opponents of participation in the nuclear industry would not ban the use of uranium for the production of isotopes within reactors for medical purposes. Even the very strong opponents have not drawn an absolute position that uranium must not be used under any circumstances for any purpose or, indeed, that reactors should not be built and operated for that limited purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: It then comes down to a question of judgment of degree as to the purposes for which the nuclear industry could morally be used and those for which it could not. I venture to suggest that a very large majority of Australians-an overwhelming majority of Australians-would regard it as immoral to be in the nuclear industry solely for the production of bombs or for their production as a by-product of other nuclear activities. For that reason, the analogy which Senator Chipp drew in his second reading speech-the analogy of nerve gas and biological weapons-was not appropriate. He said that, of course, we would not contemplate the supply of those products. I believe he is correct in saying that . I certainly hope he is correct in saying that. I do not believe his analogy is appropriate because nuclear reactors are used for purposes which I at least, and I believe most people, would regard as being legitimate-the admittedly very limited use of them for the production of radio pharmaceuticals and, on a very much bigger scale, of course, the use of them for the production of electricity. I do not think that anyone has suggested, certainly no significant number of people has suggested, that it is immoral in any way to generate electricity. Some people believe that nuclear power should not be used to generate electricity.

While recognising the views that are held very strongly and very genuinely by many people on this issue, I think it is also necessary to address ourselves to the question of what would be the effects on the dangers of waste and war of Australia's immediate withdrawal, which this Bill seeks, from the supply of uranium. I think there would be three principal effects. First, the world price would marginally increase because a very significant source of supply would be removed from the market-place. I do not believe a price increase of the magnitude likely would in any way deter somebody who really wanted to make an atomic bomb from doing so. The second effect would be to increase the probability of those people who do want uranium-whether for what I regard as legitimate purposes such as the production of power, for immoral purposes such as the production of bombs or for whatever purpose- seeking alternative suppliers who would impose few, if any, conditions on the subsequent use to which the uranium supplied may be put. Reasonably strict conditions apply now to the supply of Australian uranium and the uses to which it may be put. The Government is currently reviewing those conditions with a view to making them more effective than they are at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those strict conditions have not prevented the construction of 50 ,000 nuclear warheads.
—Yes, but none of them has been produced with Australian uranium, other than that supplied in the early 1950s.
—How do you know that?
—Well, they have. They have in the United States.

—No, what was supplied in the early 1950s might well have been used for the production of nuclear weapons. Whilst it would be risky to assert absolutely that there is no chance that any Australian uranium could be used as the raw material for an atomic weapon, the existing safeguards and controls, which the Government intends to make more effective and believes can be made more effective, make it highly improbable that Australian uranium would ultimately be used to make an atomic weapon.

SPEECH.PARA: It can be argued that the effect of Australia's withdrawal would be a marginal increase in price, which would have little relevance to anything. But more importantly, it could be an increased probability of customers seeking supplies from countries which impose few, if any, restrictions. If that is accepted, it follows inescapably that the consequence would be to increase marginally the risk of nuclear war and the dangers of long term waste storage. That is a judgment which some people will endorse and others will reject.

I concede that, in my judgment at least, there is still a residual moral argument, and that is the personal resonsibility for one's actions either as an individual or as a member of a society. Such personal moral decisions have been made. For example, some people's conscientious beliefs prevented them, they said , from taking part in the war against Hitler, and that was accepted in Australian courts, although there could be no question but that those people's judgment of Hitler would have been in accord with the judgment of virtually all of civilised humanity. But in spite of that they made a conscientious personal decision that they should not participate, and that individual right was recognised by law in this country and in a number of others. Another case involving personal responsibility in which I believe the individual has every right to insist on not being actively involved is that in which medical staff are associated with the termination of a pregnancy. Some people believe that termination should not be allowed in any circumstances whatsoever. A very much larger group, I suspect, has a conscientious objection to actually taking part in a termination. That sort of conscientious objection is one which ought to be recognised as completely legitimate. But it is a significant extension of that sort of personal moral decision which people are entitled to make, to say that a whole society must not take a particular action because of the moral objections of some members of that society.

Senator Chipp made the point, quite correctly, that the case for the nuclear industry has sometimes been put dishonestly. Nuclear power has been presented from time to time-although less so these days-as the alternative to oil, the known supplies of which are limited. I was about to say 'severely limited', but the known supplies of oil are almost certain to be exhausted within 100 years at present rates of consumption. Whilst it is technically feasible that nuclear power could produce liquid fuels for transport, it is not an economic option at present. Therefore, those who have presented nuclear power as being an alternative to oil were, in my view, quite dishonest in doing so. The far more valid comparison as to what nuclear power is the alternative to is coal. Coal reserves, even known reserves which are economically recoverable at present, are vast in comparison with oil reserves. At present rates of consumption coal reserves would last for several centuries.

However, it ought to be recognised that there are significant environmental consequences associated with burning any hydrocarbon, any carbon-based fuel, in the quantities in which it is being burnt. There is clear and probably decisive evidence that the release of sulphur dioxide from coal burning power stations in Europe is responsible for very significant environmental damage. It was known in Japan some time ago to have been a hazard to human health. It is correct that, at a price, most of the sulphur dioxide emissions can be stopped. Measures to do that have been taken in Japan, for example. It is claimed that sulphur dioxide emissions-I am not sure that the evidence is decisive on this-coming down as acid rain are destroying the Black Forest in Germany. There is certainly widespread concern, most intense in central and northern Europe, I think, about the environmental consequences of continuing to burn the present large quantities of coal, or increasing quantities, because of the sulphur dioxide.

A longer term and less certain danger associated with continuing to release into the atmosphere as carbon dioxide the enormous amounts of carbon which were locked up in fossil fuels millions of years ago is the green-house effect or the glass-house effect; the terms seems to be optional. From inquiries I have made about this matter, it seems to me that no one can predict with any assurance of accuracy what the long term effects of the continuing release of carbon dioxide at present rates will be, except that there seems to be general consensus that its effect will be to increase mean temperatures on the planet. The effect of that, of course, obviously would be influenced by the magnitude of the increase in mean temperatures, but if there were any significant increase in mean temperatures, one would expect it to cause the polar ice-caps to recede. If that happened to the point at which the polar ice-caps melted, the areas in which most of the human race now live would probably be below sea level. Certainly most of the world's major cities would be inundated by the consequential rise in sea level.

I am not trying to be alarmist by saying that those things will happen if carbon fuels continue to be burnt or if the enormous quantities of carbon locked up in fossil fuels continue to be released by burning those fuels, but there is at least a possibility of that happening. I acknowledge also that since nuclear reactors produce additional heat and with the present technology convert a relatively small amount of that heat to usable energy, there may well be some danger of an increase in global mean temperature because of nuclear power operations. Indeed, apart from human or animal muscle power or something like that, probably the only environmentally neutral method of producing electricity is through the use of solar power. That is technically feasible. It is, however, extremely expensive. On what I believe are optimistic estimates, the cost of providing solar electricity on a continuous basis is of the order of 25 times the cost of producing electricity from coal burning stations in Australia. In some other parts of the world that figure would probably be considerably less; it may even be as low as 10.

With present technology, although it is technically feasible to provide a continuous supply of solar electricity, it cannot reasonably be disputed that it is extremely expensive. That does not mean that there are no circumstances under which the use of solar power and even solar electricity is economically feasible . Household water heaters are widely used in Australia and solar produced electricity is currently used in areas where total power demand is very low. There is a need for continuous and reliable supply of low quantity power by Telecom in remote areas when the alternative power supply would be even more expensive than solar power.

With respect to the use of coal as a source of energy, I bring up a point that I am not proposing as a policy which is being or ought to be contemplated but as an argument that could be used. A movement could develop to ban the export of Australian coal on the grounds that it was destroying the Black Forest and that there was a significant danger that the continual burning of coal will change the climate of the planet to the point that the areas in which most of the human population now lives would be inundated by sea or, at least, would be below sea level. The deserts would enlarge and so on. We really do not know; we have no reliable information on the long term effects of that. But it is conceivable that that argument could be used and that some people might come to a conscientious conclusion that coal exports should be banned for that reason.

While recognising the very genuine and strongly held views on this question, and while recognising as I said in the very beginning that all responsible people by definition must be concerned about the dangers of waste storage and war, I do not believe it is responsible for us just to say that we will impose an absolute embargo on the export of Australian uranium without having at least considered the consequences of doing so within the global nuclear industry, which is established and which will continue at some level or other regardless of whether Australia ceases to be a supplier, and also the alternatives to electricity produced from nuclear power. Only one of those alternatives, as I pointed out, can be regarded as environmentally neutral. That alternative of solar electricity produced on a continuous basis is extremely expensive. I do not believe it is responsible to come to a conclusion without at least having considered all of those other things. I am not suggesting that all the people who say that an immediate embargo ought to be applied on the export of Australian uranium have not considered those things, but I suspect that a number of them who argue that way have not adequately considered all the alternatives. I think they should do so.

In conclusion, the Government's final policy in regard to Australia's participation or non-participation in the nuclear industry is scheduled to be decided next Monday. It has been reported in the Press that a particular recommndation has come from Cabinet and that an alternative recommendation will be put to the parliamentary Labor Party meeting on Monday. I will not comment on the precision of those reports, although I think the alternative recommendation was publicly released. The recommendation of Cabinet was released to members of Caucus. If some journalists do not actually have copies of it, nevertheless, it is quite clear that they have a rather good knowledge of what is contained in it . The decision on the degree of our involvement in the industry for the immediate future is scheduled to be made on Monday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs (Nuclear Materials and Hardware Prohibition) Bill introduced by Senator Chipp is a Bill seeking to stop the nuclear industry. In recent weeks we have had circulated within the parliamentary precincts a number of documents. One of the arguments in those documents concerns the obligations that Australia has to the Third World and to other countries. Senator Walsh today raised again that issue. It is the issue which I wish to concentrate upon in my speech on this Bill. Senator Mason will be speaking somewhat later in the debate and Senator Jack Evans also will probably take up other areas of this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposition I wish to put initially is that nuclear power is not economically or logistically attractive. It is not necessary for energy supply, nor is it commercially sustainable. Nuclear power has, as Senator Chipp said, been promoted often to replace oil. The replacement of oil is undoubtedly an urgent and necessary task. Unfortunately, the discussion in relation to energy tends to be a very simplistic one. Nuclear power cannot be a timely or significant substitute for the vast bulk of energy use in the world. It is the wrong kind of energy; it is too slow to construct; and it is prohibitively expensive.

The energy problem is spoken of as though there were only one problem and one sort of energy. Energy is spoken of in this chamber on many occasions as though it were any type, from any source, at any cost. Nuclear power is not a source of energy in the general sense. It is a source of energy for electricity generation . The high cost of nuclear power today limits its conceivable economic role to the base load functions of electricity only, that is to those functions which only electricity itself is able to provide. The base load function is extremely important in getting any economic argument going about nuclear power. The electrically specified functions constitute between 4 and 8 per cent of total delivered energy needs in the world. Even if nuclear power produced all the world's electricity, it would provide only 9.8 per cent of total energy needs. But as it is, the electricity generation contribution that is made by nuclear power is of the world order of roughly 10 per cent. Nuclear power, therefore, will never be able to solve the oil crisis.

Oil is used around the world in vehicles, heat generation for both domestic and industrial purposes and for providing petrochemical feed stocks. The world has long term difficulties in relation to this and certainly that fact cannot be avoided. However, it is absurd to suggest that electricity will be able to replace 90 per cent of the world's oil consumption. The low rate at which nuclear power already provides electricity makes it even more absurd to suggest that nuclear power will be able to do that. As an example, had the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries been able in 1975-that was the year of the oil crisis, as honourable senators would remember-to replace overnight their electrical generation with nuclear power, their total oil consumption would have dropped in the order of only 12 per cent. This example also tends to exaggerate the possibility of the displacement of oil since nuclear power stations involve a 10 to 15 year lead time. I shall return to the cost of nuclear power stations shortly.

I turn to the example of Japan, which has dedicated itself to the production of a very large proportion of its electricity by nuclear power. If Japan is to meet half its projected energy needs by the year 2000 with the generation of nuclear power it will need to order a new nuclear power station every 20 days, which is an absolute absurdity. It would also cost $US500 billion at current prices to achieve that, which is also an absurdity. However, if it did that ordering and spent that amount of money its fossil fuel imports would still increase by over 70 per cent. So let us get into some perspective what it is we are talking about when we say that nuclear power will solve all the energy needs of the Third World.

Let us look at some of the current costings of nuclear power. For this example I will have to use United States figures, basically because only the United States publicly provides economic statistics which allow analysis. I think it is a reasonable country to take as an example since it was the home of nuclear technology and it also has the largest number of nuclear power stations of any country. Forty-three per cent of nuclear power generation takes place in the United States. I have shown to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) a table on United States nuclear reactor costs in October 1983 figures. I seek leave to have that table incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The table reads as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —The costing in the table is on a per kilowatt basis. I make it very clear that over 100 variables must be considered when trying to make some estimate of electrical generation. It is very difficult getting a lever on an adequate costing basis for various electrical generation procedures. However, this particular costing has been done on a very conservative basis. For example, in a kilowatt year only $68 is included for decommissioning, which is an excessively low figure on the decommissioning costs now becoming available in the United States. The cost for electricity delivered to the consumer according to these figures is 12c a kilowatt hour. Of course the prices vary in the United States. The lowest cost I have been able to discover is 7c a kilowatt hour and that ranges up to 20c a kilowatt hour. The Australian average cost for electricity generation is between 1.2c and 6.9c a kilowatt hour. So there is a considerable difference and certainly, in terms of cost, Australia would not be looking at this alternative, although certainly nobody has suggested that we do. Later on I will show that if Third World countries are to be able to use nuclear power remarkable economies of scale will need to be instituted.

SPEECH.PARA: To comprehend the situation and get it in perspective in terms of oil costing, the current cost of nuclear power generation would be equivalent to buying a barrel of oil at $US191 per barrel. That is the level that we are talking about on current United States generation costs. Of course there have been astronomical additions to power generation budgets in the United States. More funds become available each day to investigate the problems that the public utilities in the United States have with their nuclear power stations. Essentially, then, the judgment to be made on the operations in the United States is that it simply had a very bad tack of market forces. No nuclear power stations have been ordered in the United States since 1978; all orders since 1974 have been cancelled. The number of units to be commissioned in the United States is shown in a table that I have circulated to the Minister and to the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney). I seek leave to have that table also incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-
The number of units to be commissioned in the U.S. is as follows:

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, do you have figures for conventional plants over the same period?
—Not at the moment.
—Do you have any coal-fired ones that were cancelled and not built at the same time, because of recession?

—I am trying to develop an argument. I will come to that at a later stage. So we have increased costings for nuclear power stations. Around the world 38 reactors are due for completion from 1990 onwards. Twenty-eight of these have been deferred indefinitely which, of course, means that they could be completed at any time or could be cancelled. Only 10 reactors are actually planned to be completed after 1990. The Nuclear Engineering International of May this year-which is a very pro-nuclear journal of engineering items-contains an article entitled 'Extensive construction activity masks the lack of new orders' which discusses the whole area in a fairly exhaustive way.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some of the operations in the United States. For example, the Washington Public Power Supply System started five reactor systems in 1972 at a cost of $4 billion. In 1982 this cost had exploded to $28 billion and, of course , the utility has gone bankrupt. Time magazine put it in the following way: They promised power without cost and they delivered cost without power.

The Zimmer nuclear power plant's projected cost in 1969 was $240m and it is now projected to be completed in 1987 at a cost of $3.1 billion. The Clinton nuclear power plant's projected cost in 1976 was $429m and it is now projected not to be completed until 1986 at a cost of $2.8 billion. The South Texas nuclear plant's projected cost in 1976 was $1 billion and it is now projected to be completed in 1987 at a cost of $5.5 billion. The Diablo 2 plant's projected cost in 1970 was $240m and it is now projected to be completed in 1985 at a cost of $4 billion. In other words, the problems that confront the nuclear industry in the United States are very real. I think we have to consider-if we are to look at the suggestion of exporting nuclear technology to Third World countries as a way of overcoming our energy problems-some of the real, hard facts. For example, I quote from a number of Wall Street specialists. First of all, Lewis Pearl of National Economic Research Associates said:

If I were a utility executive today either with a nuclear plant a short distance underway or with one I hadn't started building, I'd get out of it and never build another. Because I think the risks to your stockholders are just intolerable.
The Washington Analysis Corporation stated:

WAC estimates the overall prospects for the domestic nuclear industry as highly unfavourable. Longer-term prospects continue to be clouded by severe economic uncertainties resulting from long construction lead-times, local political opposition, unfavourable utility rate structures, inability to compete in foreign markets and a failure to resolve the radioactive waste problem.
Saunders Miller, an investment banker, said:
(to rely on nuclear energy) will constitute economic lunacy on a scale unparalled in recorded history.

In other words, if one intends to put money into something in the United States, the advice of the best people is that they should certainly not put it into nuclear power. It is important that we look at the position to get some type of perspective on what it is we are talking about. If one looks at the current United States supply capacity in terms of electrical generation-the latest information that I have been able to find regarding the peak load day was for 1980-one will see that the excess electricity supply was 35 per cent over demand . If one allows a 15 per cent over-demand as a prudent level, in this case one would have an over-capacity somewhat in excess of twice the nuclear power generation capacity of the United States. Let us compare this situation with the Australian situation. Let us consider New South Wales which has the largest grid system in this country. Total energy supplies in the 1981-82 peak demand period were 33 per cent over-capacity in that grid. So we have a comparable basis, as most developed countries do, in terms of our over-capacity at the current time.

One should look at the percentage sourcing of total energy supplies in the United States. It is useful to get some idea of where the nuclear power generation fits in. If one looks at the figures which are supplied by the various energy utilities in the United States, one comes up with the following figures: Oil, 47 per cent; natural gas, 26 per cent; coal, 19 per cent; hydro- electricity, 4 per cent; and nuclear power, 3 per cent. Let me put that 3 per cent into some perspective. Wood burning in homes and factories in the United States has taken on a fair amount of prominence in the last five years, without any government subsidy or encouragement. Wood burning now delivers twice as much energy as nuclear power in the United States. That is the order of energy sourcing about which we are talking. We are looking at an enormous cost in a very small industry. Nuclear power is put forward as necessary for the health and well-being of the world's vast majority who suffer from savage living conditions. This has been advanced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and a number of other people.

In relation to the arguments which I have just mentioned, the contribution of nuclear power must be surely almost non-existent. The International Atomic Energy Agency has projected that by 1990 nuclear power will provide 5 per cent of the underdeveloped world's electricity supply. This means that 95 per cent of its energy sources will come from sources other than nuclear power. That is the type of projection that IAEA has made. When we talk about nuclear power as being the support for the Third World and its energy problems we are not talking in realities. We are not talking about the hard world of energy sources. I think that is extremely important. We have given enough cold hands to the Third World without leading it up the garden path on yet another one.

The less developed countries which have nuclear power at present are Argentina, Brazil, China, Egypt, Mexico, India, South Korea and Taiwan. Those nations are far from being the poorest of the world's poor. Even in those nations nuclear power will not aid the poor of the peasants. They live either in slums or in desperate communities. Nuclear power will contribute to the already massive social inequalities in those countries. While the nuclear power station may look romantic silhouetted against the slums, it certainly will not do anything for those countries in terms of their desperate foreign aid debts and fragile economies. If we look at that situation we must be very careful of what it is that we are doing in terms of technology transfer in a North-South dialogue.

If we are to look at the possibilities of nuclear power and at the possibility of sourcing power to Third World countries, what are the types of options? The substitutes-if we are not going to build a nuclear power station-are neither oil -fired nor coal-fired power stations. In most countries it does not matter in the least what kind of new power station can send out the cheapest electricity, because none of them can remotely compete in either cost or speed with the real alternatives. The cheapest energy generation alternatives in this order are: Eliminating waste of electricity; replacing, with efficient building improvements and cost-effective solar systems, the electricity now used for low temperature heating and cooling; making motors, lights, appliances, smelters, et cetera, cost efficient; industrial coal generation, combining heat and power stations; low temperature heat engines operating from industrial waste heat and from solar ponds; modern wind machines; filling empty turbine bays in existing dams; and small scale hydro-electrical generation. To know what can be saved is important. Energy efficiency projects can save 75 per cent of electricity demand without spending anything more than 1.5c a kilowatt hour saved. This cost is about only a quarter of the average delivered cost of electricity. It is less than the running cost alone of any thermal power station, including a nuclear power station. That is certainly the area to look at. In the United States, that has been the area in which gains have been made. That is what we need to look at regarding the rest of the world. The United States alone has saved 2.5 billion barrels of oil a day, which is equivalent to 30 per cent of total United States oil imports, simply by plugging holes in typical dwellings; in other words, retrofitting of buildings. These types of savings are astronomical. Their cost is very low.

To return to a point which was raised by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh), in terms of other types of alternatives which are possible and may come onstream, I refer to a speech made some time ago by Senator Sir John Carrick in which he talked about solar energy as being primitive. The largest private power utility in the world is in California. A report prepared by Lawrence Livermore, of the Lawrence Livermore laboratory, which is the major nuclear weapons research centre in the United States, says:

Harnessed renewable energy resources could make California (United States' most energy intensive state) fully energy self-sufficient by the year 2025, while doubling its population and tripling its state economy.

I think we must be careful when we make statements about that current state of research. I am not suggesting that solar energy can take over. That is an absurdity. But what we have to look at is the correct mix of energy sources. If we do not let ideological commitments get in the way, we can start looking at a range of energy sources and try to get the ones which are most appropriate for Third World countries or our own country.

Essentially, energy is going to be the problem of the future, and this problem is not going to be solved by nuclear means. Let me give some examples. In Sacremento, California, a biomass conversion plant, fuelled by 20,000 tonnes a year of tree, lawn and grass clippings, is now currently being installed. This plant, costing $3.5m will produce 16 megawatts of heat, enough to replace 50 per cent of the natural gas currently used for heating government buildings. A food company, Diamond Sunsweet, is burning hundreds of tonnes of its walnut shells in a cogeneration plant to produce 4.5 megawatts. This company's investment will be paid back in three years. The cogeneration of energy is the single largest source currently available to the world which is hardly being tapped anywhere, certainly in the Western world. Cogeneration is readily available now without any new developments in technology and at very little investment cost.

The Boeing aircraft company is now building a cogeneration plant to burn various waste products from its plants. A wind energy project to be completed shortly will provide electricity to 450,000 San Francisco residents at a cost of 3.5c per kilowatt hour, which compares more than favourably with our coal burning plants in Australia. Senator Sir John Carrick refers to photovoltaic solar cells as primitive energy. It is very interesting to note that the Sanyo Corporation is currently investing $50m in a plant for the commercial production of photovoltaic solar cells in the United States alone, apart from the plants which it is already operating in Japan. One does not very often find such hard- headed companies undertaking such operations unless they think they are going to get some kind of return.

There have been problems, and there will continue to be problems, in this area. We have not even scratched the surface when we compare the money which has been put into nuclear research and the money that has been put into this area. Research in this field in Australia has commenced and is proceeding well. Solar dishes, solar generating stations and solar ponds, of course, are the types of things which have been probably to the fore in terms of most of the research which is currently under way. A variety of these are applicable in certain places. However, they are not applicable in all places and I do not wish to give that impression. My argument is that a mixture of energy sources will solve the energy problems of the future. If we believe and argue that nuclear power is absolutely and totally essential for Third World countries to solve their energy problems, we are in fact suggesting a course of action which not even the most highly industrialised and richest country is any longer able to afford. We should use a little bit of economic sense if we are to talk about the energy needs of Third World countries. Satisfying those needs certainly does not involve going down this line. I believe that we in Australia have a moral obligation which has been expressed often. I, for one, support very strongly the North-South dialogue. We have an obligation to transfer and use technologies which will be compatible and useful for those countries. There should be some prospect for those countries at some stage in the future to come out of their grinding poverty. They should not be made hostage to the rich countries in the West.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a private member's Bill brought forward by Senator Chipp. It is a piece of legislation which, in the words of Senator Chipp in his second reading speech , proposes an absolute prohibition on the export of uranium, an absolute prohibition on the import of hardware necessary for nuclear power stations and uranium enrichment plants and an absolute prohibition on the import of spent nuclear fuel rods. The debate is one which, although it has started only today, is, I suppose, timely because the issue of Australia's place in the world nuclear business is very much in the forefront of Australian politics.

SPEECH.PARA: The policy of the Australian Government is a policy which has been under very active debate within the Government. We have been told by Senator Walsh, the relevant Minister here today, that he anticipates that important decisions as to what Australia's place in that industry will be in the future will be made in the Caucus next Monday. So it is a very timely debate. If Senator Walsh's contribution to the debate is a sample of what is to follow, Senator Chipp may well feel pleased that he has brought the Bill forward whatever the result might be in terms of Senate support for or opposition to his Bill. I think most, if not all, honourable senators would agree that Senator Walsh put in a quiet and considered way many of the points of view which are held by senators from all around the chamber. I thought it was a very helpful and very good contribution to this very important debate. I express the hope that all members of the Labor Party will have the opportunity to consider the points made by Senator Walsh. I express the hope that within the councils of the Party, which are, of course, private, there would be the same very careful approach and careful attempt to weigh up the arguments which apply. Perhaps I praise Senator Walsh's speech because I disagreed with so little of it. It is always easier, of course, to praise a speech with which one agrees. I think that it was a very useful contribution to what is in fact a very difficult debate.

I wish to echo some of the points which he made because I think they bear repeating. In particular, in addressing the Bill which has been brought forward by Senator Chipp and which the Opposition intends to oppose, I wish to say that all Australians and I think all members of this Parliament would certainly regard our involvement in the nuclear industry as a matter for concern and care. This is not a matter which should be treated lightly. Senator Chipp very properly raised the concern which we all have about the threat of a nuclear war and the appropriate concerns we should have about effective waste disposal and the non-proliferation of weapons. All of those issues make this a matter for careful consideration.

When in fact the previous Government, after very long consideration, decided to affirm a policy for the mining and export of Australian uranium, it did so only after it considered a range of policies which covered, in its view, the concerns which had been expressed by many people in the community. I refer honourable senators to Parliamentary Paper No. 198/77, which contains statements that were put down in August of 1977 by the then Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister and four other Ministers in regard to their various areas of concern. One finds papers on nuclear safeguards, the health and safety aspects of nuclear power generation, the mining and milling and safety of that process, the impact on the Aboriginal society, the impact on the Kakadu National Park and a history of uranium development in Australia. Various questions were raised and answers were provided.

I mention that because at that stage I think there was a most serious attempt to come to grips with all of the issues which are raised in this debate and to lay down clear rules which would show that Australia would participate in this trade at the highest levels of responsibility. Time would not permit me to refer to all those papers. But I will quickly refer to the paper on nuclear safeguards . One finds in that paper very clear commitments that there would be a careful selection of countries to which uranium exports would be permitted. In the case of non-nuclear weapon states, sales would be made only to countries which are parties to the Non-Proliferation Treaty. Further, in the case of even those states the prior conclusion by bilateral agreements would be required which would lay down the conditions on which Australia was prepared to provide uranium . That would include fall-back safeguards which would guarantee that Australian uranium would not find its way into the world arms trade. Where we were to export to nuclear weapon states-there are a limited number of those-there was to be a condition of agreement with those states, an assurance, that nuclear material supplied for peaceful purposes would not be diverted to military or explosive purposes.

The concern which was referred to by Senator Walsh was a concern which was shared by the previous Government. I believe that the very careful approach to the making of our policy in that area, back in the early years of the life of the Fraser Government, and the very careful administration of that policy indicate the serious way with which this was dealt. I adopt many of the points which were made by Senator Walsh about the effect of Australian withdrawal. Otherwise, I do not wish to comment in detail on what he said. I simply commend it.

In the interests of a genuine debate in this place, I make some comments on the matters which were addressed by Senator Macklin in his contribution. Of course, he confined himself to a particular aspect and indicated that Senator Chipp dealt with different aspects and that Senator Mason, his colleague, would deal with others. But I think that a great deal of what Senator Macklin said does not really go to the issue which the Government of Australia faces and which, to some extent, the Senate faces in having to deal with this Bill. The really central theme to Senator Macklin's speech was that it was not economically or logistically attractive to pursue the use of nuclear power for the generation of electricity. He produced a great number of facts and figures, referred to various authorities and incorporated a certain amount of material into Hansard about nuclear reactor costs. Now I, in the course of that I have to say, will quote a few authorities which suggest that, in comparative terms, nuclear power plants represent a better prospect and a more economically attractive prospect than other forms of power generation. But, to an extent, what Senator Macklin said and what I might have to say in rebuttal or in putting forward an alternative view does not really matter very much because, if Senator Macklin is correct and if all the smart advice is that if one wants to generate electricity one does not do it using nuclear power, really this legislation is almost unnecessary. We simply will not get a developing nuclear industry if the economics are wrong. If the power stations are not going to be built, of course, there will not be customers for the nuclear power stations and they simply will not require fuel.

Whilst I found a lot of what Senator Macklin said interesting, I do not believe that it really helps us very much. Indeed, if he is correct, I think his concern about the Bill and, indeed, his Party's concern about this Bill, is somewhat misplaced because we all know uranium is available for those who wish to make weapons. The real question we are facing here is the potential for Australia to be part of the supply system for the peaceful use of nuclear energy for electricity generation.

There was a lot in what Senator Macklin said with which I would not disagree. I do not think anyone in this chamber would disagree with it. No one would argue that it is not highly desirable that we should gain as much energy as possible by conservation. But that is one of the areas where there have been signal successes since the various oil shocks. In fact, conservation measures have succeeded beyond the expectations of those who have pushed their importance. We all know of the massive shift from the use of fuel oil in favour of coal. We all know that the actual use of energy has been made much more efficient. Only today I spoke with someone who told me of the extraordinary changes in the energy efficiency of electric motors, refrigerators, air-conditioners and various other things. The sorts of measures which Senator Macklin addressed were measures addressed by the previous Government in a program sense. Senator Sir John Carrick could, no doubt, give chapter and verse the sorts of measures he promoted to encourage energy conservation.

The reality is that since the oil shocks we do have a much more energy conscious world and we do have a world which is conserving energy. Measures which are being advocated by Senator Macklin are certainly being pursued by governments and, indeed, by private industry which sees the advantage in it. So I do not join issue with Senator Macklin at all in some of those areas where he suggested that the effect of an economical use of energy is one part of meeting the world's energy problems. That is a view which was stoutly promoted by the previous Government and which is, in fact, being put into effect around the world.

I also wish to express some respect for Senator Chipp's stance with respect to this Bill. I disagree with it, but I think it has certainly strong elements of consistency and principle in it. Whilst I disagree with it, I think the Bill arises from the form of conscientious belief which was described by Senator Walsh, that there is certainly in Senator Chipp and, perhaps, in the rest of his Party for all I know, a burning, strong sense that whatever the economics, whatever the safeguards and all the rest, it is not right and cannot be tolerated.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is much more rational than that.

—I do not mean to be disparaging. I think it is a firmly held belief. I believe there are sound arguments why that belief should not be held by all and, indeed, as to why it is not held by me. I contrast that very consistent view which has been adopted by the Australian Democrats with what I think has been a much more inconsistent view on the part of the present Government and on the part of the Australian Labor Party. I do not wish to labour that but I think the illogicalities and the inconsistencies within the existing policies of the Labor Party have been acknowledged by Senator Walsh and others in the debates over recent weeks. One can only hope that those inconsistencies will be removed. The sort of inconsistency to which I refer is a readiness to approve the mining and export of uranium from a mine which has been described by the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as the daddy of them all-that is, of course, Roxby Downs-with a preparedness on a mixture of principles to block off the mining and export of uranium from very much smaller mines. I see no logic and no principle in that stance. I see nothing conscientious in that stance. All I see is a confusion which is borne of an attempt to reconcile what are ultimately irreconcilable views within the present Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I make clear why it is that the Opposition is opposed to Senator Chipp's Bill. It is opposed first because if the Bill were to become law it would take Australia out of the chain which is part of the peaceful use of nuclear power and it would remove in that process not merely employment and jobs-I do not wish to labour the economic aspects of the matter-it would also remove our ability to influence the world nuclear trade. We believe that our influence on that trade is good. We believe that the influence that we bring to bear is one which helps to avoid some of the dangers and difficulties which are the concern of Senator Chipp. We think that if Australia became a non-participant its moral lead which is being sought here would be much outweighed by the loss of Australia's demands that the trade be carried on in a responsible and sober manner. I think also the Bill is to be opposed because it underrates the importance of the peaceful use of nuclear power, and both Senator Chipp and Senator Macklin have tended to talk down the significance of nuclear power on a global basis.

I would like a little later to refer to the significance of nuclear power to some particular countries and suggest that it would be a matter of some moment to them if the access to uranium were to be removed. We also oppose the Bill because in a sense it would not achieve any of its idealistic objectives. We do not believe, in fact we know, that it would not prevent supply from other sources-it would not prevent supply from South Africa and it would not prevent supply from Canada. Indeed those countries would be prepared to supply on terms which would be I think less stringent than those imposed by Australia. There are economic elements to our opposition. We believe that were this Bill to become law it would simply export Australian jobs to the countries I have mentioned and to other countries which are able to mine and export uranium. We further believe that it would further damage our already bruised reputation as a reliable supplier of commodities. That reputation has been bruised partly by Government actions in the past but also, of course, by the very bad industrial record which we have. If we, as a country with a major interest in foreign trade, move to the point where with political changes of wind suppliers of commodities which have been contracted for are cut off, we believe that the whole of our export trade must suffer in comparison with those of our competitors. We do not believe that the Bill will advance the cause of nuclear disarmament and indeed we believe it may do the reverse, again, by removing Australia's benign-we believe-influence in that area. So we see no positive features in the Bill which would advance the cause of nuclear disarmament. Finally, we believe that to pass this Bill and to act on it would be in breach of our treaty obligations under the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons.

I mentioned a few moments ago that Senator Chipp had referred in his second reading speech to the relative unimportance of nuclear energy as a substitute for oil. Quite clearly for many of the reasons that we need energy, oil is the premium fuel, in particular for transport purposes. That is the use on which it should be concentrated. Over the last few years there has been an important move towards both substitution and conservation, but there remains a key role in electricity for uranium. If I can just remind the Senate, there are many countries which by last year were getting a very significant part of their electricity from nuclear power. Of course the Scandinavian countries led. Finland had over 40 per cent of its power coming from nuclear generation; Sweden just under 40 per cent; France just under 40 per cent, which of course is a figure which is rising very rapidly; Switzerland 28 per cent; Belgium 27 per cent; Bulgaria 25 per cent; Germany over 20 per cent; Japan over 20 per cent; and the United Kingdom 15 per cent. So in fact nuclear power is an important power source for many countries. It is fashionable of course to suggest that the industry is in decline, and figures were cited by Senator Macklin to that effect . I quote here from a source which has an interest. Energy Resources of Australia Ltd recently published a report in which it indicated:

In 1982, world generation of electricity from nuclear fuel grew by 9.3%, compared with an increase of 1.9% in that from coal. In the same period, the proportion of electricity generated from oil by power utilities actually fell by 3% and there was . . . a decline of 1.2% in electricity generated by combustion of natural gas.
A little later it points out:
The forecast by some industry observers that by the end of 1983 world consumption of uranium for power generation will exceed production for the first time in many years.
Last year throughout the world 21 nuclear power plants were commissioned, six of them in the United States. Five new orders were placed outside the US, all for pressurised water reactors.

One can point to a decline in the number of plants being commissioned and the cancellations, but as was taken up by interjection both by me and Senator Sir John Carrick, the reality is that we have been in a period of declining energy usage because of the world recession and because of energy conservation. So one has a situation in which new power stations have simply not been coming on stream and where there have been substantial changes in the predicted demands for energy. So it simply is not possible to look at the actual number of nuclear stations in isolation and say that from that one can assume that the industry is one which is in decline. Indeed, it does appear that notwithtanding the figures quoted by Senator Macklin many see nuclear power as being the most economic source of power when power requirements start to increase again. A study by the Organisation of Economic Co-operation and Development which was made in 1982- this was published by the International Atomic Energy Agency and the Nuclear Energy Agency- commented:

There are economic reasons in most OECD countries why nuclear would be the preferred course to follow when new electrical base load capacity is installed. Nuclear power is invariably much less costly than oil and in many situations is considerably cheaper than coal as a means of producing electricity. Although analysis of safety and environmental effects are uncertain they generally favour nuclear power plants and their associated fuel cycle over plants using fossil fuels.

So the reality is that for many countries it is likely that the route will be the increased use of nuclear power for the generation of electricity, and the likelihood is that there will be a continuing and expanding demand for nuclear fuels. The other matters which I want to touch on, Mr Acting Deputy President, are the sorts of issues which concern those who are opposed to the nuclear industry. I refer to waste management and non-proliferation. I will not have time to deal with those in any detail but I do want to refer during my remarks to a very recent statement which was laid down by Australia at the International Atomic Energy Agency general conference in October of this year. I will be quoting from that because it represents-I commend it to the attention of honourable senators-precisely the sort of constructive contribution that Australia is able to make to international activities in the nuclear field which contributed to removing the sorts of doubts and difficulties which are the concern of Senator Chipp. With respect to waste management I will quote this official statement which was made on behalf of the Australian Government at that conference in October:

The Seattle Conference, as the Director General has noted, concluded on an optimistic note. It reaffirmed that no further technological breakthroughs were required for the establishment of safe waste management systems. It concluded that fully feasible concepts have been developed for the disposal of high level waste, although further work needed to be performed to establish internationally accepted criteria for safe disposal.

There are many lessons still to be learned, and there is a particular need for highly complex scientific developments which are closely linked to the welfare, health and environmental protection of mankind to be made convicing and comprehensible to the public. International collaboration in the field of waste management, as the Seattle Conference demonstrated, will play an increasingly important part in the safe development of the peaceful use of nuclear energy. My Government would welcome urgent action by the Agency to follow up that Conference.

I am quoting there a source from the present Government; a submission made to an international energy meeting which is devoted to ensuring that this trade is conducted in a safe and reasonable manner. As far as safeguards are concerned I again quote from that report:

In its Annual Report for 1982, the Agency was again able to conclude that the level of assurance associated with its implementation of safeguards had continued to improve. The assurance which these findings provide is at the heart of the IAEA safeguards system and constitutes an essential political benefit to all Member States and the international community at large. We welcome the fact that the Agency is again able to perform effective verification in the two cases where it was unable previously to conclude that nuclear material under safeguards remained in peaceful nuclear activities, or was otherwise adequately accounted for.

I quote that merely to indicate the sorts of activities in which Australia is involved and the sort of attitude which has been brought forward. I mentioned the fact that this Bill, if passed, would amount to a breach of our obligations under the Non-Proliferation Treaty. I would have thought that in general our adherence to that Treaty would be a matter which would have been welcomed by the Australian Democrats. The nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty is a treaty which seeks to ensure-again I am referring to a government document, the inter- departmental committee report which the Government produced and circulated to its members as a guide in these matters. The present Government and its bureaucrats describe the treaty-

TALK.START.PARA: —But 50,000 nuclear weapons have been created during the existence of that treaty. It has not stopped that.

—The point is that an active international program is being pursued now to prevent the further proliferation of nuclear weapons among non- nuclear weapons states and active measures are being pursued by the nuclear weapons states to try to reach agreement on ways of reducing nuclear armaments. Will Australia be a party to that or not? I point our that the treaty seeks to ensure that peaceful uses of nuclear energy are developed so as not to contribute in any way to the proliferation of nuclear weapons and that nuclear weapons presently existing will be reduced and eventually discarded.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that Australians have a very great opportunity to participate in this industry in a way which will improve the conditions under which the world nuclear industry is conducted. There is a chance for us to be positively involved in an industry which is contributing to the essential energy requirements of the world. We can, I believe, consistent with safe practices, economically improve the position of our country by continuing to develop a resource in which we are rich and which the rest of the world wants. I believe that there is a whole series of reasons why the Senate must vote against this Bill and I believe, quite to the contrary of what is believed by Senator Chipp, that it is in the positive interests of the world that we should oppose this legislation and continue to pursue the peaceful use of nuclear energy and the objectives of the Non-Proliferation Treaty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I rise to support this Bill which has the full support of the five Australian Democrat senators and the Australian Democrat membership generally. I believe the majority of the Australian people would also like to see a Bill like this pass the Senate. To introduce the topic to which I particularly want to look and which I think is crucial to this debate , that is, the danger of proliferation of small, dirty, dangerous atomic weapons as a result of nuclear power, I begin with a quotation:

SPEECH.PARA: The nuclear power industry is unintentionally contributing to an increased risk of nuclear war. This is the most serious hazard associated with the industry.

That is not a quote from some left wing greenie or radical. This was the conclusion of Mr Justice Fox in 1976. That this contribution to the increased risks of nuclear war might be unintentional does nothing to reduce the actual consequences of nuclear proliferation. All commercial nuclear fuel cycles are fuelled with uranium. The irradiation of uranium fuel in any reactor produces the artificial element of plutonium, which is a bomb material, regardless of its isotopic composition or its chemical form. The only practical source of plutonium is from spent fuel rods discharged from power reactors.

This plutonium becomes a proliferation risk immediately it is extracted from the other waste by reprocessing, which is a normal procedure. Once reprocessed, it is in a concentrated, homogeneous form, which can be handled, readily transported, and negotiated. It is anonymous and cannot be identified once it is on the move. Natural uranium can also be enriched to bomb usable concentrations, using low technology centrifuges. An effective centrifuge design was published quite openly some 20 years ago. Better versions, much less efficient than the high technology commercial varieties, I grant, but still adequate, have been made by a good tradesman-machinist in a few weeks. Although hundreds of such crude centrifuges and tonnes of uranium would be needed for patient accumulation of even one bomb's worth of highly enriched uranium, the centrifuges are simple, cheap, concealable and highly accessible. It is too much to expect that they will not be made and used in the world. More sophisticated bomb design certainly is needed to achieve the same performance from reactor grade as from weapons grade plutonium and the yield of that bomb will be uncertain. However, it will still be an unpleasant, highly dangerous weapon, capable of destroying a city. This more sophisticated bomb design is a small price to pay for the greater ease of obtaining plutomium from reactor waste. The power reactor then becomes an innocent civilian cover rather than being obviously military, like a special production reactor.

Reactor grade plutonium is very freely available. The total nuclear power production capacity for 1980, for instance, would have produced 80,000 kilograms of Pu-239, that is, plutonium 239 which is the bomb fuel. The International Atomic Energy Agency estimates that it takes 8 kilograms of Pu-239 for an average nuclear size weapon and I am speaking of a 20 kiloton weapon, five kilotons larger than the Hiroshima bomb. Power reactors, then, can be considered large-scale military production reactors with an electricity by-product. Despite the conventional wisdom that bombs need reprocessed uranium in the form of plutonium, reactor grade plutonium can be used directly in weapons. They are unreliable, dirty weapons of uncertain yield, but still explodable. In 1977, a spokesperson for no less an authority than the United States Energy Research and Development Administration officialy confirmed that the United States had constructed and exploded a nuclear bomb made from reactor grade plutonium. That is on record. It astounds me that still the old saw that this cannot be done is touted around the world and even in this place.

It is not only reactor waste and fuel that increase nuclear proliferation. Many instruments or theories used in civil nuclear power have a military application. Such data as the criticality conditions of plutonium are secret when they are applied to bombs. But, and this is the important bit, precisely the same data can be found published in textbooks available in any public library and in civilian literature which reactor programs make available to proliferators.

I should like to give the Senate a brief historical perspective which demonstrates how often and inevitably the manufacture of nuclear weapons follows the development of nuclear power. The British and the French were able to have a nuclear arsenal once they developed the capacity to reprocess spent fuel, ipso facto, because of the facts I have already mentioned. The Indians purchased civilian and research reactors, fuel and expertise from Canada and lo, in 1974 they exploded a bomb. That was no accident, it was inevitable. The South Africans have developed an enrichment facility at Helikon that can produce weapons grade plutonium. That is a matter of record. The West Germans assisted them to build that facility. The Pakistanis, no doubt worried by India's bomb explosion in 1974, tried to buy nuclear technology openly. They were rebuffed, so they have developed an enrichment facility through espionage, taking Urenco centrifuge technology illegally from Holland. Brazil has purchased an enrichment plant from West Germany. They and the Swiss have also sold the Argentinians a similar facility. We say that there is not any proliferation. Let me go further. The French sold the Israelis a research reactor and the fuel in the late 1960s. The United States is now considering using its own stockpile of commercial reactor waste for nuclear weapons.

It is interesting that the United States has trained many of the world's nuclear scientists. Half of the key staff of the Indian bomb program were trained at the expense of United States taxpayers. The 1,000-odd Taiwanese, 200- odd Argentinians and 272 South Korean nuclear scientists, all United States trained, provide the bulk of their nations' expertise. All these nations are believed to be the closest of any in the world to having nuclear weapons capability, if indeed they do not already have it. It is widely suspected that a number of them do. Given these inherent dangers, it is no surprise to realise that the world community went to some trouble to develop a system of safeguards to prevent nuclear proliferation. How good are those safeguards? Let us have a good, honest look at them. The safeguards have a number of inherent problems which, at the moment, cannot be overcome because, importantly, all nuclear technology does aid a country in acquiring nuclear weapons if it so desires. Safeguards delay or perhaps publicise the inevitable.

Ironically, the foundations of the international non-proliferation regime, the nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty-the NPT-and the International Atomic Energy Agency, actually encourage the spread of nuclear technology while trying to control nuclear proliferation. That is a compromise which cannot work. The safeguards treaties are documents of convenience. They have a large number of signatories precisely because they are not restrictive, and they do not impinge on national ambitions. They are drafted that way deliberately. Safeguards themselves have an inherent flaw that few realise. They do not prevent, in any sense, diversion of bomb material; they only detect diversion. Once safeguards are of any use it is already too late. At that stage the bomb material has been diverted.

No system of safeguards can predict a nation's future intentions. Even a signatory of the Non-Proliferation Treaty can withdraw after three months' notice. That is not a very long period. Let us look at an example. An excellent example of failure to predict future intentions was in fact the 1979 proposal to export our uranium to Iran. Some months after the proposal the Shah of Iran was overthrown and the political complexion of the country changed drastically. What use are safeguards agreements when countries which are parties to the treaty can withdraw in circumstances like that after three months' notice? What sort of safeguard is that for the human race? No safeguards, no matter how well drafted, how binding or complete would have prevented our uranium from going into bombs in a country where there was a radical change of government. The only way such a thing could be prevented from happening in the future is to prohibit the export of uranium, as this Bill proposes.

Even if there is advance or timely warning about diversion of uranium into weapons, safeguards still become of scant value. The Pakistani intention to acquire nuclear weapons has been known for several years; yet no safeguard could prevent Pakistan from acquiring that capability in the long run. Israel and India are similar examples. There are other examples in the world as well. All attempts to provide for international safeguards have been flawed from the beginning and will continue to be because in a world of nationalism, of independent states, it is not possible, other than by some world government or world dictatorship, to provide a system of safeguards which will work. Apart from the contradiction of having to encourage the spread of nuclear technology while constraining it, a number of nations with nuclear power programs did not sign the treaty; for example, France, to which we export uranium, China, Pakistan, India, Israel, South Africa, Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Cuba. Most of those countries have an interest in nuclear power.

The International Atomic Energy Agency which is charged with monitoring safeguards has only 138 inspectors to cover 774 facilities. Inspectors often cannot speak the language of the country in which the reactor is sited. A country can reject inspectors on the ground of nationality only. Thus, Iraq accepted only Soviet or Hungarian International Atomic Energy Agency inspectors. That was the reason, of course, why Israel became concerned. It led to the the bombing of Iraq's Osarik reactor. That was the reason for it. The safeguards inspectors are permitted to allow a one per cent to 1.5 per cent loss of plutonium or highly enriched uranium in inventories. This material unaccounted for-it is referred to briefly as MUF-could be enough to build a small arsenal of weapons. Indeed, it is enough to do so at this stage. An average reprocessing plant handles 1,500 spent fuel rods containing 3.3 million pounds of waste each year. Of that waste one per cent, 33,000 pounds, is plutonium. One per cent of that Pu-239-a permissible amount of material unaccounted for, allowed by the safeguards inspectors-is enough for 20 nuclear weapons. We call this sieve, this mesh, of safeguards something which is going to protect to the world. It is a joke, but not a joke at which one would laugh. It is a tragic, disastrous joke. Those people who ignore these facts do so to their discredit because the future of the human race is involved in these matters.

There is no doubt at all that significant amounts of bomb material have disappeared. Public disclosures about missing bomb material make it clear that the international nuclear fuel cycle has leaked profusely, all safeguards notwithstanding. A sanitised summary of a United States General Accounting Office confidential report released in 1977, which was some time ago, said that the United States Government was unable to account for tens of tonnes of uranium and plutonium which had disappeared since World War II. One plant alone-the Nuclear Materials and Equipment Corporation in Pennsylvania-has lost 208 kilograms of weapons grade plutonium since 1978. That is enough for 26 Hiroshima -sized weapons. In January 1980 a General Accounting Office report showed that between 1955 and 1978 Du Pont's Savannah River plutonium plant had lost 146 kilograms of plutonium, enough for 18 bombs.

The fact is that any country possessing a modern nuclear power station can obtain from the plutonium recovered from its spent fuel rods enough material to make at least five to eight atomic bombs a year. It is naive to believe that this will not happen. It will happen. What will the consequence be? Quite simply , over perhaps a century or so, the risk of the destruction of human society-not with a bang but with a whimper-will be great. The destruction will probably be on a permanent basis. There will be an increasing incidence of cancer. I will deal with that a little later when I talk about the regrettable events recently at Windscale. There will be gross deformities in animals and children not yet born and other genetic consequences which are perhaps yet to unfold to the world .

When one looks at the huge amounts of recoverable uranium from Roxby Downs-1.2 million tonnes-to be sold somewhere, we understand, on a very competitive market for uranium, I believe that one may be looking at the decisive act which will destroy this world. I repeat: To go ahead with Roxby Downs is very likely to be the fatal act for the world because of the vast quantities of the material which are at Roxby Downs. Ironically, it is the Australian Labor Party which has spoken so much over the years about the dangers of nuclear power and the nuclear cycle which is prepared to accept those 30 pieces of silver for the economic short term gain it sees. It will become the architect of that final diabolical betrayal by indeed agreeing that these huge masses of disastrous material be let loose on the world.

Let us examine that situation a little more closely. Development of Roxby Downs will represent a huge investment. That is well known both by the State and by the people developing Roxby Downs. The pressure will be on to permit sale of its massive amounts of uranium to anyone prepared to buy it. Of course, the current pattern is that it is the unreliable, autocratic societies which want to buy that uranium. They do not want it for nuclear power houses. They do not want it to benefit their people. Such places as Libya, Argentina and so on do not want it for generating electric power. That would be the incidental purpose, the cover for the real purpose, which is to realise their ambition-that is, to join the nuclear club, to be able to make nuclear weapons and to be able to strong- arm, blackmail and subdue their neighbours and pursue their political ambitions.

Let us examine again these weapons, made by relatively restricted technology. They will not give reliable yields, but they will be all the more terrifying to the world because of their crudity. The major nuclear powers at least have been able to evolve weapons which do not have high fallout and which are not dirty in the sense of permanently contaminating the earth. This is not so in relation to the weapons which would be made as by-products of nuclear power. These will be Nagasaki and Hiroshima type A bombs which, when they are used in regional wars, will permanently contaminate the air and the seas of the planet with cancer- inducing substances and all those deadly isotopes, unseen and unsuspected, which cause genetic mutation and gross birth defects which will create monsters of children yet unborn.

Am I justified in saying that? Let us examine the latest report from the United Press International only yesterday, relating to the Windscale area in the United Kingdom. The headline is 'Child cancer levels jump near nuclear plant'. the report states:
Alarming levels of leukemia and cancer have been found in children who live near a nuclear power plant in north-west England, according to a television documentary research team.
