Yorkshire Television said research for the documentary found the village nearest the Windscale nuclear plant had 10 times as much leukemia as the national average and a significantly higher incidence of cancer.
Plutonium dust has been found in homes 65km from the plant.
The reports say animals are grazing in fields that are contaminated with 100 times the normal level of radiation.
A farmer, whose land borders the plant in Cumbria, claims calves with hairless, deformed limbs or without tongues and ears have been born for the last three years.
The television team studied five coastal villages near the plant and found 14 children with cancer.
The Windscale plant, which is run by the state-owned British Nuclear Fuels, is a commercial operation that reprocesses spent nuclear fuel.

For years we have been told that the Windscale operation is perfectly safe; that the British are great at technology. This now is the consequence which is emerging; it is probably only the beginning of what we are to hear, and to what we shall contribute if we allow this export of uranium to go on.

It is a fact, of course, that the supporters of nuclear power have lied over this matter, consistently and knowingly. Regulatory commissions and, indeed, the International Atomic Energy Agency have at times lied and deceived the world. When 200 tonnes of yellowcake disappeared from the ship Scheersburg A in 1968, the International Atomic Energy Agency successfully for years suppressed any information about that. That operation was almost certainly organised by the Mossad, the Israeli secret service, and the material went to the Dimona research organisation in Israel, where it was probably made into nuclear bombs. Israel does not admit to this, but some very interesting studies made on it point to very strong circumstantial evidence. Even a whole book, well researched, which has been written on the subject points directly to this as the conclusion.

The point, of course, is that, if the yellowcake did not go to Israel, where did it go? In fact, we have never had an answer on that from the Agency or anyone else. It is not known where it went. That was an entire ship with its cargo. The ship disappeared for three weeks. The cargo of yellowcake disappeared , and the ship reappeared under another name. None of the so-called safeguard organisations can tell us the truth about that matter. They are powerless organisations designed to give the world a false reassurance on this subject.

Reports of regular losses of plutonium come into the news with monotonous regularity, as I have said, but, even more alarmingly, it has been reported that there is a world black market for plutonium with anonymous buyers offering huge prices. That is only too likely to be true. Reprocessing and enrichment plants can readily be adjusted to provide weapons grade material, and that will happen.

Will all these new weapons be used? We are looking at a world now in which economic and social pressures will become acute in the next few decades, largely and ironically, due to the massive amounts of money being spent on nuclear arms which might otherwise be spent, as they should be, on improving the conditions of life and health for the human race. The destruction of Flight 007, the Beirut bombing, events in Grenada are all part of a terrible sequence of events which should give us all pause. They portend a world of greater ruthlessness and violence, in which the destruction of large numbers of human beings is accepted casually, almost inevitably, as being part of the good clean fun of the power struggle in the world. Of course the nuclear weapons made from nuclear power- houses will be used. They will be used all right, and quite soon, in regional wars which we shall see on our television sets, just like the others. But the wars of the future will be different, because unknown to us, unseen and undetectable except with special instruments, will be the deadly radiation which cannot be removed or cleaned up, which will remain for perhaps 50,000 years- further into the future than we can trace back our history into the past. That is why this Bill is a vitally important one. We are truly at a crossroads of decision in this matter. The question whether or not we export uranium now is fundamental. It is not just a small political or short term matter. It is something which will, perhaps, change the course of the world.

Finally, what will the war in which these weapons are used be like? I turn to yesterday's Melbourne Age and to a report of the Washington conference dealing with the world after nuclear war. It based its findings on the use of only one third of the weapons now in the world, and they are as follows:
Eleven hundred million people would die immediately and another 1,100 million would be severely injured.
That is more than half of the population of the planet. The report continues:

Within weeks after such an exchange, according to the report, soot, smoke and dust from nuclear fires and groundbursts could reduce the amount of sunlight at ground level to a few per cent of normal. 'An unbroken gloom would persist for weeks over the Northern Hemisphere'.

For the next months, the light filtering through this pall might not be adequate to sustain photo-synthesis, the process by which plants convert sunlight to food. At best, the reduced light could severely limit growth 'and the consequences would cascade through all food chains' . . .

The lack of sunlight could cause a 'harsh nuclear winter' with temperatures dropping as much as 25 degrees Celsius in inland areas. Many areas could be subject to continuous snowfall, even in summer. If the nuclear exchange occurred in spring or summer, virtually all crops would be killed in the Northern Hemisphere. Many animals would die of thirst because surface waters would be frozen over in the interior of continents.

I think that I cannot do better to stress the importance of this matter than to read that quotation and to try to make especially our colleages in the Australian Labor Party understand that this is just not a matter of votes in South Australia or of whether the Government there survives or, indeed, whether any government survives. It is not a matter even of economics. It is a matter of sheer survival for the human race, because that which I have described is the nightmare to which we are all contributing if we decide to export uranium.

This Bill proposes that we regain our sanity, that we give an honest and principled lead to the world by saying: 'This must stop, and we are the ones who are going to say that it must stop. Follow our lead'. I believe that the balance in the world now is so delicate that, if Australia gave that lead, others would follow. It is nonsense to say that by acquiescing weakly with what international power and monetary structures want, what big business and international corporations want, by selling our uranium, we will have any influence on events. Of course we will not have any influence on events. We will just run along with the rest of the lemmings. We will influence events only by taking a powerful firm view of the matter ourselves and saying: 'We, as a community, as a society, and as the owners of the world's most massive resources of uranium, will be taking a responsible view of this. We see the historical obligation placed on us , and we shall honour that obligation and not betray it'. That might turn back the world from what may well be the final tradgedy of the human race. On that basis I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Customs (Nuclear Materials and Hardware Prohibition) Bill is one which I am sure is brought before this chamber with the utmost of sincerity but, I believe, with a considerable degree of misunderstanding and misdirection of effort. I should like to develop some of the basic points further to those already made by, in particular, Senator Walsh, to whom I offer congratulations on a responsible speech, and by my leader in this chamber, Senator Chaney. In starting to refer to this, I should like to quote first from Professor Ted Ringwood's paper entitled 'Australia's Uranium and the International Nuclear Industry'. On page 13 he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We should accept the basic reality that the unavailability of Australian uranium will not affect the development of the nuclear industry in France, UK, Japan, USA, Sweden, Belgium, Switzerland, Germany, Italy, Spain, Finland, Taiwan , Korea, Brazil, Argentina, and many other countries, including third world nations and the eastern bloc. These countries, most of which do not possess substantial reserves of fossil fuels or indigenous uranium, are nevertheless firmly committed to the use of nuclear power, for economic and other reasons, which are seen to be compelling in their respective national interests. In these circumstances the withholding of Australian uranium from the world market appears to be something of a hollow gesture. The principle consequence of such a policy is that we are losing any influence that we might otherwise have had on the international nuclear scene. On the other hand, if Australia marketed uranium responsibly as a member of the international community and became a trusted trading partner, there is a real chance that we could influence the nuclear policies of other countries in desirable directions.

I believe that that is a fair statement of the situation which I would wish to argue. Many countries are committed to nuclear power. Attempt's to curtail the supply of uranium yellowcake, can, I believe, only further encourage the use of fast breeder reactors and the production of plutonium which can then only make more dangerous the possible conversion of uranium to nuclear weapons.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you will get that in the end, anyway, will you not? Uranium supplies are finite. You must face that in any case.

—I would hope that long before the supplies of uranium have been exhausted, solar power and other renewable energy sources will have been developed to a stage where we do not have to worry about either the use of fossil fuels or finite resources such as uranium. It is my very strong hope-one can only have faith in the future-that events will go in that direction. But, in the short term, the position is that other sources are needed.

SPEECH.PARA: We hear much about the morality of nuclear energy. I wonder about the morality of two aspects of certain of the current alternative energy sources. I also wonder about the exhaustion of the finite resources which have multiple and essential uses, such as hydrocarbons, which have a variety of uses in our society when there is a substitute which is available and which has no alternative use. That substitute is uranium. One would hope that the world would be conscious of the need to ensure that the supplies of hydrocarbons can be husbanded for as long as possible. The intemperate use of them can be slowed down.

I wonder about the morality of continuing with the development of coal mining, particularly underground coal mining with its incredible dangers and the continuous loss of life that is involved. I will quote some figures to support this view. During 1982 I understand the following accidents occurred: In January a coal mine explosion in Kentucky with 17 killed; an oil mine explosion in Mexico with 8 killed; in February an oil rig sank off Newfoundland with 84 killed; in March a coal pipe collapsed in Calcutta with 18 killed; in April a coal mine explosion in Poland with 15 killed; in May a coal mine explosion in Yugoslavia with 39 killed; in October a dam collapsed in Libya with 200 killed; in November a coal mine explosion in Poland with 18 killed; in December an oil fired power station explosion in Venezuela with 145 killed.

TALK.START.PARA: —All on about page 50 of the newspapers. They did not get any publicity at all.

—I acknowledge Senator Jessop's interjection. I believe most of those accidents were the product of negligence. If one looks at what has happened so far as the United States nuclear industry is concerned, it is hard to escape the conclusion that any of the problems that have arisen there are the result of negligence and not any more inherent in the operation than is the risk of a dam collapsing and killing a lot of people who are flooded by the water or of a coal mine collapsing and people being killed. I would have thought that the latter two examples are far more likely than the first.
—Do you have any statistics on lung cancer among coal miners?

—I have some, but I was not proposing to cite them. No doubt later speakers in the debate will be able to do so. I also wanted to refer to the morality question-the morality of continuing to pollute the atmosphere with coal fired thermal power stations, with the creation of acid rain, with the impacts which have hit particular parts of the world very severely. I refer to the effects generally of the pollution on the health of humans and animals not just in coal mines, but also on people who live in the area and are subjected, whether they like it or not, to the fall-out from burning hyrdocarbons. If one looks at any of the objectively acquired figures, it is very hard to escape the conclusion that the comparative risk between coal fired thermal and nuclear power, places nuclear power at the relatively safe end of the scale and coal fired thermal power at the very disadvantageous and dangerous end of the scale.

SPEECH.PARA: Following on from that, I want to refer very briefly to what I think is an unfortunate and a fairly massive scale campaign of disinformation by people who perhaps have some vested interests. I refer, for example to some of those who provide funds for the so-called peace movement in Europe. They have vested interests in attacking the situation of the West and its capacity to defend itself. Senator Chipp spent quite a bit of time referring to the horrors of a prospective nuclear war. Whilst I subscribed to the general points he raised, I think some of the emphasis in his speech was unfortunate. For instance, he said that the United States could deliver 12,000 warheads on the Soviets and the Soviets could unload 8,000 warheads on the United States with such accuracy as they would land within 100 feet of a target, often after travelling thousands of miles. I rather had the impression that the whole concern of western Europe and the NATO allies is that the position is the reverse. The escalation since 1979- in the last four years in particular-that has taken place has been by the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics upscaling dramatically the number of warheads, not necessarily the number of missiles. I will just quote from a paper presented to-

TALK.START.PARA: —Does it matter? Are not 20,000 nuclear warheads aimed at human beings enough for you? Do you want some more?
—We don't want them all on the one side.

—I wonder whether honourable senators would let me make the points as I go. I started to say that I agree with the sentiments expressed by Senator Chipp. I want to get the balance into this aspect of the debate. I wanted to quote from a document presented by Mr Michael Forrestall of Canada to the North Atlantic Assembly just over a month ago.
—Who is he?
—He was the Rapporteur appointed, as a member of the North Atlantic Assembly, to consider the question of the military balance and the arms control agenda. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Warsaw Pact long-range nuclear forces deployed in the Soviet Union consist of SS-4, SS-5 and SS-20 ballistic missiles.
He further said that the SS-4 and SS-5 missiles:

. . . have been replaced beginning in 1977 with MIRVed SS-20s carrying three warheads. Thus, although the number launchers has remained approximately stable, the number of warheads deployed on long-range systems has increased, nearly doubling since the December 1979 NATO decision.
That is the dual track decision. The Rapporteur continues:

Currently, the Soviet Union has deployed 360 SS-20s, and retains 248 SS-4s and SS-5s, totalling 1328 warheads. 108 SS-20s are deployed in Soviet Asia, and it is expected that this number will double within one year.

Even more horrific in many ways-I think there is a degree of control in relation to anybody starting a nuclear war-is another aspect that was not mentioned. I refer to the horror that is facing Europe and the world as the two major power groups, the Soviet bloc and the NATO allies, remain in a stand-off position each , as Senator Chipp pointed out, with immense nuclear power. I quote again from the same paper:
Soviet chemical agents are thought to include Soman and Tuban nerve gases, as well as Mustard gas.
Means of delivery include artillery, rocket launchers, aircraft and tactical missiles as well as land mines. It continues:
Some estimates suggest that the Soviet Union is equipped to fight a chemical war with NATO for 30 days at a depth of 500 kilometres. Soviet chemical agent stockpiles are estimated at 350,000 tons.
I repeat, the Soviet Union has 350,000 tons of chemical agents to be used. The paper goes on:

The United States last produced chemical weapons in 1969. The current US stockpile of chemical agents is estimated at roughly 42,000 tons, 15,000 tons of which consists of nerve agents GB and VX, with the rest as mustard gas.

I quote that as part of my joining in the concern expressed in relation to what is happening, including the escalation of nuclear weapons and horrific weapons of war. I do not think there is any real doubt on the part of anybody that the escalation which has taken place in recent years has been because of the use of Soviet SS20 missiles and their deployment. They are aimed principally at Western Europe, and Western Europe has responded by going ahead with the Pershing and Cruise missile program. It is typical of the attitude towards self-defence, which has been a dominant force since the Second World War. Whether or not the figures I cited are accurate, the prospect of the first firing of a nuclear weapon is quite horrific. The situation is that, whoever is responsible for refusing to go ahead with the disarmament talks that NATO allies claim that they are endeavouring to hold and whoever is responsible for the escalation, the fact is that it has happened; the fact is that we have this incredible stand-off, and the fact is that it is not simply limited to Western Europe, although that is where the major problem exists. In the light of what I have said, I cannot see that Australia's exporting of uranium for use subject to nuclear safeguards and subject to the controls which we have developed, probably as responsibly or more responsibly than any other country, will enhance the risk of the sort of destruction which will take place if someone is mad enough, insane enough, to start a nuclear war with the weaponry already available.

From the point of view of the misuse of nuclear material by terrorists, to which reference has been made, I would like to quote very briefly from a paper prepared and published by the Home Mission Division of the Methodist Church of London. At page 15 it says:

Violence and terrorism are sadly fairly common, and it is of real concern that nuclear materials such as fission product waste or plutonium might provide terrorists with new opportunities to cause harm or hold communities to ransom.

Neither uranium ore nor fresh fuel for thermal reactors are attractive materials for the terrorist. They cannot be made into nuclear weapons without colossal effort and expenditure and they are much less poisonous than many weedkillers. Once inside a reactor, the uranium in the fuel is steadily converted into fission products and plutonium, but at this stage it presents extremely difficult problems for a terrorist who might want to use it. In order to steal the fuel he must take over the power station, use the complicated fuel loading and unloading machine to take out some fuel and choose between taking it away in an ordinary lorry, in which case its radiation will kill him within a short time, or using a heavy, slow and easily located fuel transport lorry. The fuel is so radioactive at this stage that it is highly self-defending, as it is when it is being transported from the power station to the fuel reprocessing plant. After reprocessing the fission products (the waste) are just as self- defending as ever and by the time the terrorist can handle them they do not pose a very great threat to anybody.

The article goes on to develop that argument but it is worth bearing in mind the points made in that passage. I would have thought the real risk in relation to terrorists is that they may steal an existing nuclear weapon, not try to get hold of uranium fuels to build their own.

Reference has been made to the comparative costs of power generation and I would like quite briefly to put the other side of that story. The cost of power from France's significant and very advanced nuclear system is 26 per cent less than that generated from its coal system. As it has to import some coal, although it has a large amount of its own, and it has to import virtually all of its uranium, one imagines that those costs are reasonably comparable. Senator Macklin referred to the cost of nuclear power generation in the United States. One would think that is the least appropriate country to cite and that France, the United Kingdom, the Federal Republic of Germany, Sweden and a number of other countries would be far more appropriate. A Press release of 16 September 1983-just a couple of months ago-indicated that even in the United States the cost of producing electricity per kilowatt hour averaged, in 1982, 3.1c for nuclear power, 3.5c for coal and 7c for oil. The figures given by almost every country on which I have been able to check are similarly comparable in showing nuclear power as costing significantly less than anything except hydro- electricity. As everybody knows, hydro-electricity is becoming more expensive because of the long lead times and higher positive interest rates.

The next point I refer to is the impact of this matter on Australia. A paper prepared by the office of the current Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), with the aid of the appropriate interdepartmental committee, suggests that a shutdown of the uranium industry would cost $7,000m and up to 18,600 jobs in the next 10 years. I agree that if the question were simply one of jobs or bombs we would have a very serious responsibility. But one can argue, as I have, that it is not a case of jobs in Australia or bombs around the world because the bombs are already around the world. It is a very serious responsibility when we are considering closing off those 18,600 jobs in Australia. If Australia opts out of the uranium industry we will have no say in regard to safeguards, nuclear proliferation or waste disposal. We would suffer an enormous loss of revenue, investment and jobs if that happened and, rather than going in that direction, I suggest that Australia's interests require that we control even more and also get more value added benefit out of our uranium exports by moving towards enrichment processes which will quite obviously produce those results. Australia would then be in a position to influence even more effectively decisions resulting from the world- wide nuclear debate. It is my belief that one of the problems in relation to nuclear power is that so much of the debate takes place on the basis of the very understandable emotions of the 1940s when people looked at 'nuclear' as nuclear bombs. It is understandable that, if one lived in Europe on either side of the demarcation zone between the two Germanies, one would feel very conscious and very concerned about the possibility of nuclear war and nuclear bombs. But nuclear power and nuclear weapons--

TALK.START.PARA: —But you do not think we would survive a European nuclear war, do you? What has it got to do with the Europeans?
—I would have thought that living where the weapons are situated and aimed at each other, many of them at a relatively short distance, and where there are both tactical and strategic--
—Not one Australian will be left alive.
—I do not have time to debate that in detail. I am saying I can imagine that if one lives--
—That is groundless.
—You are a hypocrite.
—I raise a point of order. Senator Chipp referred to Senator Tate, who was seeking to interject, as a hypocrite. I request that he withdraw that remark.
—I did not hear the remark. Did Senator Chipp say that? If so, he must withdraw it.
—Yes, I made it. I withdraw it.

—The point I was endeavouring to make is that if one lived right under the shadow of the nuclear weapons stand-off position, one's sensitivity would be considerably heightened. I suggest, notwithstanding that, there is virtually no debate-contrary to what the media in Australia portrays- about nuclear power in most of those countries. The debate is about nuclear weapons. When the subject is portrayed in the media in Australia, particularly the electronic media, it comes through as if the protests are against nuclear energy and nuclear power. This is where one of the major unfortunate confusions in the nature of the debate takes place. The technology of the 1980s is very different to the nuclear technology of the 1950s. Technology which is now available is subjected to incredible testing and safeguards. Recently I visited the Fromotome plant in France which builds high pressure water cylinders. It takes four years to build a cylinder, over half of which time is spent on testing to ensure the safety of the cylinders. For those who say that there is not much of a future for nuclear power energy, I can only say that something like 30 cylinders were being produced on the production line at that plant. Obviously Fromotome believes it has plenty of orders to fulfil. France has probably gone more strongly down the nuclear energy track than almost any other country. An extremely high percentage-43 per cent-of its power is now produced by nuclear power. It is moving towards a situation where, by 1990, 70 per cent of its electricity needs will be provided from that source.
—One of the most immoral countries in the world.

—Senator Chipp interjected about morality. I go back to the fact that I believe the burning of hydrocarbons and their being let loose on the world is an immoral act. I refer also to the huge growth which is planned in Japan in the development of nuclear power. A figure of 20.3 per cent of Japan's total requirements are already provided as a result of nuclear power. If there were any country which one would expect to be extremely sensitive to nuclear energy, to nuclear power, it would be the only country that has experienced a nuclear bomb. Yet last year Japan announced the expansion of a further 100 nuclear power plants as a program to the end of the century. Already 20 per cent of its power is provided from that source.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe there are very genuine issues of concern such as proliferation, safety of operation and the question of waste disposal. As I have stated, I think there are ways in which these issues can be overcome. Rather than stopping Australia's participation in what will happen in any event and which would certainly remove our power to participate in making the likelihood of nuclear war and the misuse of the capacity of uranium less than it is now, we should strongly support the endeavours of our ally, the United States, in the disarmament negotiations which are taking place and will continue to take place. We should encourage the further development of waste disposal methods. In particular we should strongly support the further development of the synroc waste disposal method developed by Professor Ringwood and the Australian Atomic Energy Commission. We should encourage the continued development of nuclear safeguards agreements and the extending of the participation in their enforcement. In semi-final conclusion I wish to quote the conclusions of the Methodist Church document from which I have already quoted. It states:
In this chapter we have tried to present the essential conclusions of our two year study of nuclear power. In summary they are:
i. Nuclear energy is an integral part of nature, just as much God's creation as sunshine and rain.
ii. It does offer mankind a new energy source which is very large, convenient and not very costly.

iii. Around the world the most important energy sources, oil in the rich world and wood in the poor, are becoming scarce, so that we cannot afford to set aside any energy technology with large potential which is cost effective, provided it is reasonably safe.

iv. There are risks associated with the use of nuclear power, as with everything else, but these have been very carefull evaluated, are not very big and are not at all out of scale compared with risks of other energy sources and other ordinary hazards.
Finally, I quote from page 19 of Professor Ringwood's paper to which I have referred. The paper states:

There are very few areas of major enterprise where Australia has the capacity to play a strategic role on the world scene and exercise a degree of International leadership. The nuclear fuel cycle is one such area. If we fail to accept this challenge, we would be abandoning our responsibilities to the remainder of the world, and simultaneously sabotaging our national interests.
I endorse and accept the words of Professor Ringwood.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted under sessional order for the consideration of General Business having expired, the debate is interrupted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Walsh) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the second reading speech.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to continue bounty assistance during 1983-84 to the manufacturer in Australia of certain refrigerated room air conditioners. The Temporary Assistance Authority (TAA), in its report No. 62 of 7 June 1983 entitled 'Certain Room Air Conditioning Machines' recommended that bounty assistance continue during 1983-84 at the same rates and limits that applied in 1982-83. The Government has decided to continue bounty assistance on locally produced room air conditioners for a further 12 months to 30 June 1984. An additional $1,500,000 is to be made available for bounty payments during this period. Bounty will be paid on room air conditioning machines of a portable or fixed window type designed primarily for use without ducting and having a nominally rated cooling capacity of 5.4 kilowatts or less. The rates of bounty are $60 for smaller units not exceeding 3.528 kilowatts cooling capacity and $90 for larger units.

The Email owned Kelvinator plant in Adelaide has been subjected to severe import competition, and the extension of the bounty is designed to assist the company to secure sales of their locally produced air conditioners. However, given existing high levels of imported stocks, the bounty may do little to assist Email contain competition from new imports in 1983-84. Accordingly, the Government has also introduced import restraints for 1983-84 by a tariff quota limiting imports for that period to 55 per cent of the 1982-83 level. These combined temporary measures-bounty and tariff quota-are considered essential if the local industry is to regain economies of scale to ensure its future viability. Without them there would be a significant risk that local manufacture could cease and thus the bounty already accorded and production investment made by the company would have been wasted. The cost of the additional bounty is $1, 500,000 in 1983-84 and there are no direct offset savings. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw attention to that section of the report of Estimates Committee B which relates to the question of special funds of some $53m, $20m of which was allocated by the Department of Finance to the Department of Social Security for the purpose of establishing staff and facilities for the introduction of the assets test. It became evident during Estimates committee hearings that the Department of Social Security did not know of the composition of or the purpose for which this $20m had been allocated until after the Budget had been presented and after there had been an announcement about the assets test.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I want to make here is that clearly the Department of Finance had determined how much of this so-called special fund was to be set aside for the use of the Department of Social Security. However, it came out in evidence that the permanent head of the Department of Social Security indicated that he in fact had not sought the funds prior to the Budget and in fact quite clearly the total had been determined outside his own control. As I understand it, he was not clear, at the time the Budget was brought down, what this money was going to be used for.

I think this highlights the point that was made during the debate on this matter last night, that in fact there was a great deal of haste on the part of the Government in the putting together of the assets test in the final days before the presentation of the Budget. Consequently the Department of Social Security clearly was not aware of how much money it was going to need to establish the assets test. Consequently, its role in determining this matter is brought very clearly into question.

The other aspect of the problem I want to raise is specifically mentioned in the report of the Estimates Committee. I think it is worth quoting from the report just to draw attention to the problem that I think is raised by this matter. The report states:
Finally, the Committee questions the practice of seeking funds for the assets test under the vote for the ordinary annual services of the Government which is not subject to amendment by the Senate.
It goes on:

The assets test is clearly a new program and its initial funding should have been included in either Appropriation Bill (No. 2) which is intended, in part, for the funding of new policies or otherwise in a subsequent Appropriation Bill which could be introduced when the purposes for which the funds are required have been identified to the Parliament and the program approved by the Parliament.

The point that needs to be made straight away is that the device that was used to create an allocation of about $53m, part of which was to be used for the establishment of the assets test under the votes of the Department of Social Security, was included in this manner in the Estimates even though there had been no passage through the Parliament of the necessary legislation establishing the assets test. The report clearly demonstrates that a very significant question arises because, while Parliament is allocating funds by legislation for the purpose of establishing an assets test, there can be no guarantee that the necessary legislation establishing the assets test will be passed by the Parliament. I am not in any way indicating what position may be taken on policy or what the fate of such legislation may be. I am only drawing attention to the fact that surely the Department of Finance would be used to handling sums of money in accordance with the normal Treasury requirements so that the proper formalities for dealing with the funding of new programs by the Government are met and the Parliament has a full debate on programs before funds are allocated to it. This program has got under way with the allocation of $20m. Of course, there has been a pre-emption of this Parliament's role in determining the question of policy in that funds have already been allocated. I think that requires some answer. I draw the Minister's attention to the Estimates Committee report on this matter. The Chairman, Senator Giles, is present in the chamber. I am sure that she would agree that this matter needs some answers.

Advances are made by the Minister for Finance from time to time for various urgent and unforeseen needs. That system of funding for particular needs is a well-defined one and one for which guidelines are very clearly laid down. Reports must be made to the Parliament on the nature of the expenditure, albeit after the event. But the guidelines stipulate that the allocation must be for urgent and unforeseen matters. It is a different matter when a special fund for a particular purpose is established. For allocations from the Advance to the Minister for Finance, a seemingly less important area, there are strict guidelines yet, in this case, where the Government has decided upon a new program, funds have been allocated well in advance of the determination of the program. I believe that the Parliament should be concerned about funds being allocated in this fashion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Messner, you are supposed to be debating the Estimates and not other matters.

—Indeed I am. There is only one other matter I would like to raise in connection with the Estimates and that is the matter of identity cards for social security recipients. I noted some debate on this matter yesterday in the House of Representatives. My attention was drawn to the remarks of the honourable member for Darling Downs, Mr McVeigh. I perused a transcript of an AM program some weeks ago and the following reply by Mr Snow, the honourable member for Eden-Monaro, to a question from Michael Dodd:

SPEECH.PARA: If that doesn't work then I think we'd have to look at the possibility having identity cards so that people can be listed with a number for instance that would indicate that they are receiving a social security benefit, they have to produce that identity card, and if that was done I think it would be much easier for governments to tell where there are abuses of the system.

I think Mr Willis, in his remarks yesterday in the House of Representatives, completely repudiated this suggestion in respect of identity cards. However, his remarks were limited to the unemployed. I ask the Minister for Social Security ( Senator Grimes): Is that the Government's position in respect of all social security recipients?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose I should deal with the last point first; that would be easiest. I am certainly aware of Mr Snow's remarks on the AM program in which he seemed to advocate the view that if the present methods for cutting down on social security fraud were not successful we should introduce identity cards for the unemployed. I make it perfectly clear, as I made it clear to Mr Snow at the time, that that is not government policy and it is certainly not my policy. In answer to a question in the Senate the other day I said that there is all the difference in the world between having a system like that which exists, for instance, in the United States of America, where everyone from the President right down to the latest new-born child has a social security number, and the sort of thing that is being advocated by Mr McVeigh and, I think, on face value, by Mr Snow-that we provide identity cards to disadvantaged groups in the community. I am always amused, as I said the other day, at the Opposition's attitude to this sort of thing. We have frequently heard Opposition members, particularly members of the National Party of Australia, advocating the view that unemployment beneficiaries and pensioners and others should have cards to identify themselves and to single them out from the rest of the community. Yet at the same time with the introduction of Medibank and Medicare, when people had Medibank and Medicare numbers for the convenience of the accounting system, this was painted by Mr Fraser, Mr Anthony and others as somehow returning to the days of nazi Germany and identity cards.

SPEECH.PARA: I really think the situation of the Government is clear. We have no intention of introducing identity cards for unemployment beneficiaries or others. There is no proposal of that type before the Government at the moment, nor do we have any intention of introducing social security numbers a la the United States for everyone in the community. That is our position. I do not know what the Opposition's position is. It depends on who talks and who says things. Mr Snow had a view. Mr Snow, as honourable senators know, is the honourable member for Eden-Monaro in another place. He had a view about one group in the community. That was his personal view and it is certainly not the view of the Australian Labor Party or the Government.

Let me go back to Senator Messner's initial remarks about the assets test and how it came about and about division 312 of the Estimates, which covers the special funds for expenditure in relation to government programs at the direction of the Minister for Finance. I do not know how many times I have said this, but I will say it again now: Senator Messner's assertion that the assets test was conceived in haste in the last week or 10 days before the Budget is just not correct. It is not true and I do not think I need to say more than that . Just because Senator Messner says it every time he gets on his feet in this place does not make it true. The matter of assets tests and all the other options in the incomes policy was one for consideration of Cabinet, of Cabinet committees and working parties for a considerable time-in fact practically from the time we got into government. Senator Messner can feed his prejudices by making assertions like this over and over again as much as he likes. Of course, that is what Dr Goebbels and Adolf Hitler did. The more one repeats a lie and the bigger the lie the more one hopes it will be true. But he will be no more successful in the long run than Goebbels or Hitler were in their little efforts. I repeat that the assets test was given proper consideration. I repeat that it was not conceived in haste in the last week or fortnight before the Budget, nor has it been hastily conceived since. It was done in this way so we could consult with various members of the community and various pensioner organisations. As I say, I cannot stop Senator Messner saying it, but if he wants to bore everyone to tears with that sort of assertion, fair enough.

As for division 312-this other area of the Estimates which Senator Messner has such a problem with-in the past where new or extended programs have been approved for introduction late in the Budget context, where the decision is made for introduction later on in the year, additional staffing requirements of administering departments have often been considered by the Public Service Board after the Budget with the salaries and related administrative costs being funded from the Advance to the Minister for Finance pending the Additional Estimates. We all know that and we all go through it every year. The Additional Estimates contain what has come from the Advance to the Minister for Finance. It is believed, and I think has been believed in the Department of Finance and Treasury for some time, that this practice can adversely effect the integrity of the Budget Estimates and so for the 1983-84 Budget progress was made towards the integration of staffing and financial estimates such that where time permitted it, administration costs associated with new or extended programs were provide under the departments concerned. Where inefficient time precluded specific allocations, bulk provision was made under division 312.

That was the $53m that Senator Messner is talking about. Senator Messner seems to be under the illusion that no one in the Department of Social Security knew about this or knew how much money was coming or where it was coming from. In fact he first asked Mr Calvert, an officer from my Department, in the Estimates Committee hearing what it was all about. Mr Calvert said that the $20m was to cover the assets testing and that he had had it communicated to him in broad terms consequent upon the introduction of the Budget. That was Mr Calvert's situation. He answered accurately-particularly so. Mr Ayers-he is the Director- General and he knew-later on pointed out that under the new arrangements the Department of Social Security had made a particular bid for the particular share of the breakup of that money to cope with the assets test situation. It was not as though the Department of Finance suddenly came along and said: 'We will throw you $20m.' The decision was not made off the top of the head. It was made because it had been informed of the potential cost and the staffing problems associated with the assets test.

So we have the situation where insufficient time precluded the specific allocation; this bulk provision was made under division 312. As the amounts not allocated were known to relate to salary and related administrative costs it was considered that parliamentary control and scrutiny would best be served by making a specific provision rather than utilising the more anonymous Advance to the Minister for Finance. We have the previous situation of the Advance to the Minister for Finance which we all find out about in the Additional Estimates, when we all try to sort out what has gone where. In this situation there is a specific allocation in division 312 which is brought before the Estimates Committee, which is brought before the Parliament, and there is nothing anonymous about it. If there was something anonymous about it Senator Messner would not be able to talk about this $20m. Particulars of the allocations made to specific departments under the provision of this division 312 must be submitted to the Parliament as soon as practicable. Now I do not see anything anonymous or mysterious or dangerous about that sort of situation. We know that a large part, some $20m, is likely to be required by the Department of Social Security, the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Administrative Services for administrative support in respect of the pensions assets test. But no final decisions have been made on the allocation of any part of the $53m provision and determination cannot be formally made in respect of division 312 until the Bill has been enacted.

Surely that is a sensible approach and that is a practical way to go about it. If we had said in the chamber: 'We are going to introduce an assets test. We know it will cost a few bob to introduce. We know we will need more staff. We know we are going to have to train them and we know we will have all these administrative costs but we are not going to tell you what it is likely to cost or where it fits into the Budget situation because the legislation has not been passed', we would have had Senator Messner saying: 'You are outrageous. You are coming into this place and introducing a new program; you are going to sneak the money out of the Advance to the Minister for Finance and you are not telling us everything.' Senator Messner cannot have it both ways, although he tries.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not use that kind of language at all; I was seeking an explanation.
—That is the implication of what he is saying. He is getting an explanation.
—I thank you for it.

—Good, that is terrific. The Chairman of the Public Service Board advised heads of departments and relevant authorities of the approved average staffing levels for 1983-84 and, where applicable, suggested that where additional responsibilities cannot be absorbed within approved levels their Ministers should submit details to the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Division 312 relates only to departmental salaries and related costs of departmental administration and is thus included in the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) in line with normal practice; program expenditures in relation to new initiatives have been provided in Appropriation Bill (No. 2). This normal practice is consistent with the Compact of 1965 on Ordinary Annual Services of the Government and has been followed ever since that time. I am not aware of any previous instances of departmental salaries and administrative expenses having been provided in other than the Ordinary Annual Services Bill.

While the report of the Committee of Government Senators on 'Appropriation Bills and the Ordinary Annual Services of the Government', which formed the basis of the 1965 Compact, dealt primarily with matters that should be excluded from the Ordinary Annual Services Bill, it is clear from the context of the report that salaries, et cetera, were regarded as ordinary annual services and that program expenditures on new policies were not; I think that is an important distinction. For example, paragraph 58 states:

Those quotations give support to three propositions -(1) That ordinary annual expenses are those for the general upkeep of the Government, including the salaries of public servants; (2) That new works and undertakings should be separated from the ordinary annual expenses; and (3) That appropriations for new policies should not be tacked to the annual Appropriation Bill.

It is for that reason that I believe the perfectly reasonable practice of introducing appropriations in this area of division 312 was made. I do not think there is anything mysterious about it. I think it is quite wrong of Senator Messner to give the impression that this was something that was done by the Department of Finance with the Department of Social Security in ignorance. The individual officer who was asked the question first was not in a position to know how much money was involved. But clearly there was discussion between the Department of Finance and between those concerned in the Department as well as to what the amount was likely to be. I believe that this is a perfectly satisfactory way for the Parliament to be able to look at and debate expenditure of this type.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) for his comments. All I am really seeking is the Government's explanation in relation to this matter. TALK.START.PARA: —I have only one question left. I refer to an answer I received when I was talking about the health card and the issuing of the health card to children under 16 years of age or dependent children. When I asked for some statistics, in answer to my question Mr Ayers said:

SPEECH.PARA: We do not keep separate statistics-
this was in regard to children in certain areas-
but my impression from visiting regional offices is that there are very few that I am aware of in this situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

The cover was headed: 'Immigration and Ethnic Affairs: Labor's Policies in Action'. My question-debate in the House of Representatives does not reveal this very clearly-is: Who is responsible for this cover to the statement? What is the intention regarding circulation of this document?

—I am informed by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs that this document was produced by that Department. The number of copies printed was 370. The cost of the materials was $50, the covers being $28. The cost, including labour and overheads was $200. Twelve copies with covers were sent direct to the Table Office by the Department; 150 copies were sent to the House of Representatives with covers direct from the Department; 80 copies were given to the Press Gallery; and a further 150 copies are being produced without covers for the Senate, at my request.

— That possibly explains why the statement was available so late to honourable senators. It was my intention to raise this matter yesterday at the time of the tabling of papers but we did not reach this item on the list. Whilst I know this may not be specifically relevant to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, although it partially involves the printing of its report, this report was not available to honourable senators until 5.30 p.m. yesterday afternoon, 2 November. It had been tabled 24 hours earlier in the House of Representatives. I ask the Minister: On whose instruction did the Department produce a cover for a report which is nothing other than political propaganda? I accept that it is quite legitimate for the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) to have said what he said in his statement. However, I cannot recall in nearly 10 years in the Senate a report being produced in a cover for the Press Gallery, members of the House of Representatives or anyone else that is very clearly a party political document. It is extremely unusual for any party in government. As I said, as far as I am aware it is unique in my experience to produce a cover for a document like this which, as it is presented and as the statement stands, a party manifesto. I would like to know on whose instructions or advice this cover was produced by the Department.

—I am informed, that the document was produced in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) saw the final draft without the cover. It was produced by the Department. In view of the flack that arose from it I think the Minister would prefer that it had not been done. I think Senator Martin is drawing a long bow when she says that that sort of thing has not happened before. It has happened in different forms.
—Come on, tell us how.

—I am about to tell you, Senator Walters, do not be too anxious. I can remember a document produced by the Department of Foreign Affairs that had no fewer than nine photographs of the then Minister for Foreign Affairs in it. I can remember documents of this type in the past. I make no bones about it. I am the spokesman on immigration in this place. When I saw the document I asked that copies be produced for the Senate without the cover before I knew there was any fuss about it in the House of Representatives. We all make errors of judgment. Someone in the Department made an error of judgment. I do not think anyone will be too excited about that sort of thing happening. I am sure it will not happen again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make one comment. The present Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) gets his photograph in publications of the Department of Foreign Affairs and no objection has been raised to that. That is not the same situation as this. In the House of Representatives, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West), said:

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the cover is concerned, I did not authorise the distribution of the cover in this House.

From the answer the Minister has given on the number of covers printed and their distribution, I take it that the Minister so far as he was aware of the cover only meant it for Press Gallery distribution plus 150 extra copies which were going somewhere or other. The matter may well have been an embarrassment to the Minister. One gets that feeling from reading the debate in the House of Representatives. However, it was not clear from the debate in the House of Representatives who had authorised or was responsible for the publication. It is extremely unusual for a department of the Public Service which is meant to be apolitical apparently to initiate, according to what the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) has said, a party political document like this. I point out to Senator Grimes that I would have absolutely no objection to this cover if the crest of the Commonwealth and the words 'Immigration and Ethnic Affairs' were not on it and it had been printed by the Australian Labor Party--

TALK.START.PARA: —And paid for by the Labor Party.

—And paid for by the Labor Party and distributed by the Labor Party in the proper way. I certainly hope that this is the last example of this sort of thing emanating from the Department. I do not know whether I have understood correctly the comments of the Minister for Social Security, but they came across to me as though the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs was unaware of this cover, to a certain point, and certainly unaware that it was to be circulated to members of the House of Representatives. That is not surprising , because he might have expected some embarrassment-the embarrassment that he got when it actually went into the hands of members of the House of Representatives. Have the covers been removed from a number of reports for circulation?

—First, let me say that if the previous Government had produced a document such as that, I would have been the first person to get stuck into that Government. I am not justifying it. It will not happen again. Secondly, it is my understanding that when the objections were raised, covers were removed from at least a large number of those that had not been distributed. As I say, when they hit the deck in this place, I had the covers removed before they were distributed.

—Are there copies of the report out in the community as is? That is what I am concerned about. We can take the Labor policies bit, but the community would not be aware of the tragedy of that sort of thing.

—I think there are 370. I do not think there would be too many out in the community. I am sure that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) would want the document to be distributed in the community, because he stands by the contents if not by the cover. I am told by the officers that about 500 will be produced to go out to the community. I shall obtain further information as to whether they are supposed to have covers and who will print them.

—As I understand the report, it is being printed in 11 languages, which is not an unreasonable number with a report on immigration policies. So one assumes that copies of this statement by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) are going to leaders of ethnic communities. Are they going in these covers printed at the Government's expense when they should have been printed at the expense of the Australian Labor Party? There was a suggestion in debate in the House of Representatives that this document might be circulated within the electorate of Moreton some time this week. Is the Minister aware whether that has happened?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not to the knowledge of the officers present. I shall also seek that information for the honourable senator.
