SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Income Tax Laws Amendment ( Medicare Levy) Bill 1983 was debated in this chamber, Senator Baume, on behalf of the Opposition, raised an anomaly with regard to members of the defence forces who are receiving free or government-paid medical and hospital benefits. The general provision under Medicare is that such employees of the defence services are exempt from paying the one per cent Medicare levy. However, if they have dependent members of their family, they will need to contribute half of the normal levy. If, in addition, the other spouse in the family is earning an income, that spouse has to pay a one per cent levy on that spouse's own income. This extra financial penalty on such a serviceman's family was referred to on 22 September by Senator Baume, and the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes ) then adequately and fully responded with the benefit of advice available then to the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: However, since that time this anomaly has continued to be discussed in the community and, I understand, within the Government. I shall not ask about Cabinet minutes, and so on, but I understand-and it is the understanding of many within the community-that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is concerned about this anomaly and has requested the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating), in writing, to solve the anomaly. My question is: Has the government reconsidered this anomaly? Is it the case that such a one per cent levy will not now be required from the spouse of a serviceman?

TALK.START.PARA: —First, I have no knowledge that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or anyone else has asked the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) about this matter, and I have some difficulty in knowing what the anomaly is. Servicemen have, as part of their pay and conditions, free health care. Therefore, when they signed up in the forces, part of their pay and conditions was free health care. Therefore, there is a perfectly valid argument, put forward by them and accepted by us, that they should not pay the levy, because that would be asking them to pay a levy on top. However, if servicemen have dependent wives and children, under their conditions of pay the dependents do not get free medical treatment. A serviceman at present would take out health insurance to cover those people. It is reasonable that they pay half the levy if they have dependants in those circumstances, because the pay and conditions of servicemen do not cover their wives and dependants. If a serviceman's spouse is earning a taxable income, for the life of me I cannot see that it is an anomaly that the spouse should have to pay the one per cent levy when everyone else in the community has to pay it, with the specific exception of the serviceman who has it as part of his pay and conditions. So I do not know what the anomaly is. All that I can say is that I will seek the information. I have no knowledge of it myself. I can recall no stage in the Cabinet discussions at which the Treasurer or the Minister for Health has discussed this matter since it was settled some time ago, and I understand that the officers present know nothing about it at all.

—Perhaps I may clarify the anomaly as I see it. Let us compare two families-a serviceman who has a wife and no children, and another serviceman who has a wife and no children. The difference between the two couples is that one wife is working and the other wife is not working. With respect to the non-working wife, the serviceman husband, say, is required to pay half of the levy in respect of his dependent spouse. With the other family, the working wife is paying one per cent of her income and the serviceman is required to pay half of the one per cent of his income towards the Medicare levy. If the spouse is working, there is a double contribution. That is a real anomaly. I understand that there has been concern about this not only within the community but also within the Cabinet.

—I will clarify that position for the honourable senator. It is my understanding that the serviceman with the dependent spouse pays half the Medibank levy, but the serviceman without a dependent spouse-in other words, a serviceman whose spouse is working-does not pay half the levy. The spouse pays the one per cent levy on her income. That is my understanding. I may be wrong. It certainly would seem anomolous on the surface. I will clarify the situation for the honourable senator by seeking some information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the hearings for Estimates Committee B I asked several questions. I was concerned about people working with dangerous substances such as pollutants. The Department of Health was kind enough to provide me with information. Referring to workers who are working with materials that are dangerous, I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Does the Department inform workers of how dangerous they are and what precautions should be taken?
The Department has supplied me with a list of products, chemicals and other things that are dangerous. I appreciate its doing so. I further asked about occupational health matters. I said:
My experience in the work force is that no information goes out to the people who are actually doing work in areas where great dangers exist . . .

The Department has also supplied me with a list with probably thousands of names and addresses of people and unions to whom they supply details about dangerous chemicals and substances. But on further examining this matter by asking people working with dangerous substances, I found that they are still not getting that information. I ask the Minister: Can he look into this matter and see that the people actually on the work floor receive this material? In some instances the unions are supplying it; in other instances, because of the many areas of work, they cannot. The information gets lost along the way. Management does not always put this material up for workers to read. It is my experience that people in the work force are not getting the information. I believe it is essential for everyone in the community to try to reduce the number of instances regarding compensation, especially among those working with dangerous materials. I simply ask the Minister whether he could look at this question and see what further provision can be made.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think all honourable senators would share the concern expressed by Senator Elstob about the availability to workers of information on dangerous substances. When the Minister answers the points raised it would be helpful if he could advise us of Commonwealth and State responsibilities in this area, and how we can work to get the best kind of advice sent out and a proper recognition of the area of responsibility. It seems to me that one of the problems here may be jurisdictional. Perhaps that is not the right term, but it is a problem of where responsibility rests and how one lines up that responsibility with the goal which Senator Elstob seeks to achieve .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Elstob has raised a very important question. Many more hours are lost in this country every year from industrial accidents and industrial illnesses than are ever lost from industrial disputes. One of the problems is the great complexity and diversity of industrial processes, and the rapid changes in them. I think Senator Elstob is correct when he says that in a lot of cases some of the accidents and some of the difficulties arise out of ignorance by workers of how to use or get involved in processes because the information simply does not get to them. I think an answer given to Senator Elstob pointed out that the National Health and Medical Research Council has an occupational health publication which is spread fairly widely to the community, but obviously that is not satisfactory.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Baume says, the problem is also one of jurisdiction-I think ' jurisdictional' is probably as good a word as any in this case. In many cases the responsibility is shared particularly between States-in some cases local government bodies as to regulations, for example-and the Commonwealth Government as to the introduction of toxic chemicals and the like. Thus there is a certain amount of confusion as to who is responsible for getting the information out. The Government is very conscious of this. One of the reasons that the Interim Council for Industrial Safety and Health was established by the Minister for Health was so that we could take a rational and more co-ordinated approach at all levels of government, industry and unions to this very real problem, a problem which bedevils all industrial countries. I hope that out of that initiative and new approach would come a better look at how we can get the information to and educate the people at the work face, who are the people, as Senator Elstob said, who suffer in these circumstances. I think there is a much greater consciousness now than there was in the past about the dangers and potential dangers in many areas. I hope that, by a combination of efforts of unions, government and industry and more co-operation, we will reach a more satisfactory situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My comments relate to the issue of Medicare cards. There are two points I want to raise. The first one relates to the system of issue. As I understand it, householders are being asked to fill in forms and send them back, whereupon they are sent the appropriate type of Medicare card. There is an exception, I gather, that applies to people who happen to have private health insurance with Medibank Private. These people are being sent Medicare cards directly. Perhaps the Minister could confirm that.

SPEECH.PARA: I make a comment on behalf of at least some percentage of Medibank Private subscribers. I can understand one of the reasons that that procedure would have been undertaken. It would have saved the expense of sending out the form and handling the paperwork when it came back. However, there are two issues which arise. One is that that card is effective as from 1 February 1984 and that system has given those people who happen to be subscribers to Medibank Private no opportunity at all to make whatever adjustments they might have had in mind between now and 1 February 1984 for the issue of their cards. For example, it is possible that some Medibank Private subscribers are about to go from a single rate to a family rate. They now have to go through all the loopholes and red tape of getting an adjustment to a card when it could have been done at the same time as a card was applied for.

I would also like to know upon what basis Medibank Private took it upon itself to provide its list of subscribers to anyone. I am sure that when people have subscribed to Medibank Private they have believed they were subscribing on the same basis as they would have subscribed to any other private health fund; that is, that their decision to subscribe to that health fund would have between them and the health fund, and not between them and the Government. Details of their medical insurance-namely the type of insurance, whether single or family or whatever-have been handed over by a private health fund to government. That is not a particularly sinister sort of action in this case, as it happens, but one which is right out of order. As a subscriber to Medibank Private, I was unaware that my health fund had taken it upon itself to give to the Government certain personal information. Certainly, the health fund did not inform its subscribers that it was going to do that.

The second point I want to raise relates to some information that has come my way on the issue of Medicare cards. I do not know how this could have happened. Perhaps the Minister or his officers could illuminate us. If they cannot, perhaps they can do some careful checking of this automatic issue of Medicare cards. I have been informed by one of my constituents that her family has had staying with it a visitor from overseas who came to Australia for medical treatment that was not available in the country the person came from, a Pacific country. This week a Medicare card arrived at that home for this citizen of the other country who has since returned home.

TALK.START.PARA: —For all next year.

—Yes, that is right. It is valid from 1 February 1984. One wonders how this could have happened, and one wonders in how many cases it happened. I wonder whether the Minister could illuminate us a little on the system of issuing Medicare cards and as to how a non-Australian citizen, not a member of a medical benefits fund, could receive medical treatment in Australia and receive a Medicare card.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, the Medicare card is a card with a name and a number on it and it facilitates the processing of health insurance claims. It does not do any more than that. Secondly, the Health Insurance Commission is running Medicare. It sent out cards to those who were members of Medibank Private because it has their names and addresses and whatever other details are needed and an identity card can be provided in that way. The Commission also sent out cards to pensioners using names and addresses obtained from the social security system. I cannot understand what the honourable senator means by a breach of privacy in this area . I think there may have been a misconception in what she was saying. I assume that when she says people may want to adjust their status between now and February, she means that they may want to get married or unmarried or change their name, or something like that.
—Or maybe give birth to a child.

—Sure, and if they have a child between now and February and they want that child's name on the card, they can go in and have that done. They can adjust it as much as they like. It is only a card with a number to facilitate the claiming of health insurance. It does not do anything magical. As I have said in the past, it does not entitle one to health care and the absence of a Medicare card does not stop one from getting health care under the Medicare system. It is a means of facilitation.

SPEECH.PARA: As for the person from overseas who got a card, I do not know how that happened . I will try to find that out for Senator Martin. I suggest that in the distribution of the millions of cards which will obviously be necessary the odd thing like that will happen. It is hard to imagine how it did happen but I suppose that person could have been on--

TALK.START.PARA: —The mind boggles.

—I do not think the mind boggles at all. That person would have been receiving some sort of assistance in Australia and the name came from those records. She may well have been a member of Medibank Private. That might be the reason for it happening. If a person from overseas is a member of Medibank Private, then the name may slip through the system. I would not have thought there was a huge number of those people. I will certainly find out how that might have happened and provide the information to Senator Martin.

—I was unable, when the Estimates committees were meeting, to ask some questions in relation to the Department of Health; so on 20 September I put on the Notice Paper a series of questions relating to items which arose out of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts progress report on medical fraud and overservicing. Of particular concern to me was the 'pay-under' system. I have not yet received any information in relation to that. I am happy to await that information if it is to be coming shortly. Otherwise, I would now like to pursue the various items I raised in that question. If the Minister for Social Security is able to assure me that that answer will be forthcoming fairly rapidly, I will not pursue the matter now.

—Fortunately, one of the officers here does know about Senator Macklin's question and assures me that the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) is in the process of giving him an answer. He expects it to be next week or the week after. I have no knowledge of the question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Grimes may recall that there was a lot of discussion in the Estimates Committee on the backlog in the processing of direct billing claims. I asked whether details in relation to the backlog of bulk bill claims on a State by State basis could be given, including the period of backlog and the number of claims made. I am surprised that the Department of Health would forget Tasmania, particularly as it has a Minister from Tasmania. I have the information from New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland, South Australia , Western Australia, and Australia as a whole. I know for a fact that there is a backlog in Tasmania. I would be more than a little surprised if the Department does not know that Tasmanians are a little sensitive about being left out repeatedly, but if the Minister representing the Minister for Health cannot get across to the Department that Tasmania exists then I am just not quite sure how we can do it.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, could I have the figures for Tasmania? There are a number of other questions on that matter, so perhaps including them now will save time. Is it a fact that a 'work to rule' or a 'go slow' is still going on in the Medibank claims processing centre at Moonee Ponds, Melbourne? Does that mean that there has been a serious deterioration in the processing time since I received these figures, which apply until 9 September 1983? Has the backlog grown? I have had a number of complaints, indeed ever since the Minister answered Senator Tate's question in the Senate about how wonderful it was all going to be when Medicare came in and there would no longer be any problem in this area. Complaints have continued to roll in from my Tasmanian constituents and, as he would well know, there is a cash flow problem in the area of self-employed doctors. If the Minister could answer those questions I would be grateful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very happy to be a Tasmanian and to represent Tasmania but I make it perfectly clear that I am not one of those Tasmanians, as the vast majority is not, who run around looking for lists or maps without Tasmania tacked on them. The Tasmanian bulk billing claims are processed at Moonee Ponds in Victoria with the rest of the claims from Victoria. Tasmanian and Victorian claims are processed together because that is an efficient and sensible way to do it. Hence there is no separating out of the Tasmanian figures. The processing figures given to the honourable senator referred to the place where they were processed. Frankly, I do not believe that one person in Tasmania is going to lose any sleep tonight over the fact that Senator Walters did not get a separate list for Tasmania for the bulk billing of doctors in that State, but she can try.
—I am not suggesting for one moment that they are. I am wanting the figures.

—Senator Walters should not get all sensitive. The good senator talked about Tasmanians being sensitive about being left off lists and maps and about how it was surprising that even though we had a Minister from Tasmania- that is, me-the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) did not give a list with Tasmania on it. She went on at considerable length and I am just pointing out that I am not going to enter into that barney with her. On 21 October I am told, approximately, 1.8 million bulk billing processing services were outstanding; there were 2 million on 9 September. There has been an improvement in all States except New South Wales where some difficulty was experienced in containing the backlog, particularly with regard to initial claims. In South Australia and Western Australia the processing of the claims is up to date. In Queensland it is almost up to date. In Victoria the situation was progressing satisfactorily until work bans were imposed on 5 October. Despite those work bans the cheques have been going out and the situation has not worsened; that is, whilst the office is not up to date it is not getting any further behind.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that a meeting was held today regarding the Moonee Ponds situation and that the dispute is now settled. The cheques will be sent out today, which will solve the situation in that Victorian office. I am sure that as the methods improve, as they have been improving, the backlog will not cause any difficulty.

As an anecdotal counter to the sort of thing about which Senator Walters spoke, I add that only today I received a letter from a doctor in Hobart who told me that he objected to the way in which some medical practitioners in Tasmania were carrying on about what they consider are inordinate delays. He found the system very effective and did not mind waiting two weeks for his money in view of the money that he got and, in fact, he welcomed the introduction of Medicare because he believed the bulk billing system would become more efficient under that system with more experience, as it did under Medibank. Not all doctors are complaining about the system. The answer to Senator Walters's question is: No, I cannot give her the separate figures for Tasmania. I suppose I could ask someone in the Moonee Ponds office to go through the postcode numbers and separate that specific group of figures in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, I would appreciate it.
—If the honourable senator really needs that--
—Yes, I would.

—I will try to do so. I really think that sort of effort, in view of the cost to the public purse, would not assist the progress of this chamber at all. What we need to do is have an efficient system of bulk billing, as I am sure the honourable senator would agree. The most efficient way to do it on a cost benefit basis would be to incorporate Tasmanian bulk billing into the Moonee Ponds office. As I say, I will make some attempt, as Senator Walters insists, but I make it perfectly clear that I am not doing it for chauvinistic reasons. I am not doing it to prevent the sorts of remarks which Senator Walters made earlier in her questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received complaints. If a delay of two weeks were involved I do not think for one minute there would be any complaints. To me, two weeks would be a very reasonable time for anyone to put up with sending in their claims and getting them back. That is not the sort of time about which I have had complaints. Senator Grimes may have received a complaint today from someone-he might be a good socialist Labor fellow-who believes that everyone should be bulk billed and should be under government pay. He probably believes doctors should be nationalised, but that is not the view of the majority of doctors in Tasmania. Indeed, the complaints are rolling in. A person phoned me today. In that case a six weeks delay was involved. That is a different story from Senator Grimes's two weeks.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the claims which have been rejected for perhaps a small mistake on the form. In Victoria and New South Wales an extraordinary number of weeks seems to be involved. In New South Wales the figure is 9.9 weeks. Obviously that figure is only an average. If the Minister were to provide me with the Tasmanian figures we might find that Tasmania is much worse off. We might find that the Tasmanian figures are much worse, for some reason, than the figures for Victoria . I believe the Minister should be willing to ascertain whether that is so, particularly in view of the fact that one of his own senators, Senator Tate, has conveyed complaints from my State. I am not the only one who has received complaints. It is for this reason that I ask the Minister to separate the Tasmanian backlog from the Victorian one. Finally, on the question of bulk billing, can the Minister explain to me in great detail how Medicare will overcome all these problems caused by strikes, mistakes in numbers and so on? I would be most interested.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a couple of comments in this general area. I accept what the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) said; that is, for reason of efficiency and operation of the Department of Social Security certain administrative arrangements should be made. No one is contesting that. It may be proper for the Moonee Ponds office to carry out this procedure. Senator Grimes was a co-signatory to a Senate report on evaluation. He will recall that the question of accountability came up. I do not know the details in Tasmania, but it is a reasonable exercise in accountability-quite apart from any questions of politics, ideology or anything else-for people to be able to text the efficiency of a system under which they are operating. I would have thought the information being sought, just on the grounds of accountability alone, was reasonable. I am grateful that the Minister has indicated that he will try to get the information.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of delays, I wish to raise the problems which exist in New South Wales. Senator Walters mentioned a figure of 9.9 weeks. The problem arises in relation to people who run pathology practices. I start off by saying that I operate on the assumption that most members of the medical profession and pathologists within the profession are ethical, professional and decent. I would say further that the practice of pathology is notable for the fact that it operates at a high volume and low profit margin. Indeed, that is what it should do. The pathology rebates have been structured so that people get a smaller return on each service, but because there are so many services they can make a living. The problems which a pathology practice have relate to its high capital needs; the high amount of cash and overdraft servicing, which is part of the business; the relatively large staff and the fact that that staff is expensive and trained. It is a very expensive business to run. As I say, it is a high volume fairly low turnover practice. A pathology practice in Sydney, with which I have had dealings, a practice which I found to be very ethical, very responsible and very professional, is concerned that its current experience with Medibank involves a five-week turnaround time for the payment of accounts. This five-week turnaround time is putting that practice in some jeopardy and placing it under some strain in terms of its own needs to service money and to operate its business. I ask the Minister, in addition to what Senator Walters has already asked him--

TALK.START.PARA: —With that cough, you will have to change your brand of cigarettes.

—I am grateful, Senator, for that very healthy and constructive interjection. I notice that Senator Elstob remains very healthy on his cigarette smoking. Perhaps that will be the subject of my next lot of questions to the Minister. I wish to ask the Minister several questions. Is the Minister aware of the particular problems which are associated with pathology services in terms of the need for speedy payments to meet the continuing high labour and capital leasing costs? The questions are important in terms of the efficiency of the new Medicare system which is now to be introduced, legislation for which the Parliament has approved. I also ask: Have any arrangements been made with the Health Insurance Commission for payments to be made to pathology practices promptly? That really should not mean a five-week turnaround. People have been talking about a five-day turnaround. However, that five-day turnaround should in fact become a reality because without that, people who often take very small margins, will be put under some strain.

SPEECH.PARA: Can the Minister assure us that the present lag time of five weeks will be reduced to five days, as is being claimed by the Health Insurance Commission will be the case? Unless this happens there will be considerable difficulty. Will the Minister agree that without prompt payment many pathology services will be placed under great strain and that one could in fact drive a pathology service to the wall simply by interfering with its cash flow and its capacity to service its business?

I accept that the Minister is approaching this matter in a fairly constructive sense and I hope that he can give us some answers to these problems. They are real problems in Sydney. Many of the people concerned are offering a public service and are operating at a very professional and ethical level.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry if I gave Senator Walters the impression that I believed that all claims were settled within two weeks. I was quoting from a letter I received today. Certainly, the delay has been longer with projections and claims that have to be re-examined. In the case of those who have been serviced at Moonee Ponds the delays have been longer still because of the industrial dispute. I have never made the claim that the introduction of Medicare will stop industrial disputes any more than they can be stopped in any other area.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume raised important questions and the answers to his questions partly answer the problems that Senator Walters raised. Of course, as Senator Baume says, certain services, particularly pathology services I would imagine, have a fairly high cash turnover because of wages, et cetera and therefore prompt payments are needed if they are to bulk bill in these circumstances. The big advantage of the Medicare system over the existing system is that there are no eligibility criteria, there is no need for the matching with social security records to ascertain whether a person has a pensioner health card and so on as is the case now. For these reasons, the Health Insurance Commission with great confidence says that it will get that processing time down to five days. I would have thought that five days was a very satisfactory turnover time for pathology services or any other services. I think that because of the basic simplicity of the system, because of the experience the Health Insurance Commission has had and, of course, with modern technology, we will be able to get this turnover time down to five days.

I certainly agree with Senator Baume that there is a case, if that were not possible, for some specific services perhaps to receive special treatment. However, I do not believe that will be necessary because with the lack of the need for matching and the lack of the need to chase eligibility criteria which will exist in the new system we will, with modern technology, the new cards and all the rest, end up with a turnover in the order of five days. I think that will be to everyone's benefit-the patients, the doctors, the pathologists, whoever they are.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there any possibility that claims can be sent from Tasmania and payment received within five days? We would need the co- operation of Australia Post for this to happen.

—The good senator may or may not know that every night I lie in my bed in Launceston I am frequently woken up by planes-they are things with wings that fly and change their pitch as they go over. Things are frequently sent backwards and forwards from Tasmania to Moonee Ponds on those planes. In fact, they can be sent overnight in this modern world. So I do not think that the fact that Tasmania is separated from the mainland by a couple of hundred miles of Bass Strait should prevent us from being efficient in this area.

—I am really well aware of the aircraft that fly over. It is the directions to the pilots that worry me. I wonder whether Senator Grimes will direct the pilots to fly low but inconspicuously over Tasmania so as not to disturb the natives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Grimes answered a question, I think today, concerning nutramagin and pregestimil and a conflict that had occurred between the Government and a particular pharmaceutical company. I take Senator Grimes's mind back to an adjournment debate which we had here some weeks ago in which I raised with him the question of a group of patients who require the drug cyclophosphamide and who are being caught, as it were, as the meat in the sandwich in the same conflict between government and the pharmaceutical company. The people, who are suffering from the disease dermatomyositis and for whom this drug is required on a continuing basis, are being severely disadvantaged. The proposition that I put to the honourable senator at that time was that I did not care how the issue was resolved. That was a battle which government and the pharmaceutical company would work out in their own way and in their own time and that would depend on the merits of the case. But in the meantime, a group of patients, small in number, for whom this drug is necessary and is needed on a continuing basis are being disadvantaged. The only way in which they can get the drug is to be admitted to hospital.

SPEECH.PARA: I will admit in this Committee that there have been occasions in the past-I imagine Senator Grimes might make the same admission-when I have had patients admitted to hospital for very brief periods in order to comply with the ridiculous prescribing requirements for certain essential pharmaceutical agents. However, those days are behind me because I am no longer in active medical practice. It is undesirable, anyhow, that people with these diseases should have to go to those lengths. The Minister promised to try to provide me with some information and tell me what solution had been reached. Is he now in a position to do so?

TALK.START.PARA: —Indeed, I did. From memory, the Department of Health was about to make provision for people suffering from dermatomyositis to get cyclophosphamide through the out-patient departments of hospitals. However, I apologise profusely to Senator Baume that he has not received the answer by now. The answer has gone out of my head. I will promptly, on leaving this place tonight, see whether I can get the answer to him as quickly as possible. I am also interested as to what sort of solution has come up. I have asked the officers present tonight but, unfortunately, none of them is connected with the section which has information in this matter. But I will certainly seek that information for the honourable senator.

—The Minister for Social Security might remember that during a meeting of the Estimates Committee I asked what amount was paid to Dr Deeble in the last financial year and how much it was expected would be paid this year. I got a reply that the Public Service Board approved a temporary employment for Dr Deeble at the level 5 Second Division rate for a three-month period commencing 22 March 1983. The Public Service Board subsequently approved an extension of that period of employment until 30 September 1983. The amount paid for the three-month period was $12,734.96. I was also told that it was not expected that that amount would be exceeded for the next three months. However, I find that today, 3 November, Dr Deeble is still speaking in the health area. I ask the Minister: Is this a voluntary capacity or is he still being paid by the Department of Health?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is as was previously provided. Dr Deeble was getting the equivalent of $50,000 per year which is the salary for a level 5 officer in the Second Division. He is no longer being paid by the Department of Health. He is back at the Australian National University.

SPEECH.PARA: Consideration interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In conformity with the sessional order relating to the adjournment of the Senate, I formally put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Temporary Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
The Temporary Chairman having reported accordingly-

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Mr Kevin McAlister-Taxation Evasion and Avoidance-Uranium Mining in Northern Territory-Commonwealth Government Funding of Northern Territory

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr Kevin McAlister-Taxation Evasion and Avoidance-Uranium Mining in Northern Territory-Commonwealth Government Funding of Northern Territory

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In conformity with the sessional order relating to the adjournment of the Senate, I formally put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

I draw the attention of honourable senators to the fact that today is the last sitting day on which the Senate has the services of Mr Kevin McAlister who, for many years, has looked after the needs of honourable senators in this place. Mr McAlister is to retire tomorrow. He commenced duty in Parliament House in 1968. In his time he has worked in all the attendant positions, including in the chamber and in the Government and Opposition corridors. I am sure many honourable senators will be familiar with the courteous and unassuming manner with which he has carried out his work. On behalf of honourable senators I offer my best wishes to Kevin and Joyce, his wife of almost 44 years, and wish them both good health and a long and happy retirement.
The President is aware of the fact that Mr McAlister is retiring and has asked me to pass on his best wishes for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Government I would like to join with you, Mr Deputy President, and, I am sure, with all honourable senators in wishing Mr Kevin McAlister and his wife well in his retirement. Mr McAlister has lived in Canberra for along time. He arrived in Canberra from Captains Flat where he operated a barber shop. He was a barber in Canberra from 1963 until 1968.
—I wish I had known.

—We all wish we had known that. I am frequently in need of assistance in that regard. Kevin started in Parliament House on 19 August 1968. Since then he has worked in Parliament continuously except for an 11-week period in 1980 when he was ill. During the 15 years and three months he has been here there have been five Prime Ministers. I do not think he has had anything to do with the turnover of Prime Ministers in that time. We are pleased to know that Kevin is staying in Canberra with his family during the summer months and will be travelling to the north coast during the winter months where he can take up his interests in cricket, bowling and rugby league. As an old rugby league player and as someone who would certainly like to be travelling north each winter, I wish Kevin well as I am sure all Government senators do. I hope that Kevin and his wife enjoy their retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, on behalf of the Opposition I would like to add our support to your words and to those which have been expressed by Senator Grimes. Kevin McAlister is a friend to many people on both sides of the chamber. Many on this side know him well. We have had a chance to get to know him very closely. He and I have sometimes discussed medical and professional matters over the years. Many would not know that Kevin left school at a very young age in a hard time. Only today we were discussing the capacity of young people to go out rabbit trapping to raise a few bob. We were discussing the fact that when I was a young fellow I would go out and do a bit of rabbit-trapping and hang all the skins up ready to sell to raise a bit of money. Those were the days when there was a good trade in this kind of thing.

SPEECH.PARA: He also told me that his ties to Canberra are quite extensive. He has children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren in Canberra. He is blessed with a large family. We completely endorse his decision not to move away and to stay here where his roots are. We hope we will see him in Parliament House. He has been courteous and friendly to us all. The only thing that is really hard to take is that he supports the Parramatta team.

TALK.START.PARA: —So do I.
—Senator Grimes does as well. That is doubly bad. We will see if we cannot do something about that next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to speak on the same subject. I should say in explanation to Mr McAlister that I asked Senator Peter Baume to speak on behalf of the Opposition because I was going to speak on less pleasant topics. I did not want to mix up the general good wishes for Mr McAlister with the other matters that I wish to raise on the adjournment. Perhaps I should say, personally, that I express the same good wishes to him on his retirement as have been expressed by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) on behalf of the Government and by Senator Peter Baume on behalf of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to detain the Senate at great length, but I wish to refer to a question and answer in this afternoon's Question Time. The question was directed to Senator Walsh by Senator Cook. It was described by Senator Cook as one of the Christo Moll series. He referred to a letter to the editor in the West Australian of 22 October, signed by Mr John Gillett, the senior partner of a Perth-based law firm, Northmore Hale Davy and Leake. The question, in part, stated:

Is the Minister aware that in that letter Mr Gillett claims that the statement made to the Senate by the Minister, namely that Northmore Hale Davy and Leake had set up the first tax evasion scheme for Christo Moll, was 'untruthful'? Is Mr Gillett's assertion accurate?
I would like to read that letter, which appeared in the West Australian on 22 October 1983. It states:
On page 19 of the West Australian (October 20) it was reported that Senator Walsh said that our firm set up the first tax-evasion scheme for Christo Moll.
This firm did not set up and has never set up or devised a tax-evasion scheme for Christo Moll or any other person.
The untruthful statement by Senator Walsh is defamatory and we would have taken action had it not been protected by parliamentary privilege.

It is quite clear from the answer given today that Senator Walsh has not chosen to accept that invitation. He has not repeated it outside the House and therefore has not given Mr Gillett the chance to take action as Mr Gillett said he would like to. However, I wish to refer to the answer which was given by Senator Walsh, which is a very sad attempt to obscure the difference between tax evasion and tax avoidance. I think Senator Walsh is quite well instructed in these matters. I think he has no difficulty in his mind in distinguishing between tax evasion and tax avoidance, the former being illegal and the latter being legal and being referred to by various terms such as tax minimisation and so on. I know that Senator Walsh is well informed because he has made that clear in debates in this place. I know that he is a member of a farming partnership. I am sure that he understands that in setting up the affairs of a farming partnership and rearranging interests, action is taken by lawyers and accountants to ensure that stock is transferred at correct values and that things are done so as not to attract unnecessary income tax, stamp duty and so on. I am sure that he is quite familiar with the idea of tax minimisation as part of the normal commercial life of Australia. I would very much doubt whether he would arrange his own affairs in a way to maximise tax; rather he would do what a normal prudent man would do and I am sure he would act on professional advice.
Senator Walsh, in responding to the question this afternoon, used some words. Perhaps I should use the words that he used. He said:

I have a number of comments to make. Firstly, Senator Chaney has placed on record officially in the Senate that Christo Moll was a client of that firm. Secondly, some lawyers make a living through casuistry. Mr Gillett has used the term 'tax evasion'. Many lawyers would quibble about what is evasion and what is avoidance. That is another possibility.

I simply wish to say that an allegation which was the original allegation by Senator Walsh on 19 October, that that legal firm had set up a tax evasion scheme for Christo Moll, is an allegation of complicity in illegal conduct. That is a very offensive statement. That is no doubt why Mr Gillett said that if the statement were made outside this place of privilege, it would be the subject of defamation action.

So much for that, Mr Deputy President, but in a quite extraordinary way Senator Walsh went on, slid on, skidded on-or whatever one does in these circumstances- to mention Sir Victor Garland. This was apparently done because it came to mind that he once had a complaint from a solicitor in Melbourne who apparently had something to do at some stage with Sir Victor Garland's affairs and who, he tells us later, is now facing criminal charges-that is, the lawyer-in relation to tax evasion. This is a classic example of an attempt to roll a whole lot of things up so as to leave some dirt attaching to somebody. I cannot see any reason why Sir Victor Garland should be mentioned in this answer in the way that he was, and I wish to reject any suggestion that might be implicit in that mention that Sir Victor Garland is in some way involved in things which are out of order. There have of course been odd mentions of him in this place. Because of Senator Walsh's record of persistent attempts to blacken other people's names , I have kept a copy of a letter which was sent to Sir Victor Garland by the Acting Deputy Commissioner of Taxation of the Australian Taxation Office in Perth, and I would like to read that letter:
Dear Sir Victor
I refer to your letter of 21 September 1983 and your earlier 'phone call asking for written assurance in respect of matters mentioned hereunder.
After examination of income tax returns lodged in respect of yourself and entities with which you have been involved I am able to confirm that:
(a) You were not a person to whom the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax-Vendors) Act 1982 had application.

(b) Neither would you have incurred a liability under the proposed amendments to that legislation either in respect of those which were defeated in parliament on 2 June 1983 or those presently before parliament.
(c) There was no involvement in artificial schemes of tax avoidance.
Yours sincerely
(R. S. CONEY) Acting Deputy Commissioner of Taxation

As I say, I am at a loss as to why Sir Victor should be brought into this answer and rolled up in the reply in this way. I think in fairness to him-he after all is still serving Australia and indeed this Government in the position of High Commissioner in London-I make it clear that he has that letter from the Commissioner of Taxation, and indeed I seek leave to incorporate that letter in full in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Dear Sir Victor
I refer to your letter of 21 September 1983 and your earlier 'phone call asking for written assurance in respect of matters mentioned hereunder.
After examination of income tax returns lodged in respect of yourself and entities with which you have been involved I am able to confirm that:
(a) You were not a person to whom the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax-Vendors) Act 1982 had application.

(b) Neither would you have incurred a liability under the proposed amendments to that legislation either in respect of those which were defeated in parliament on 2 June 1983 or those presently before parliament.
(c) There was no involvement in artificial schemes of tax avoidance.
Yours sincerely
(R. S. CONEY) Acting Deputy Commissioner of Taxation

TALK.START.PARA: —I do believe that we all have a difficult task in this place in using privilege in the way in which it was intended. It was intended to provide us with the opportunity to raise matters of public importance fearlessly. I believe that in this case, as on other occasions, Senator Walsh has gone beyond his duty in this matter. He has merely sought to blacken people's names quite unjustifiably. If he has the courage of his convictions he should face up to the suggestion made by Mr Gillett in his letter to the newspapers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned about three statements. First, as a lawyer, Senator Chaney should know that the truth is not of itself a defence against an action for defamation. Secondly, Senator Chaney made the distinction between tax evasion and tax avoidance. I do not know whether in making that distinction he intended to imply that in fact the firm of Northmore Hale Davy and Leake was involved in a tax avoidance or tax minimisation scheme, or whatever one would like to call it for Mr Moll. If that is the case or if Senator Chaney was acknowledging that that was the case, judgment as to what is avoidance and what is evasion is ultimately made in the courts, but in this case Caesar is judging Caesar. Senator Chaney seems to be acknowledging that the firm has arranged, or whatever verb one would like to use, a tax minimisation scheme for Mr Moll.

SPEECH.PARA: He asked why I mentioned Mr Collie. The reason for that is that at the time-I think it was about 1979 or it may have been 1980-I was reporting matters which concerned Mr Collie and also concerned some companies once owned by Sir Victor Garland, as Senator Chaney has said. I received a telex from Mr Collie vehemently denying that he had any association with any unsavoury or illegal activities, and I note that criminal charges have since been laid against him. I mentioned that because I believe it has some relevance in that denials without any corroborating evidence are not accepted by me, particularly when there is other evidence to suggest complicity. Mr Collie also, as I mentioned--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. What Senator Walsh has said is that he made an attack on Mr Collie and Mr Collie vehemently denied it but that he has subsequently been charged. I would have thought that that is the very time when propriety would require that one did not refer further to the matter at least until the charges have been heard and the court has determined one way or another. I think it is quite contrary to the practice of the Senate, as well as to the Standing Orders, for that matter to be debated whilst the man is facing a charge. I ask, Mr Deputy President, that you seek from Senator Walsh an assurance that he will not deal further with the circumstances of a man who has been charged but apparently not yet tried.

—The question of the sub judice rule is one of the more difficult ones to administer in this chamber. The rule basically is that anything said which would prejudice the fair conduct of a trial is out of order. So far Senator Walsh has not said anything which in my view would prejudice a fair trial, but I ask him to refrain from continuing in any line that might affect a fair trial of the individual concerned.

—Very well, Mr Deputy President. I believe I have done no more than state facts which are already on the public record, including that last fact. This is on the public record because I said in the Senate in or around 1980 that I had asked Mr Collie to supply the details since he disputed the facts. He did not respond to that invitation. I then went on to extend a similar invitation to Mr Gillett. It was for that reason that that was mentioned, and for that reason only.

SPEECH.PARA: I did also mention today, and I have attempted to follow this up but there has not been sufficient time, that Mr Moll has requested the firm of Northmore Hale Davy and Leake to hand over documents-or I may have said that, in which case it was a minor error on my part. The Australian Federal Police have received a letter from Mr Moll in which he authorises the firm of Northmore Hale Davy and Leake to make available all records for the period in which the firm acted on his behalf. That was reported in the Melbourne Age on Tuesday of this week. I seek leave to incorporate the article from the Age of that day in Hansard to save the time of the Senate.
Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
MOLL FREES RECORDS FOR POLICE SCRUTINY
By Marshall Wilson and Stephen Foley
A Perth legal firm will be asked to hand over confidential documents relating to private investments by clients of the financier Christo Moll, including payments to the Liberal Party.
Federal Police have received a letter from Mr Moll in which he authorises the firm Northmore, Hale, Davy and Leake to make available all records for the period in which the firm acted on his behalf.
The letter specifically isolates:
Gemstone valuations and delivery receipts contained in a file marked '' confidential clients''.
Schedules of overseas bank accounts including some in the United States.
Cash payment sheets and codification ledger detailing cash paid overseas and donations made to the Liberal Party.
Copies of contracts and schedules relating to Mr Moll's half share interest in the firm Quartermaine Travel in Perth.
The file marked ''Minutes of Confidential Meetings-Clients''.
The confidential files on firms Mogill Ltd and Quamolt GmbH together with the proforma financial statements.
The hand-written letter dated 18 October arrived at Federal Police headquarters in Perth this week.

Two weeks ago the Energy and Resources Minister, Senator Walsh, alleged in Parliament that the Opposition's Senate Leader, Senator Chaney, had been an active partner in the firm Northmore, Hale, Davy and Leake in 1973 ''at the time that the firm set up the first tax evasion scheme for Christo Moll''.
Senator Chaney denied any involvement in advising on tax evasion schemes during his years with the firm, which he left in 1974.
Senator Chaney said in a statement that he was aware that Mr Moll was at some stage a client of the firm but he ''was never involved in personal dealings with him''.
In Perth the firm of Northmore, Hale, Davy and Leake has strongly denied setting up tax-evasion schemes for Mr Moll.
Mr Moll has also written personally to the Attorney-General, Senator Evans, seeking protection and immunity from prosecution to help police inquiries into his business affairs.
The registered letter was posted in Nice, France, on 24 October.
Mr Moll, a former prominent WA businessman, has admitted to having been the head of a money-moving operation which used couriers to move millions of dollars into Swiss bank accounts.
He left Australia in 1979 after the sudden collapse of his investment conglomerate.

An officer of the Federal Police who accompanied an 'Age' reporter to Austria last month to interview Mr Moll, has submitted a report to Canberra indicating Mr Moll could play a major role in identifying areas of irregularity arising from documents handed over.
The Federal Police in Perth believe more than $200 million may have been moved through the Moll pipeline.

TALK.START.PARA: —That article specifies a number of specific items which Mr Moll has asked the Federal Police to recover from the firm. Finally, my office has attempted, through Mr Beazley's office, to find out whether the Police have in fact made the request and whether they have in fact received the documents. I am afraid I have not got a reply at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I regret that I have to take up the time of the Senate now but, as you would be aware, Question Time this week and particularly today has been very crowded and I have not been able to raise a matter that I wish to bring up before the Senate retires for the weekend. I refer briefly once again to the problem associated with the development of the uranium mines in the Northern Territory. There has been a most incredible situation in the last two or three weeks with the wrangling within the Government, in public and in private. Of course, the media have been full of all the variations of the Government, the Cabinet and the left wing of the Australian Labor Party and the machinations and moves that were changing day by day. A very good description of events appears in today's Australian Financial Review in an article referring to uranium double dealings. It is quite an interesting article. The first paragraph reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The political argument on uranium policy is getting into a rare old mess. Principles and expediency have become hopelessly intermingled, to the extent that hardly anyone in the Government or in the Labor Party has a clue what the real argument is about.
The article finishes with these words:
But it is absurd for Australia to forgo a valuable export industry for the sake of mildly inconveniencing the world nuclear medicine and nuclear power industries.

In the last day or so there has been talk of compensation. It is very interesting to see what the Director of the Bureau of the Northern Land Council had to say on After 8 this morning. I refer to Wesley Lanhupuy, an Aboriginal person from Galiwinku. The interviewer said:

Well, it's not just the Northern Territory Government that would contemplate seeking compensation for the halting of the uranium mines. Wesley Lanhupuy, Director of the Northern Land Council says that mining royalties have, until now , enabled Aboriginal traditional owners to provide services for their own communities and to invest in the Territory without having to put a hand out for Government funds.
Mr Lanhupuy said:

Well, I think the concept of accepting mining, and I'm not necessarily saying uranium mining, slowly gained over a period of time, and they have seen the benefits that they are receiving now because of the established existing mines and it assisted them in investing in the Northern Territory stabilised their communities even though there might be signs of distortion to what benefits they are receiving. For example, you are very much aware of the reports that the Institute of Aboriginal Affairs has done at Oenpelli and I think in all from my personal observation, I think that Aboriginal people are better off with another source of funding which makes them self-sufficient.
He goes on to say:
Well, the Land Council has not actually discussed that-
that is, seeking compensation from the Federal Government-

but we will certainly be making inquiries for the people that are the recipients of the existing royalties that we are receiving to get their views but there is no doubt that we could be approaching the Federal Government on compensation because it is going to deprive them of a source of income.
The question that I should have liked to ask the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) today is as follows:

I refer to a Press Conference held by the Northern Territory Chief Minister, Paul Everingham, last Tuesday, at which he said he had instructed the Territories Co-ordinator General to look into the question of compensation for the Territory if the future development of the uranium industry is stopped.

I refer also to a transcript of this morning's After 8 program in Darwin, in which the Director of the Northern Land Council, Wesley Lanhupuy, said there is no doubt the Council could be approaching the Federal Government on the compensation issue. I ask the Minister: (1) does he acknowledge the necessity for compensation to be paid to (A) the mining companies involved who have, in good faith, spent millions of dollars in carrying out the Government's requirements for development and to (B) the traditional Aboriginal owners of the land who have given their permission for mining to be undertaken and stand to lose some two hundred million dollars in royalties if, as I understand it, it is not.

(2) In view of the precedent for compensation which has been set by the Federal and Tasmanian Governments concerning the Franklin Dam issue, does the Minister acknowledge that no matter what amount the Government may settle on, compensation for the Northern Territory could not make up for the loss of the uranium industry, and
(3) Is it the intention of the Government to review the decision and to allow the development of the uranium industry in the Northern Territory?
One would think that after all the mess and wrangle-the absolutely incredible situation that has eventuated-that that would be the correct thing to do.

I wish to refer briefly to another matter that concerns me. On Tuesday of this week, when we were discussing the Northern Territory Grant (Special Assistance) Bill, I was complaining about various situations in the Northern Territory and I was querying the necessity for a review by the Commonwealth Government into the memorandum of articles for the funding of the Northern Territory by the Commonwealth Government. Today I received a letter which concerns me considerably. I refer to a letter to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) from Mr Ian Tuxworth, MLA, Minister for Community Development, Northern Territory. The letter states:

In response to your telex of November 2, I must ask whether you have yet had an opportunity to consider the contents of my letter of October 11. This letter was in response to yours of September 5 and effectively responded to your later correspondence of October 6, received in my office after the despatch of my letter.
This letter outlined the Northern Territory Government's understanding of the conditions applicable to the transfer of functions to my Department from the Commonwealth Government.
This included a reference to an expectation on the part of the Commonwealth that-
' . . . the Northern Territory Government will make arrangements for the introduction of an appropriate scale of charges for service'
You will see that this is in accord with the Commonwealth Government's own intentions prior to the transfer of this function, that is prior to self- government.
I am surprised, therefore, that you regard this as a departure from the spririt from the original agreement.
Further, it is my clear understanding that the very purpose of the title attaching to the land on which the Aboriginal communities reside is to provide facilities exclusive to their own use.
In effect, this is in regard to electricity charges. The letter continues:
In effect, these facilities are not available to the wider population, unless by invitation.

It is necessary that I should reaffirm the Northern Territory Government's policy that wherever possible all sections of the community should receive similar treatment at the hands of Government with respect to the payment of all services.
The user groups in these cases do have the capacity to meet these charges and it is irresponsible and contrary to a policy of self determination and self reliance to continue the current situation.
The Northern Territory Government has not diverted funds for expenditure in Aboriginal communities to other areas. Your threat-
a rather surprising comment from a Federal Minister-

to interfere with the memorandum of understanding and to direct the Northern Territory to use general purpose grants to satisfy Federal Government aspirations is repugnant but is the type of jackbooted approach that has become familiar to us since have dealings with you.
The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is getting quite a reputation. The letter goes on:

If the Commonwealth wishes to vary the agreement reached on July 17, 1978 and provide special purpose grants to absolve aboriginal groups of meeting their financial responsibilities, I would be only too pleased to have our officers meet and agree on the level of additional funding required to satisfy your wishes.

On 17 July 1978, the Commonwealth Government devolved upon the Northern Territory responsibility for providing services to the Aboriginal communities. This was done in a letter from the then Prime Minister to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. For its part, the Commonwealth provided a level of funding in the Northern Territory's general purpose grants equivalent to the amount of expenditure at that time and it required from the Northern Territory an undertaking that the Northern Territory would introduce charges for those services, such as power and water, that it was providing. The Northern Territory did not plunge headlong into this exercise and create any unreasonable harassment for the Aboriginal communities and camps concerned. However, in recent days it has been criticised by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Commonwealth Grants Commission for not making any effort at all to recoup costs in these areas as it had formerly agreed to do with the Commonwealth. Earlier this year the Northern Territory Government advised the communities concerned that they would be charged for power and water for those communities living inside town areas and that they should make provision for those charges in their budgets for 1983-84. The Aboriginal communities have taken the very strong position of refusing to pay at all for their services becuse they regard themselves as a special group and they believe that these services should be provided to them by the Government at no cost. Perhaps the Federal Government should pick up the tab.

The Northern Territory Government, in line with its undertaking to the Commonwealth, has not been prepared to accept this and has indicated that it will disconnect services where people refuse to pay their accounts. As a result of representations made by Aboriginal communities to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Holding has advised the Northern Territory Government that he will be seeking to have the financial arrangements with the Northern Territory altered so that funds can be taken from the Northern Territory and given to the Aboriginals concerned at the Minister's discretion. What arrogance!

This proposition is equivalent to tearing up the constitutional arrangements that exist between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory. I, as a senator representing the Northern Territory, seek a clear and unequivocal understanding from the Federal Government that the current arrangements will not be interfered with, that the general purpose funding arrangements will be honoured and the Commonwealth will not direct the Northern Territory to spend funds from the general purose grants on those things that interest the Commonwealth. I further seek an understanding from the Federal Minister that he will ask the people concerned to meet their community obligations and make appropriate arrangements to pay their bills. I think it would be a very good idea if the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs stopped interfering in State-like matters and arrangements that have been made between the Federal Government and the Northern Territory Government.

Now, on a much more pleasant note, I would like to add my remarks to those of other senators in farewelling Kevin McAlister. I would like particularly to mention the willingness and courtesy with which Kevin has conducted his duties at all times. Kevin's office, of course, is across the corridor from my office on the Opposition side. He has been a most pleasant neighbour. It was particularly heartening to see Kevin McAlister return to his duties after a bout of illness which may well have caused the retirement of a less courageous person . Kevin is a reserved sort of person and we know little about his life before he joined the Senate some 15 years ago other than-this was mentioned by Senator Peter Baume-that he, as the town's barber, cut the hair and shaved with a cut- throat razor the heads and faces of the inhabitants of Captain's Flat. For those who do not know it, Captain's Flat is a once thriving mining community just outside Queanbeyan. He watched that town go from boom to bust. I think that Kevin has had a very fascinating life. He has been a very quiet person here. I have no doubt that at some time in the future we would like to hear more of the tales of his past at Captain's Flat. It is with regret that I watch him go. He is called away from us to the care of his garden, wife-not necessarily, of course, in that order-and a well deserved retirement. I am sure he takes with him all our good wishes for his future happiness.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 8.02 p.m. until 2 p.m. on Tuesday, 8 November 1983

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 8 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On Tuesday, 16 August 1983, did 700 Filipino workers strike against alleged slave labour conditions at the Australian-owned Dunlop factory in Manila which manufactures Grosby shoes for the Australian market.

(2) Was the Philippine military called in by that company to break up picket lines outside the plant on Friday, 19 August 1983, injuring a number of striking Filipinos, despite the fact that, under Philippine industrial law, that strike was perfectly legal.

(3) Was there a subsequent meeting in Manila between the Philippine Ministry of Labour and Employment, Dunlop lawyers and union lawyers, at which the Australian company was accused by the Ministry of Labour and Employment of breaking the collective bargaining agreement and, therefore, Philippine industrial law, by forcing its employees into compulsory overtime to meet deadlines for a recent large order.

(4) has the Grosby factory also broken the collective bargaining agreement in the areas of maternity leave payments, emergency allowances and missing leave forms, unauthorised illegal wage deductions, shortages in overtime payments and Sunday premium payments.
(5) Has the company also been accused of interference in union elections.
(6) Is this the same company that closed its Australian operations to take advantage of cheaper costs of manufacturing in South East Asia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) 400 Filipino workers at the Dunlop/Grosby factory in Manila went on strike from 16 to 19 August 1983. The 400 workers were members of KADIWA-the United Movement for Hope for Workers-at Grosby-Footwear. The issues that were in dispute are detailed below.
(2) On 18 August, the Philippine Ministry of Labour and Employment signed an order directing the strikers to return to work and certifying the dispute for compulsory arbitration.

On 19 August, an agreement to return to work, pending further negotiations, had been reached. This agreement apparently had not been transmitted to picketing workers before a group of management and other non-striking workers attempted to enter the factory. When local police intervened, violence ensued. Union leaders arrived on the scene shortly after the incident and explained the misunderstanding to the picketers, who agreed to return to work in return for the release of unionists arrested in the incident and the dropping of charges against them.

(3) According to the Philippine Ministry of Labour and Employment, the Grosby factory has not been accused of breaking the collective bargaining agreement or of violating Philippine labour laws. On 1 September 1983, the management and union representatives of Dunlop/Grosby signed an agreement resolving a number of issues. This agreement covers overtime, back wages and leave to cover temporary layoffs. All other grievances were resolved at a meeting covened by the National Labour Relations Council on 28 September 1983.

(4) According to a Philippine Ministry of Labour and Employment spokesman, the workers' grievances were: Compulsory overtime, temporary layoffs, determination of production quotas and the company's method of calculating wages.

(5) The Dunlop/Grosby company has not been accused of interference in union elections. The union has alleged that management is encouraging the entry of an alternative union into the factory. The Ministry of Labour and Employment spokesman did not mention this matter as a cause of the dispute.

(6) I am informed that Dunlop/Grosby has not closed its Australian operations. Last year it relocated its Melbourne operation to new premises in North Melbourne. The company also operates a factory in Geelong. The company provides employment for 681 people in Melbourne and Geelong. The relocation of operations carried out in August and September 1982 did not see any reduction in staff.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 5 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the current situation in relation to the Australian Capital Territory Veterans vis a vis concessional/free rail travel entitlement with regard to free rail travel for World War I veterans.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is:

ANSWER.PARA: World War I veterans including those resident in the Australian Capital Territory are eligible for unlimited free rail travel on all services operated by the Australian National Railways including the line between Canberra and Queanbeyan. The concession covers the first class fare component but not charges for sleeping berths and meals.

The New South Wales Transport authorities do not provide World War I veterans who reside in the Australian Capital Territory with free rail travel on the basis of World War I service alone. However, most of these veterans would qualify for free or concessional travel, subject to certain restrictions, on the New South Wales rail system by virtue of being service pensioners with pensioner health benefits cards.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 October 1983 (Hansard page 1036) Senator Bolkus asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, a question without notice as to when it was envisaged that that part of the Fry Committee report recommending registration of foreign dentists in Australia would be implemented.

QUESTION.PARA: The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The report of the Committee of Inquiry into the recognition of overseas qualifications (Fry Committee) was tabled in the Parliament on 12 May this year.
The report was discussed with State and Territorial Ministers responsible for immigration and ethnic affairs in July when a large measure of support for it was expressed.

The report addresses complex issues (including recognition procedures for dentistry) which affect a wide range of Commonwealth, State and autonomous agencies. The report is being considered in detail by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in consultation with other interested bodies.
The Government attaches a great deal of importance to finding adequate and equitable solutions to the problems facing migrants and refugees in obtaining recognition of their qualifications.
It is expected that the Government's decision on the report will be announced towards the end of the year.
